verses.latin: Haec sunt nomina filiorum Israël, qui ingressi sunt Ægyptum cum Jacob: singuli cum domibus suis introierunt:
verses.english: These are the names of the sons of Israel who migrated into Egypt with Jacob, each one entering with his own household:

verses.latin: Ruben, Simeon, Levi, Juda,
verses.english: Reuben, Simeon, Levi, Judah,

verses.latin: Issachar, Zabulon, et Benjamin,
verses.english: Issachar, Zebulun, and Benjamin,

verses.latin: Dan, et Nephthali, Gad, et Aser.
verses.english: Dan, Naphtali, Gad, and Asher.

verses.latin: Omnes animæ, quæ egressæ sunt de femore Jacob, fuerunt septuaginta: Joseph autem in Ægypto erat.
verses.english: All the descendants who came forth from Jacob were seventy in number, counting Jacob himself; Joseph, however, was already residing in Egypt.

verses.latin: Mortuoque Joseph, et universo fratrum ejus, omnique cognatione illa,
verses.english: And so Joseph died, and all of his brothers, and all that entire generation of his relatives passed away.

verses.latin: Filii autem Israël creverunt, et quasi germinantes multiplicati sunt: impleveruntque terram.
verses.english: But the sons of Israel grew greatly in numbers, multiplying like seeds sown in the earth; they filled the entire land of Egypt.

verses.latin: Surrexit interea rex novus super Ægyptum, qui ignorabat Joseph:
verses.english: In the meantime, a new king arose over Egypt, one who did not know or remember Joseph's contributions and legacy.

verses.latin: et ait ad populum suum: Ecce, populus filiorum Israël multus, et fortior nobis est.
verses.english: He spoke to his own people, saying, 'Look, the nation of the sons of Israel is numerous, and they are becoming stronger than we are.'

verses.latin: Venite, sapienter opprimamus eum, ne forte multiplicetur, et si ingruerit contra nos bellum, addatur inimicis nostris, expugnatisque nobis, egrediatur de terra.
verses.english: Come, let us deal cunningly with them, lest they multiply further, and if war breaks out against us, they might join our enemies, fight against us, and then depart from our land entirely.

verses.latin: Præposuit itaque eis magistros operum, ut affligerent eos oneribus: ædificaveruntque urbes tabernaculorum Pharaoni, Phithom, et Raamses.
verses.english: Therefore, the Egyptians appointed taskmasters over them to oppress the Israelites with heavy burdens. The Israelites then built storage cities for Pharaoh: Pithom and Raamses.

verses.latin: Quantoque opprimebant eos, tanto magis multiplicabantur, et crescebant. Oderantque filios Israël Ægyptii,
verses.english: But the more the Egyptians oppressed them, the more the Israelites multiplied and grew. This caused the Egyptians to despise the sons of Israel even more,

verses.latin: et affligebant eos per singula opera,
verses.english: and they afflicted them with harsh servitude in every kind of work.

verses.latin: et ad amaritudinem perducebant vitam eorum operibus duris luti et lateris, omnique famulatu, quo in terræ operibus premebantur.
verses.english: They made their lives bitter with hard labor in mortar and bricks, and with all types of forced labor in the fields, imposing every kind of heavy agricultural work upon them.

verses.latin: Dixit autem rex Ægypti obstetricibus Hebræorum, quarum una vocabatur Sephra, altera Phua,
verses.english: Then the king of Egypt spoke to the Hebrew midwives—one of whom was named Shiphrah, and the other Puah—

verses.latin: præcipiens: Quando obstetricabitis Hebræas, et partus tempus advenerit: si masculus fuerit, interficite eum: sin femina, reservate.
verses.english: commanding them: 'When you attend to the Hebrew women in childbirth, and the time for delivery comes: if it is a son, you must kill him; but if it is a daughter, you may let her live.'

verses.latin: Timuerunt autem obstetrices Deum, et non fecerunt juxta præceptum regis Ægypti, sed conservabant mares.
verses.english: However, the midwives feared God more than the king. They did not do as the king of Egypt commanded, but allowed the male children to live.

verses.latin: Quibus ad se accersitis, rex ait: Quid hoc est quod facere voluistis, ut pueros mares reservaretis?
verses.english: So the king summoned the midwives and asked them, 'Why have you done this, allowing the male children to live?'

verses.latin: Quæ responderunt: Non sunt Hebrææ sicut Ægyptiæ mulieres: ipsæ enim obstetricandi habent scientiam, et priusquam veniamus ad eas, pariunt.
verses.english: They answered Pharaoh: 'The Hebrew women are not like the Egyptian women; they are strong and give birth quickly, and they have already delivered before we midwives can even arrive to assist them.'

verses.latin: Bene ergo fecit Deus obstetricibus: et crevit populus, et confortatus est nimis.
verses.english: Therefore, God dealt kindly with the midwives and blessed them; and the people of Israel continued to increase and grew exceedingly strong.

verses.latin: Et quia timuerunt obstetrices Deum, ædificavit illis domos.
verses.english: And because the midwives feared God, He built up their households and gave them families of their own.

verses.latin: Præcepit ergo Pharao omni populo suo, dicens: Quidquid masculini sexus natum fuerit, in flumen projicite: quidquid feminini, reservate.
verses.english: So Pharaoh then gave a command to all his people, saying, 'Every son who is born to the Hebrews, you must throw into the Nile River; but every daughter, you may let live.'

verses.latin: Abiit ergo vir de domo Levi, et accepit uxorem de filiabus ejusdem.
verses.english: A man from the tribe of Levi married a woman from the very same tribe of Levi.

verses.latin: Quæ concepit, et peperit filium: et videns eum elegantem, abscondit tribus mensibus.
verses.english: She conceived and bore a son. When she saw that he was a healthy and beautiful child, she hid him for three months.

verses.latin: Et cum celare non posset ultra, sumpsit fiscellam scirpeam, et linivit eam bitumine ac pice: et posuit in ea infantulum, et exposuit in carecto juxta ripam fluminis.
verses.english: When she could no longer hide him, she took a basket made of reeds and waterproofed it with tar and pitch. She placed the baby in it and set it among the reeds by the bank of the river.

verses.latin: Steteruntque sorores ejus procul, et considerabant quid ei accideret.
verses.english: And the baby's sister stood at a distance, watching to see what would happen to him.

verses.latin: Ecce autem descendebat filia Pharaonis, ut lavaretur in flumine: et puellae ejus gradiebantur per mensuram ripae. Quæ cum vidisset fiscellam in carecto, misit unam de famulabus suis: et allatam aperiens, conspexit in ea parvulum vagientem: et miserta ejus, ait: De parvulis Hebraeorum iste est.
verses.english: Then Pharaoh's daughter went down to bathe in the river, while her attendants walked along the river's bank. When she saw the basket among the reeds, she sent one of her servants to get it. When the basket was brought to her and opened, she saw the crying baby inside. She felt compassion for him and said, "This is one of the Hebrew children."

verses.latin: Cui locuta est soror ejus: Vis vocem tibi nutricem de Hebraeis, et alat tibi infantulum?
verses.english: Then the baby's sister spoke to Pharaoh's daughter, "Do you want me to go and call a Hebrew nurse for you, so she can nurse the baby for you?"

verses.latin: Respondit: Vade. Perrexit puella, et vocavit matrem ejus.
verses.english: Pharaoh's daughter replied, "Go." So the girl went and called the baby's mother.

verses.latin: Cui Pharaonis filia ait: Accipe puerum istum, et lacta mihi: ego mercedem dabo tibi. Suscepit mulier, et lactavit puerum.
verses.english: Pharaoh's daughter said to her, "Take this child and nurse him for me, and I will pay you your wages." So the woman took the child and nursed him.

verses.latin: Cumque crevisset, tradidit eum filiae Pharaonis. Quae adoptavit eum in filium, et vocavit nomen ejus Moysen, dicens: Quia de aqua tuli eum.
verses.english: When the child had grown up, his mother gave him back to Pharaoh's daughter. She adopted him as her own son and named him Moses, explaining that she had drawn him out of the water.

verses.latin: In diebus illis, post multum temporis, egressus Moyses ad fratres suos, et videns afflictionem eorum, virum Aegyptium percutientem quendam de Hebraeis fratribus suis.
verses.english: In those days, after a long time had passed, Moses went out to his people, the Hebrews. He saw their suffering and watched an Egyptian man striking one of his Hebrew kinsmen.

verses.latin: Et cum circumspexisset huc atque illuc, et nullum adesse videret, percussum Aegyptium abscondit sabulo.
verses.english: He looked around carefully, and when he saw no one else was around, he struck down the Egyptian and buried him in the sand.

verses.latin: Egrediensque die altero, vidit duos viros Hebraeos rixantes: dixitque ei qui faciebat injuriam: Cur percutis proximum tuum?
verses.english: The next day, when Moses went out again, he saw two Hebrew men quarreling. He said to the one who was in the wrong, "Why are you striking your fellow man?"

verses.latin: Qui respondit: Quis te constituit principem et judicem super nos? Num occidere me vis, sicut occidisti Aegyptium heri? Timuit Moyses, et ait: Quomodo palam facta est res ista?
verses.english: The man replied, "Who appointed you a ruler and a judge over us? Do you mean to kill me as you killed the Egyptian yesterday?" Moses became afraid and said to himself, "How did this deed become known?"

verses.latin: Audivitque Pharao sermonem istum, et quærebat occidere Moysen. Qui fugiens de conspectu ejus, moratus est in terra Madian, sedens juxta puteum.
verses.english: When Pharaoh heard this report, he sought to kill Moses. But Moses fled from Pharaoh's presence and settled in the land of Midian, sitting by a well.

verses.latin: Erat autem sacerdoti Madian septem filiae, quae venientes hauriebant aquam, et implebant canales, ut adaquaretur grex patris sui.
verses.english: The priest of Midian had seven daughters. They came to draw water and fill the watering troughs to water their father's flock.

verses.latin: Supervenientibusque pastoribus, abigebant eas: et Moyses consurgens defendit illas, haustaque aqua potavit oves earum.
verses.english: Other shepherds would often come and drive them away from the well. But Moses rose to their defense, and after drawing water himself, he watered their sheep for them.

verses.latin: Reversisque ad Raguel patrem suum, dixit eis: Cur solito velocius venistis?
verses.english: When they returned to Reuel, their father, he asked them, "Why have you come back sooner than usual today?"

verses.latin: Responderunt: Vir Aegyptius liberavit nos de manu pastorum: insuper et hausta aqua potavit oves nostras.
verses.english: They answered, "An Egyptian man rescued us from the shepherds and even drew water for us, then watered our sheep."

verses.latin: At ille: Ubi est? cur dimisistis virum? Vocate eum ut comedat panem.
verses.english: Reuel said, "Where is he now? Why did you leave him there? Go and invite him to come eat a meal with us."

verses.latin: Juravit ergo Moyses habitare cum eo. Qui accepit Sephoram filiam suam uxorem illi.
verses.english: So Moses agreed and swore to stay with Reuel. Reuel then gave Zipporah, his daughter, to be Moses' wife.

verses.latin: Quæ peperit ei filium, quem vocavit Gersam, dicens: Advena fui in terra aliena.
verses.english: She bore him a son, whom Moses named Gershom, explaining that he had been a sojourner in a foreign land.

verses.latin: Rursumque peperit alterum, quem vocavit Eliezer, dicens: Deus enim patris mei, adjutor meus, et eruit me de manu Pharaonis.
verses.english: Later, she bore another son, whom Moses named Eliezer, saying, "For the God of my father has been my helper, and delivered me from Pharaoh's hand."

verses.latin: Post multos ergo dierum, mortuus est rex Aegypti: et ingemuerunt filii Israel propter opera, et clamaverunt, et ascendit clamor eorum ad Deum de operibus.
verses.english: After a very long time, the king of Egypt died. But the children of Israel continued to groan under their oppressive labor. They cried out, and their cry for help from their labor went up to God.

verses.latin: Et audivit Deus gemitum eorum, et recordatus est pacti sui quod pepigit cum Abraham, Isaac et Jacob.
verses.english: God heard their groaning and remembered His solemn covenant that He had established with Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob.

verses.latin: Et respexit Dominus filios Israel, et cognovit eos.
verses.english: The Lord looked upon the children of Israel, and He truly acknowledged their plight.

verses.latin: Moyses autem pascebat oves Jethro cognati sui sacerdotis Madian: cumque minasset gregem ad interiora deserti, venit ad montem Dei Horeb.
verses.english: Moses was shepherding the sheep belonging to Jethro, his father-in-law, who was the priest of Midian. He led the flock deep into the desert and came to Horeb, the mountain of God.

verses.latin: Apparuitque ei Dominus in flamma ignis de medio rubi: et videbat quod rubus arderet et non combureretur.
verses.english: Then the Lord God appeared to him in a flame of fire coming out of the middle of a bush. Moses saw that the bush was burning with fire, yet it was not consumed or destroyed.

verses.latin: Dixitque Moyses: Ibo, et videbo visionem hanc magnam, quare non comburatur rubus.
verses.english: And Moses said to himself: "I will go and see this great sight, to understand why the bush does not burn away."

verses.latin: Cernens autem Dominus quod pergeret ad videndum, vocavit eum de medio rubi, et ait: Moyses, Moyses. Qui respondit: Adsum.
verses.english: When the Lord saw that Moses was moving closer to investigate, God called to him from the middle of the bush, saying: "Moses, Moses!" And Moses answered: "Here I am."

verses.latin: Et ait: Ne adpropinques huc: solve calceamentum de pedibus tuis: locus enim, in quo stas, terra sancta est.
verses.english: Then God said: "Do not come any closer here. Take off the sandals from your feet, for the place on which you are standing is holy ground."

verses.latin: Et ait: Ego sum Deus patris tui, Deus Abraham, Deus Isaac, et Deus Jacob. Abscondit Moyses faciem suam: non enim audebat aspicere contra Deum.
verses.english: He continued: "I am the God of your father, the God of Abraham, the God of Isaac, and the God of Jacob." Moses covered his face because he did not dare to look directly at God.

verses.latin: Dixitque Dominus: Videns vidi afflictionem populi mei in Ægypto, et clamorem ejus audivi propter duritiam eorum qui præsunt operibus: et sciens dolorem ejus,
verses.english: And the Lord God said: "I have clearly seen the suffering of my people in Egypt. I have heard their cry because of the harshness of those who are over them in their work. I know their pain,

verses.latin: descendi ut liberem eos de manibus Ægyptiorum, et educam de terra illa in terram bonam et spatiosam, in terram quæ fluit lacte et melle, ad loca Chananei et Hethæi et Amorrhæi et Pherezæi et Hevæi et Jebusæi.
verses.english: and so I have come down to deliver them from the power of the Egyptians and to lead them out of that land into a good and spacious land—a land flowing with milk and honey. This is the land of the Canaanites, Hittites, Amorites, Perizzites, Hivites, and Jebusites.

verses.latin: Clamor ergo filiorum Israel pervenit ad me: vidique afflictionem eorum, qua ab Ægyptiis opprimuntur.
verses.english: The cry of the children of Israel has indeed reached me, and I have seen how the Egyptians oppress them.

verses.latin: Sed veni, et mittam te ad Pharaonem, ut educas populum meum, filios Israel, de Ægypto.
verses.english: Therefore, come now, and I will send you to Pharaoh, so that you may lead my people, the children of Israel, out of Egypt.

verses.latin: Dixitque Moyses ad Deum: Quis sum ego, ut vadam ad Pharaonem, et educam filios Israel de Ægypto?
verses.english: And Moses said to God: "Who am I, that I should go to Pharaoh and lead the children of Israel out of Egypt?"

verses.latin: Et ait: Ego ero tecum: et hoc habebis signum, quod miserim te: Cum eduxeris populum de Ægypto, immolabis Deo super montem istum.
verses.english: God said: "I will be with you. And this will be the sign that I have sent you: When you have led the people out of Egypt, you will offer sacrifice to God on this very mountain."

verses.latin: Dixit Moyses ad Deum: Ecce ego vadam ad filios Israel, et dicam eis: Deus patrum vestrorum misit me ad vos. Si dixerint mihi: Quod est nomen ejus? quid dicam eis?
verses.english: Moses then said to God: "Look, when I go to the children of Israel and tell them, 'The God of your fathers has sent me to you,' and they ask me, 'What is His name?'—what shall I tell them?"

verses.latin: Dixit Deus ad Moysen: Ego sum qui sum. Ait: Sic dices filiis Israel: Qui est, misit me ad vos.
verses.english: God said to Moses: "I AM WHO I AM." He added: "Thus you shall say to the children of Israel: 'The One Who Is—has sent me to you.'"

verses.latin: Dixitque iterum Deus ad Moysen: Hæc dices filiis Israel: Dominus Deus patrum vestrorum, Deus Abraham, Deus Isaac, et Deus Jacob, misit me ad vos: hoc nomen mihi est in æternum, et hoc memoriale meum in generationem et generationem.
verses.english: God also said to Moses: "Thus you shall say to the children of Israel: 'The Lord God of your fathers, the God of Abraham, the God of Isaac, and the God of Jacob, has sent me to you.' This is My name forever, and this is My memorial to all generations.

verses.latin: Vade, et congrega seniores Israel, et dices ad eos: Dominus Deus patrum vestrorum, Deus Abraham, Deus Isaac, et Deus Jacob, apparuit mihi, dicens: Visitans visitavi vos, et omnia quæ acciderunt vobis in Ægypto:
verses.english: Go and gather the elders of Israel. Tell them: 'The Lord God of your fathers, the God of Abraham, the God of Isaac, and the God of Jacob, has appeared to me, saying: I have indeed visited you and seen everything that has happened to you in Egypt.

verses.latin: et dixi ut educam vos de afflictionibus Ægypti, in terram Chananei et Hethæi et Amorrhæi et Pherezæi et Hevæi et Jebusæi, ad terram fluentem lacte et melle.
verses.english: And I have said that I will lead you out of the afflictions of Egypt into the land of the Canaanites, Hittites, Amorites, Perizzites, Hivites, and Jebusites—a land flowing with milk and honey.'

verses.latin: Et audient vocem tuam: ingredierisque tu et seniores Israel ad regem Ægypti, et dicetis ad eum: Dominus Deus Hebræorum vocavit nos: imus viam trium dierum in solitudinem, ut sacrificemus Domino Deo nostro.
verses.english: They will listen to your voice. Then you and the elders of Israel shall go to the king of Egypt and tell him: 'The Lord God of the Hebrews has summoned us. Let us go on a journey of three days into the wilderness, so that we may offer sacrifice to the Lord our God.'

verses.latin: Sed ego scio quod non dimittet vos rex Ægypti ut eatis, nisi per manum magnam.
verses.english: But I know that the king of Egypt will not let you go, unless it is by a mighty hand.

verses.latin: Extendam enim manum meam, et percutiam Ægyptum in omnibus mirabilibus meis, quæ facturus sum in medio eorum: et post hæc dimittet vos.
verses.english: For I will stretch out My hand and strike Egypt with all My wonders, which I will perform in their midst. And after these things, he will let you go.

verses.latin: Daboque gratiam populo huic coram Ægyptiis: et cum egrediemini, non exibitis vacui:
verses.english: I will give this people favor in the sight of the Egyptians, so that when you depart, you will not leave empty-handed.

verses.latin: sed spoliabitis Ægyptios, et auferetis ab eis vasa argentea et aurea, ac vestem, ponetisque super filios vestros et filias, et diripietis Ægyptum.
verses.english: Instead, you will plunder the Egyptians. You will take from them silver articles and gold articles, and clothing. You will put these upon your sons and your daughters, and thus you will strip Egypt of its riches.

verses.latin: Respondit Moyses, et ait: Non credent mihi, neque audient vocem meam, sed dicent: Non apparuit tibi Dominus.
verses.english: Moses answered the Lord, saying: "They will not believe me, nor will they listen to what I say. Instead, they will insist: 'The Lord never appeared to you.'"

verses.latin: Dixit ergo ad eum Dominus: Quid est hoc, quod tenes in manu tua? Respondit: Virga.
verses.english: The Lord then asked Moses: "What is that you are holding in your hand?" Moses answered: "A staff."

verses.latin: Et ait: Projice illam in terram. Projecit, et versa est in colubrum: fugiebatque Moyses.
verses.english: And the Lord said: "Throw it on the ground." Moses threw it down, and it turned into a serpent. Moses immediately fled from it.

verses.latin: Et dixit Dominus: Extende manum tuam, et apprehende caudam ejus. Extendit, et apprehensum tenuit: reversaque est in virgam in manu ejus.
verses.english: Then the Lord said: "Reach out your hand and grasp its tail." Moses stretched out his hand, seized it, and held it. The serpent then returned to being a staff in his hand.

verses.latin: Ut credant, inquit, quia apparuit tibi Dominus Deus patrum eorum, Deus Abraham, Deus Isaac, et Deus Jacob.
verses.english: The Lord said: "Do this so that they may believe that the Lord, the God of their fathers—the God of Abraham, the God of Isaac, and the God of Jacob—has truly appeared to you."

verses.latin: Dixitque Dominus rursum: Introduc manum tuam in sinum tuum. Cum immisisset in sinum, protulit leprosam instar nivis.
verses.english: The Lord spoke again, saying: "Now, put your hand inside your cloak." When Moses placed his hand inside, he pulled it out, and it was leprous, white as snow.

verses.latin: Et ait: Revertere manus tua in sinum tuum. Et reversa est, protulitque illam de sinu suo sicut carnem alteram.
verses.english: And He said: "Put your hand back into your cloak." Moses put it back, and when he drew it out of his cloak, it was restored, just like his other flesh.

verses.latin: Quod si, inquit, non crediderint tibi, neque audierint sermonem signi prioris, credent sermonem signi sequentis.
verses.english: The Lord said: "If they do not believe you, nor listen to the message of the first sign, they will then believe the message of the second sign."

verses.latin: Quod si nec duobus his signis crediderint, neque audierint vocem tuam, sume aquam fluminis, et effunde in aridam: et quod hauseris de fluvio, vertetur in sanguinem.
verses.english: "But if they do not believe even these two signs, nor listen to your voice, then take water from the river and pour it on the dry ground. What you draw from the river will turn into blood."

verses.latin: Ait Moyses: Obsecro, Domine, non sum eloquens ab heri et nudiustertius, et ex quo locutus es ad servum tuum: impedita et tardiori lingua sum.
verses.english: Moses said: "Oh, please, Lord! I am not an eloquent speaker. I haven't been from yesterday, nor the day before, and not even since you began speaking to your servant. I am slow of speech and tongue."

verses.latin: Dixit Dominus ad eum: Quis fecit os hominis? aut quis fabricatus est mutum et surdum, videntem et cæcum? nonne ego?
verses.english: The Lord said to him: "Who gave humans their mouths? Or who made them mute or deaf, or able to see or blind? Was it not I, the Lord?"

verses.latin: I nunc, et ego ero in ore tuo: et docebo te quid loquaris.
verses.english: "Now, go! I will be with your mouth and will teach you what you are to say."

verses.latin: At ille ait: Obsecro, Domine, mitte quem misurus es.
verses.english: But Moses replied: "Oh, please, Lord! Send someone else to whom you intend to send."

verses.latin: Iratus Dominus contra Moysen, ait: Nonne Aaron frater tuus Leviticus est? scio quod eloquens sit: ecce ipse egreditur in occursum tuum, et videns te lætabitur.
verses.english: The Lord became angry with Moses and said: "Is not Aaron, your brother, a Levite? I know that he is eloquent. Look, he is coming out to meet you, and when he sees you, he will be glad."

verses.latin: Loquere ad eum, et pone sermones meos in ore ejus: et ego ero in ore tuo, et in ore illius, et ostendam vobis quid agere debeatis.
verses.english: "Speak to him, and put my words in his mouth. I will be with your mouth and with his mouth, and I will show both of you what you must do."

verses.latin: Ille loquetur pro te ad populum, et ipse erit os tuum: tu autem eris ei in his quæ ad Deum pertinent.
verses.english: "He will speak for you to the people, and he will be your mouth. You, in turn, will be like God for him, guiding him in what pertains to God."

verses.latin: Virgam quoque hanc sume in manu tua, in qua facturus es signa.
verses.english: "Also, take this staff in your hand, with which you will perform the miraculous signs."

verses.latin: Abiit Moyses, et reversus est ad Jethro socerum suum, dixitque ei: Vadam, et revertar ad fratres meos in Ægyptum, ut videam si adhuc vivant. Et ait ei Jethro: Vade in pace.
verses.english: Moses went and returned to Jethro, his father-in-law, and said to him: "I need to go back to my brothers in Egypt to see if they are still alive." Jethro said to him: "Go in peace."

verses.latin: Dixit ergo Dominus ad Moysen in Madian: Vade, et revertere in Ægyptum: defuncti sunt enim omnes qui quærebant animam tuam.
verses.english: The Lord then said to Moses in Midian: "Go, and return to Egypt, for all those who sought to kill you are dead."

verses.latin: Tulit Moyses uxorem suam, et filios, et imposuit eos super asinum: reversusque est in Ægyptum, portans virgam Dei in manu sua.
verses.english: So Moses took his wife and his sons and set them upon a donkey. He returned to Egypt, carrying the staff of God in his hand.

verses.latin: Et ait Dominus ad Moysen: Cum regressus fueris in Ægyptum, vide ut omnia ostenta quæ posui in manu tua, facias coram Pharaone: ego indurabo cor ejus, et non dimittet populum.
verses.english: And the Lord said to Moses: "When you return to Egypt, be sure to perform all the wonders that I have put in your power before Pharaoh. However, I will harden his heart, and he will not let the people go."

verses.latin: Dicesque ad eum: Hæc dicit Dominus: Filius meus primogenitus Israel.
verses.english: "And you shall say to him: 'Thus says the Lord: Israel is My firstborn son.'"

verses.latin: Dimitte filium meum, ut serviat mihi: si nolueris dimittere, ecce ego interficiam filium tuum primogenitum.
verses.english: "'Let My son go, so that he may serve Me. If you refuse to let him go, behold, I will kill your firstborn son.'"

verses.latin: Factum est autem in via, in diversorio, occuivit ei Dominus, et volebat occidere eum.
verses.english: It came to pass on the way, at a lodging place, that the Lord met Moses and intended to kill him.

verses.latin: Tulit illico Seffora cultrum lapideum, et circumcidit præputium filii sui, et tetigit pedes ejus, dixitque: Sponsus sanguinum tu mihi es.
verses.english: Immediately, Zipporah took a sharp flint knife and circumcised the foreskin of her son. She then touched Moses' feet with it and said: "You are a bridegroom of blood to me."

verses.latin: Et recessit ab eo: post verba enim Sponsus sanguinum, statim eum Dominus dimisit.
verses.english: So the Lord departed from him. For after she spoke the words "bridegroom of blood," the Lord immediately let him go.

verses.latin: Dixitque Dominus ad Aaron: Vade in occursum Moysi in desertum. Qui perrexit, et obviam ei factus est in monte Dei, et osculatus est eum.
verses.english: And the Lord said to Aaron: "Go into the desert to meet Moses." So Aaron went, and he met him at the mountain of God and kissed him.

verses.latin: Narravitque Moyses Aaron omnia verba Domini quæ miserat, et de signis quæ mandaverat ei.
verses.english: And Moses told Aaron all the words of the Lord with which He had sent him, and all about the miraculous signs which He had commanded him to perform.

verses.latin: Veneruntque Moyses et Aaron, et congregaverunt omnes seniores filiorum Israel.
verses.english: So Moses and Aaron went and gathered all the elders of the children of Israel.

verses.latin: Locutusque est Aaron omnia verba quæ dixerat Dominus ad Moysen: et fecit signa coram populo.
verses.english: And Aaron spoke all the words that the Lord had said to Moses, and he performed the miraculous signs before the people.

verses.latin: Et credidit populus. Et audierunt Dominum visitasse filios Israel, et aspexisse afflictionem eorum: et proni adoraverunt.
verses.english: And the people believed. They heard that the Lord had visited the children of Israel and had seen their affliction, and they bowed down and worshipped.

verses.latin: Post haec venerunt Moyses et Aaron, et dixerunt Pharaoni: Haec dicit Dominus Deus Israel: Dimitte populum meum, ut sacrificet mihi in deserto.
verses.english: After these events, Moses and Aaron came and spoke to Pharaoh, saying, "The Lord, the God of Israel, says this: Release my people, so they may offer a sacrifice to me in the desert."

verses.latin: At ille respondit: Quis est Dominus, ut audiam vocem ejus, et dimittam Israel? nescio Dominum, et Israel non dimittam.
verses.english: But Pharaoh replied, "Who is the Lord that I should listen to His voice and release Israel? I do not know the Lord, and I will not release Israel."

verses.latin: Dixerunt: Deus Hebraeorum vocavit nos, ut eamus viam trium dierum in solitudinem, et sacrificemus Domino Deo nostro: ne forte accidat nobis pestis, aut gladius.
verses.english: Moses and Aaron said to him, "The God of the Hebrews has called upon us to go a three-day journey into the desert, to offer sacrifice to the Lord our God. We must do this, lest He strike us with plague or with the sword."

verses.latin: Respondit Pharao: Quare Moyses et Aaron sollicitatis populum ab operibus suis? ite ad onera vestra.
verses.english: Pharaoh replied to them, "Why, Moses and Aaron, do you distract the people from their labors? Go back to your own burdens."

verses.latin: Dixitque Pharao: Multus est populus terrae, videtis: multo magis si cessaverint ab operibus.
verses.english: Pharaoh then said, "Look, the people of the land are numerous, as you can see. Think how much worse it will be if they stop working."

verses.latin: Praecepit itaque Pharao in die illo praefectis operum et exactoribus populi, dicens:
verses.english: Therefore, on that very day, Pharaoh commanded the taskmasters over the people and their foremen, saying:

verses.latin: Non ultra dabitis paleas populo ad conficiendos lateres, sicut prius: sed ipsi vadant, et colligant sibi paleas.
verses.english: "You will no longer give straw to the people for making bricks, as you did before. Instead, they must go and gather straw for themselves."

verses.latin: Et mensuram laterum, quam prius faciebant, imponetis super eos, nec minuetis ex ea quidquam: sunt enim otiosi, et propter hoc clamant, dicentes: Eamus, et sacrificemus Deo nostro.
verses.english: "And you will impose upon them the same quota of bricks that they previously made; you are not to reduce it in any way. For they are idle, and because of this, they cry out, saying, 'Let us go and offer sacrifice to our God.'"

verses.latin: Aggraventur opera virorum, et expleant eam: et non intendant sermonibus mendacibus.
verses.english: "Let the men's work be made heavier, and let them complete it; and let them not pay attention to false words."

verses.latin: Igitur egressi praefecti operum et exactores ad populum, dixerunt: Sic dicit Pharao: Non do vobis paleas.
verses.english: So the taskmasters and foremen went out to the people and said, "Thus says Pharaoh: I will not give you straw."

verses.latin: Ite, et colligite vobis paleas ubi invenire poteritis: nihilominus de opere pristino non minuetur quidquam.
verses.english: "Go yourselves and gather straw wherever you can find it. Nevertheless, your quota of the former work will not be reduced at all."

verses.latin: Dispersusque est populus per omnem terram Aegypti ad colligendas paleas.
verses.english: So the people were scattered throughout all the land of Egypt to gather straw.

verses.latin: Officinae quoque praefecti urgentes, dicebant: Completote opus vestrum per singulos dies, sicut prius, quando dabantur vobis paleae.
verses.english: And the taskmasters urged them on, saying, "Complete your daily work, just as before, when you were given straw."

verses.latin: Flagellati sunt itaque exactores filiorum Israel, quos constituerant super eos praefecti operum Pharaonis, dicentes: Quare non impletis statutum, in faciendo lateres sicut hesterna die et nudiustertius?
verses.english: So the foremen of the sons of Israel, whom Pharaoh's taskmasters had appointed over them, were beaten. The taskmasters asked them, "Why have you not completed the required number of bricks today, just as yesterday and the day before yesterday?"

verses.latin: Veneruntque praepositi filiorum Israel, et clamaverunt ad Pharaonem, dicentes: Cur sic agis contra servos tuos?
verses.english: Then the foremen of the sons of Israel came and cried out to Pharaoh, saying, "Why do you treat your servants in this manner?"

verses.latin: Paleae non dantur nobis, et lateres similiter exiguntur: ecce servi tui flagellis caedimur, et iniuste agitur nobiscum.
verses.english: "Straw is not given to us, yet bricks are still demanded from us. Behold, your servants are beaten with whips, and we are treated unjustly."

verses.latin: Qui respondit: Otiosi estis, et propter hoc dicitis: Eamus, et sacrificemus Domino.
verses.english: Pharaoh replied, "You are idle, and because of this, you say, 'Let us go and offer sacrifice to the Lord.'"

verses.latin: Ite ergo, et operamini: paleas non dabuntur vobis, et statutum laterum implebitis.
verses.english: "Go now and work. Straw will not be given to you, but you must complete the required number of bricks."

verses.latin: Videruntque se praepositi filiorum Israel in malo, eo quod diceretur eis: Non minuetur quidquam de laterum pristina summa per singulos dies.
verses.english: The foremen of the sons of Israel saw themselves in trouble, because they were told, "Nothing will be reduced from the original number of bricks required each day."

verses.latin: Occurrentesque Moysi et Aaron, qui stabant ex latere, quando egrederentur a Pharaone,
verses.english: And as they came out from Pharaoh, they met Moses and Aaron, who were standing there waiting for them.

verses.latin: dixerunt: Videat Dominus et judicet, quoniam foetere fecistis nomen nostrum coram Pharaone et servis ejus, et dedistis gladium in manus eorum ut interficerent nos.
verses.english: And they said to them, "May the Lord see and judge! For you have made our name foul before Pharaoh and his servants, and you have put a sword in their hands to kill us."

verses.latin: Reversusque Moyses ad Dominum, ait: Domine, cur afflixisti populum istum? quare misisti me?
verses.english: Then Moses returned to the Lord and said, "Lord, why have you afflicted this people? Why did you send me?"

verses.latin: ex quo enim ingressus sum ad Pharaonem ut loquerer in nomine tuo, afflixit populum tuum: et non liberasti.
verses.english: "For since I came to Pharaoh to speak in Your name, he has afflicted Your people, and You have not delivered them."

verses.latin: Dixit autem Dominus ad Moysen: Nunc videbis quæ facturus sum Pharaoni: per manum enim fortem ejiciet eos, et in brachio magno ejiciet illos de terra sua.
verses.english: But the Lord said to Moses, "Now you will see what I am about to do to Pharaoh. For by My strong hand, Pharaoh will be compelled to drive the Israelites out, and with a mighty arm, he will expel them from his land."

verses.latin: Locutusque est Dominus ad Moysen, dicens: Ego Dominus.
verses.english: And the Lord spoke to Moses, saying, "I am the Lord, God Almighty."

verses.latin: Et visus sum Abraham, Isaac et Jacob in Deo omnipotente: et nomen meum Adonai non indicavi eis.
verses.english: And I appeared to Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob as God Almighty, but My name, YHWH, in its full meaning and power, I did not fully reveal to them.

verses.latin: Et fœdus meum statui cum eis, ut darem illis terram Chanaan, terram peregrinationis eorum, in qua fuerunt advenæ.
verses.english: And I established My covenant with them, promising to give them the land of Canaan—the land where they lived as sojourners and strangers.

verses.latin: Ego igitur audivi gemitum filiorum Israel, quos Ægyptii in servitutem redegerunt: et recordatus sum fœderis mei.
verses.english: Therefore, I have heard the groaning of the children of Israel, whom the Egyptians have enslaved, and I have remembered My covenant.

verses.latin: Ideo dic filiis Israel: Ego Dominus qui educam vos de ergastulo Ægyptiorum, et eruam de servitute, et redimam in brachio excelso, et faciam judicia magna.
verses.english: Therefore say to the children of Israel: 'I am the Lord, who will lead you out from under the heavy burdens imposed by the Egyptians. I will rescue you from slavery, and I will redeem you with My powerful, outstretched arm, and I will execute great judgments upon Egypt.'

verses.latin: Et assumam vos mihi in populum, et ero vester Deus: et scietis quia ego Dominus Deus vester, qui eduxerim vos de ergastulo Ægyptiorum:
verses.english: And I will take you to Myself as My own people, and I will be your God. You will know for certain that I am the Lord your God, who has led you out from under the burdens of the Egyptians.

verses.latin: et inducam vos in terram, super quam levavi manum meam, ut darem illam Abraham, Isaac, et Jacob: et dabo illam vobis possidendam. Ego Dominus.
verses.english: And I will bring you into the land for which I solemnly swore to give it to Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob. I will give that land to you as your possession. I am the Lord.

verses.latin: Narravit ergo Moyses omnia filiis Israel: qui non acquieverunt ei propter angustiam spiritus, et opus durum.
verses.english: So Moses told all these things to the children of Israel, but they would not listen to him because of their deep discouragement and the harshness of their labor.

verses.latin: Locutusque est Dominus ad Moysen, dicens:
verses.english: Then the Lord spoke to Moses again, saying:

verses.latin: Ingredere, et loquere ad Pharaonem regem Ægypti, ut dimittat filios Israel de terra sua.
verses.english: "Go and speak to Pharaoh, the king of Egypt, telling him to let the children of Israel leave his land."

verses.latin: Respondit Moyses coram Domino: Ecce filii Israel non audiunt me: et quomodo audiet Pharao, præsertim cum incircumcisus sim labiis?
verses.english: Moses replied before the Lord, "Look, the children of Israel themselves do not listen to me. So how will Pharaoh possibly listen to me, especially since I am a man of 'uncircumcised lips'—meaning my speech is ineffective or halting?"

verses.latin: Locutusque est Dominus ad Moysen et Aaron, et dedit mandatum ad filios Israel, et ad Pharaonem regem Ægypti, ut educerent filios Israel de terra Ægypti.
verses.english: And the Lord spoke to both Moses and Aaron, giving them a specific command for the children of Israel and for Pharaoh, the king of Egypt: that they were to lead the children of Israel out of the land of Egypt.

verses.latin: Isti sunt principes familiarum per domos suas. Filii Ruben primogeniti Israel: Henoch et Phallu, Hesron et Charmi:
verses.english: These are the heads of the tribal families by their ancestral houses. The sons of Reuben, who was Israel's firstborn, were Hanoch, Pallu, Hezron, and Carmi.

verses.latin: hæ cognationes Ruben. Filii Simeon: Jamuel et Jamin et Ahod, et Jachin et Sohar, et Saul filius Chananitidis: hæ familiæ Simeon.
verses.english: These are the clans descended from Reuben. The sons of Simeon were Jemuel, Jamin, Ohad, Jachin, Zohar, and Shaul, who was the son of a Canaanite woman. These are the families descended from Simeon.

verses.latin: Et hæc nomina filiorum Levi per cognationes suas: Gerson et Caath et Merari. Anni autem vitæ Levi fuerunt centum triginta septem.
verses.english: And these are the names of the sons of Levi, according to their clans: Gershon, Kohath, and Merari. Levi lived for one hundred thirty-seven years.

verses.latin: Filii Gerson: Lobni et Semei, per cognationes suas.
verses.english: The sons of Gershon were Libni and Shimei, by their respective clans.

verses.latin: Filii vero Caath: Amram et Isaar et Hebron et Oziel. Anni quoque vitæ Caath fuerunt centum triginta tres.
verses.english: The sons of Kohath were Amram, Izhar, Hebron, and Uzziel. Kohath himself lived for one hundred thirty-three years.

verses.latin: Filii Merari: Moolli et Musi. Hæ cognationes Levi per familias suas.
verses.english: The sons of Merari were Mahli and Mushi. These are the clans of Levi according to their family lines.

verses.latin: Accepit autem Amram uxorem suam Jochabed patruelem suam: quæ peperit ei Aaron et Moysen, et Mariam sororem eorum. Anni quoque vitæ Amram fuerunt centum triginta septem.
verses.english: Amram took Jochebed, his father's sister, as his wife. She bore him Aaron and Moses, as well as their sister Miriam. Amram lived for one hundred thirty-seven years.

verses.latin: Filii Isaar: Core et Nepheg et Zechri.
verses.english: The sons of Izhar were Korah, Nepheg, and Zichri.

verses.latin: Filii quoque Oziel: Misael et Elisaphan et Sethri.
verses.english: The sons of Uzziel were Mishael, Elzaphan, and Sithri.

verses.latin: Accepit autem Aaron uxorem Elisabeth filiam Aminadab, sororem Naasson: quæ peperit ei Nadab et Abiu et Eleazar et Ithamar.
verses.english: Aaron took as his wife Elisheba, the daughter of Amminadab and sister of Nahshon. She bore him Nadab, Abihu, Eleazar, and Ithamar.

verses.latin: Filii quoque Core: Aser et Elcana et Abiasaph: hæ cognationes Coritarum.
verses.english: The sons of Korah were Assir, Elkanah, and Abiasaph. These are the clans that descended from Korah.

verses.latin: Porro Eleazar filius Aaron accepit uxorem de filiabus Phutiel: quæ peperit ei Phinees. Hæc sunt capita familiarum leviticarum per cognationes suas.
verses.english: Furthermore, Eleazar, Aaron's son, took a wife from the daughters of Putiel, and she bore him Phinehas. These are the heads of the Levitical families according to their clans.

verses.latin: Iste est Aaron et Moyses, quibus præcepit Dominus ut educerent filios Israel de terra Ægypti per turbas suas.
verses.english: These are the very Aaron and Moses to whom the Lord gave the command to lead the children of Israel out of the land of Egypt, organized by their divisions.

verses.latin: Hi sunt qui loquuntur ad Pharaonem regem Ægypti, ut educant filios Israel de Ægypto: iste est Moyses et Aaron.
verses.english: These are the ones who spoke to Pharaoh, the king of Egypt, to lead the children of Israel out of Egypt. This refers to the very Moses and Aaron mentioned previously.

verses.latin: In die qua locutus est Dominus ad Moysen in terra Ægypti,
verses.english: On the day that the Lord spoke to Moses in the land of Egypt—

verses.latin: locutus est Dominus ad eum, dicens: Ego Dominus: loquere ad Pharaonem regem Ægypti omnia quæ ego loquor tibi.
verses.english: —the Lord spoke to him, saying, "I am the Lord. Speak to Pharaoh, the king of Egypt, everything that I tell you."

verses.latin: Dixitque Moyses coram Domino: Ecce incircumcisus labiis sum: quomodo audiet me Pharao?
verses.english: But Moses said before the Lord, "Look, I am a man of 'uncircumcised lips,' meaning my speech is ineffective. How then will Pharaoh possibly listen to me?"

verses.latin: Dixitque Dominus ad Moysen: Ecce constitui te quasi Deum Pharaonis: et Aaron frater tuus erit propheta tuus.
verses.english: The Lord said to Moses, "Listen, I have made you like a god to Pharaoh, and your brother Aaron will be your prophet."

verses.latin: Tu loqueris omnia quæ ego mandabo tibi: et ille loquetur Aaron fratri suo, ut educat filios Israel de terra Ægypti.
verses.english: You will speak everything I command you, and Aaron, your brother, will speak for you, so that he may lead the children of Israel out of the land of Egypt.

verses.latin: Sed ego indurabo cor ejus, et multiplicabo signa et ostenta mea in terra Ægypti.
verses.english: But I will make Pharaoh's heart stubborn, and I will multiply My signs and wonders in the land of Egypt.

verses.latin: Et non audiet vos: et extendam manum meam super Ægyptum, et educam exercitum meum, et populum meum filios Israel, de terra Ægypti per judicia maxima.
verses.english: He will not listen to you, so I will stretch out My hand over Egypt and bring out My army—My people, the children of Israel—from the land of Egypt through very great acts of judgment.

verses.latin: Et scient Ægyptii quia ego sum Dominus, quando extendero manum meam super Ægyptum, et eduxero filios Israel de medio eorum.
verses.english: And the Egyptians will know that I am the Lord when I stretch out My hand over Egypt and bring the children of Israel out from among them.

verses.latin: Fecerunt itaque Moyses et Aaron sicut præceperat Dominus.
verses.english: So Moses and Aaron did just as the Lord had commanded.

verses.latin: Moyses autem octoginta annorum erat, et Aaron octoginta trium, quando ad Pharaonem sunt locuti.
verses.english: Moses was eighty years old, and Aaron was eighty-three, when they spoke to Pharaoh.

verses.latin: Locutusque est Dominus ad Moysen et Aaron, dicens:
verses.english: The Lord spoke to Moses and Aaron, saying:

verses.latin: Cum dixerit vobis Pharao: Ostendite signa: dices ad Aaron: Tolle virgam tuam, et projice coram Pharaone, et vertetur in draconem.
verses.english: "When Pharaoh says to you, 'Show a sign,' you will say to Aaron, 'Take your staff and throw it down before Pharaoh, and it will turn into a serpent.'"

verses.latin: Igitur introierunt Moyses et Aaron ad Pharaonem: et fecerunt sicut præceperat Dominus. Projecitque Aaron virgam coram Pharaone et servis ejus, quæ versa est in draconem.
verses.english: So Moses and Aaron went to Pharaoh and did as the Lord had commanded. Aaron threw down his staff before Pharaoh and his servants, and it turned into a serpent.

verses.latin: Vocavit autem Pharao sapientes et maleficos: et fecerunt etiam ipsi Ægyptii per incantationes suas et arcana, similiter.
verses.english: But Pharaoh called for his wise men and his sorcerers. And the Egyptian magicians also did the same thing with their enchantments and secret arts.

verses.latin: Projeceruntque singuli virgas suas, quæ versæ sunt in dracones: et devoravit virga Aaron virgas eorum.
verses.english: For each of them threw down his staff, and they also turned into serpents. But Aaron's staff swallowed up their staffs.

verses.latin: Et induratum est cor Pharaonis, nec audivit eos, sicut Dominus dixerat.
verses.english: And Pharaoh's heart grew stubborn, and he would not listen to them, just as the Lord had said.

verses.latin: Dixitque Dominus ad Moysen: Ingravatum est cor Pharaonis, noluit dimittere populum.
verses.english: Then the Lord said to Moses, "Pharaoh's heart is hardened; he refuses to let the people go."

verses.latin: Vade ad Pharaonem mane: ecce egredietur ad aquas: et stabis in occursum ejus super ripam fluminis: et virgam quæ versa est in draconem, tolles in manu tua.
verses.english: "Go to Pharaoh in the morning. He will be going out to the waters—to the Nile River—and you will stand to meet him on the riverbank. Take in your hand the staff that was turned into a serpent."

verses.latin: Et dices ad eum: Dominus Deus Hebræorum misit me ad te, dicens: Dimitte populum meum, ut sacrificet mihi in deserto: et usque ad præsens audire noluisti.
verses.english: "And you will say to him, 'The Lord, the God of the Hebrews, has sent me to you, saying: "Let My people go, so that they may sacrifice to Me in the desert." But up until now, you have refused to listen.'"

verses.latin: Hæc igitur dicit Dominus: In hoc scies quia ego sum Dominus: ecce percutiam virga, quæ est in manu mea, aquam fluminis, et vertetur in sanguinem.
verses.english: "Therefore, this is what the Lord says: 'By this, you will know that I am the Lord. Behold, I will strike the water of the river with the staff that is in My hand, and it will turn into blood.'"

verses.latin: Et pisces, qui sunt in fluvio, morientur, et computrescent aquæ, et fœtor erit in Ægypto, nec poterunt bibere aquam fluminis.
verses.english: "And the fish in the river will die, and the water will become foul and rot, and there will be a stench throughout Egypt. The Egyptians will not be able to drink the water from the river."

verses.latin: Dixit quoque Dominus ad Moysen: Dic ad Aaron: Tolle virgam tuam, et extende manum tuam super aquas Ægypti, et super flumina eorum, et super rivos, ac paludes, et omnes lacus aquarum, ut vertantur in sanguinem: et sit sanguis in omni terra Ægypti, tam in ligneis vasis quam in saxeis.
verses.english: The Lord also said to Moses, "Say to Aaron, 'Take your staff and stretch out your hand over the waters of Egypt—over their rivers, over their canals, over their marshes, and over all their pools of water—so that they may turn into blood. Let there be blood throughout all the land of Egypt, both in wooden vessels and in stone vessels.'"

verses.latin: Feceruntque Moyses et Aaron sicut præceperat Dominus: et elevans Aaron virgam, percussit aquas fluminis coram Pharaone et servis ejus: versæque sunt omnes aquæ fluminis in sanguinem.
verses.english: So Moses and Aaron did just as the Lord had commanded. Aaron lifted up his staff and struck the waters of the river before Pharaoh and his servants, and all the waters of the river turned into blood.

verses.latin: Et pisces, qui erant in fluvio, mortui sunt: et putruerunt aquæ, et non poterant Ægyptii bibere aquam fluminis, et fuit sanguis in tota terra Ægypti.
verses.english: And the fish that were in the river died, and the water became foul, and the Egyptians could not drink the water from the river. There was blood throughout all the land of Egypt.

verses.latin: Feceruntque similiter malefici Ægyptiorum incantationibus suis: et induratum est cor Pharaonis, nec audivit eos, sicut dixerat Dominus.
verses.english: And the magicians of Egypt did the same thing with their enchantments. So Pharaoh's heart grew stubborn again, and he would not listen to them, just as the Lord had said.

verses.latin: Et avertit se, et ingressus est domum suam, nec apposuit cor suum etiam hac vice.
verses.english: And Pharaoh turned away and went into his house, and he did not even take this to heart this time.

verses.latin: Foderunt autem omnes Ægyptii per circuitum fluminis puteos, ut haberent aquam ad bibendum: non enim poterant bibere de aqua fluminis.
verses.english: But all the Egyptians dug wells around the river to get water to drink, for they could not drink the water from the river.

verses.latin: Impletique sunt septem dies, ex quo percussit Dominus fluvium.
verses.english: And seven days passed after the Lord struck the river.

verses.latin: Dixitque Dominus ad Moysen: Ingredere ad Pharaonem, et loquere ad eum: Hæc dicit Dominus: Dimitte populum meum, ut sacrificet mihi.
verses.english: The Lord said to Moses, "Go to Pharaoh and tell him, 'This is what the Lord says: Let My people go, so that they may sacrifice to Me.'"

verses.latin: Quod si nolueris dimittere, ecce ego percutiam omnes fines tuos ranis:
verses.english: "But if you refuse to let them go, behold, I will strike all your territory with frogs."

verses.latin: et ebulliet fluvius ranas, quæ ascendent et ingredientur domum tuam, et cubiculum lecti tui, et super stratum tuum, et in domos servorum tuorum et populi tui, et in fornaces tuas, et in reliquias ciborum tuorum:
verses.english: "And the river will swarm with frogs, which will come up and enter your house, your bedroom, and your bed, and the houses of your servants and your people, and into your ovens and your kneading bowls."

verses.latin: et ad te, et ad populum tuum, et ad omnes servos tuos, intrabunt ranæ.
verses.english: "And the frogs will come up on you, and on your people, and on all your servants."

verses.latin: Et dixit Dominus ad Moysen: Dic ad Aaron: Extende manum tuam super flumina, et super rivos, et super paludes, et educ ranas super terram Ægypti.
verses.english: Then the Lord said to Moses, "Tell Aaron, 'Stretch out your hand with your staff over the rivers, over the canals, and over the marshes, and bring up frogs upon the land of Egypt.'"

verses.latin: Extenditque Aaron manum super aquas Ægypti: et egressæ sunt ranæ, et operuerunt omnem terram Ægypti.
verses.english: So Aaron stretched out his hand over the waters of Egypt, and the frogs came out and covered all the land of Egypt.

verses.latin: Feceruntque similiter malefici incantationibus suis, et eduxerunt ranas super terram Ægypti.
verses.english: And the magicians did the same thing with their enchantments and brought up frogs upon the land of Egypt.

verses.latin: Vocavitque Pharao Moysen et Aaron, et dixit: Orate Dominum ut auferat ranas a me, et a populo meo: dimittamque populum ut sacrificet Domino.
verses.english: Pharaoh then called Moses and Aaron and said, "Pray to the Lord that He may remove the frogs from me and from my people. Then I will let the people go to sacrifice to the Lord."

verses.latin: Et ait Moyses ad Pharaonem: Constitue mihi quando exorem pro te, et pro servis tuis, et pro populo tuo, ut abigantur ranæ a te, et a domibus tuis, et tantum in fluvio permaneant.
verses.english: Moses said to Pharaoh, "Set a time for me, when I should pray for you, and for your servants, and for your people, so that the frogs may be driven away from you and from your houses and remain only in the river."

verses.latin: Qui respondit: Cras. Et ait: Juxta verbum tuum faciam, ut scias quia non est alter sicut Dominus Deus noster.
verses.english: Pharaoh answered, "Tomorrow." And Moses said, "It will be as you say, so that you may know that there is no one else like the Lord our God."

verses.latin: Et recedent ranæ a te, et a domibus tuis, et a servis tuis, et a populo tuo: tantum in flumine tantum remanebunt.
verses.english: "And the frogs will withdraw from you, and from your houses, and from your servants, and from your people. They will remain only in the river."

verses.latin: Egressique sunt Moyses et Aaron a Pharaone: et clamavit Moyses ad Dominum pro sponsione ranarum, quas statuerat Pharaoni.
verses.english: Then Moses and Aaron went out from Pharaoh, and Moses cried out to the Lord concerning the frogs, according to the promise he had made to Pharaoh.

verses.latin: Fecitque Dominus juxta verbum Moysi: et mortuæ sunt ranæ de domibus, et de vicis, et de agris.
verses.english: And the Lord did according to the word of Moses, and the frogs died in the houses, in the villages, and in the fields.

verses.latin: Et congregaverunt eas in multitudines immensas, et computruit terra.
verses.english: And they gathered them together in immense heaps, and the land became foul with their stench.

verses.latin: Videns autem Pharao quod data esset quies, ingravavit cor suum, et non audivit eos, sicut dixerat Dominus.
verses.english: But when Pharaoh saw that there was a respite, his heart grew stubborn, and he did not listen to them, just as the Lord had said.

verses.latin: Dixit quoque Dominus ad Moysen: Ingredere ad Pharaonem et dices ad eum: Hæc dicit Dominus: Dimitte populum meum ut sacrificet mihi.
verses.english: The Lord then gave Moses another command: "Go to Pharaoh and say to him, 'This is what the Lord declares: Let My people go so they can offer sacrifices to Me.'"

verses.latin: Quod si nolueris dimittere, ecce ego percutiam omnes fines tuos ranis.
verses.english: "But if you refuse to let them go, understand that I will strike all your territories with a plague of frogs."

verses.latin: Et ebulliet fluvius ranarum: quæ ascendentes ingredientur domum tuam, et cubiculum lectuli tui, et super stratum tuum, et in domos servorum tuorum et populi tui, et in fornaces tuas, et in reliquias ciborum tuorum:
verses.english: The Nile River will swarm with frogs, and they will crawl out and enter your palace, your bedroom, and even your bed. They will invade the homes of your officials and your people, and get into your ovens and your kneading bowls where you prepare food.

verses.latin: et ad te, et ad populum tuum, et ad omnes servos tuos, ranæ consurgent.
verses.english: The frogs will cover you, your people, and all your servants everywhere.

verses.latin: Et dixit Dominus ad Moysen: Dic Aaroni: Extende manum tuam super flumina, et super rivos, et super paludes, et educ ranas super terram Aegypti.
verses.english: The Lord then told Moses, "Command Aaron: 'Stretch out your hand over the rivers, canals, and ponds, and bring forth the frogs upon the land of Egypt.'"

verses.latin: Extenditque Aaron manum super aquas Aegypti, et ascenderunt ranæ, et operuerunt terram Aegypti.
verses.english: Aaron stretched his hand over the waters of Egypt, and the frogs emerged, covering the entire land of Egypt.

verses.latin: Fecerunt autem similiter et arioli in incantationibus suis, et eduxerunt ranas super terram Aegypti.
verses.english: The Egyptian magicians, using their secret arts, also attempted to do the same and managed to bring forth frogs upon the land of Egypt through their dark magic.

verses.latin: Vocavitque Pharao Moysen et Aaron, et dixit: Orate Dominum ut auferat ranas a me et a populo meo, et dimittam populum ut sacrificet Domino.
verses.english: Pharaoh called for Moses and Aaron and pleaded with them: "Pray to the Lord to remove these frogs from me and my people, and I will let your people go to offer sacrifices to the Lord."

verses.latin: Et ait Moyses ad Pharaonem: Constitue mihi quando exorem pro te, et pro servis tuis, et pro populo tuo, ut abigantur ranæ a te et a domibus tuis, et tantum in fluvio remaneant.
verses.english: Moses said to Pharaoh, "You name the time when I should pray for you, your servants, and your people, that the frogs may be removed from you and your homes, remaining only in the Nile River."

verses.latin: Qui respondit: Cras. Et ille ait: Juxta verbum tuum, ut scias quia non est alter sicut Dominus Deus noster:
verses.english: Pharaoh replied, "Tomorrow." Moses then responded, "It will be according to your word, so you may know that there is no other God like the Lord our God."

verses.latin: et auferentur ranæ a te, et a domibus tuis, et a servis tuis, et a populo tuo: tantum in fluvio solo remanebunt.
verses.english: "The frogs will be removed from you, your homes, your servants, and your people; they will remain only in the Nile River itself."

verses.latin: Egressique Moyses et Aaron a Pharaone, clamavit Moyses ad Dominum pro sponsione ranarum quam constituerat Pharao.
verses.english: After Moses and Aaron left Pharaoh, Moses cried out to the Lord concerning the plague of frogs that Pharaoh had agreed to have removed.

verses.latin: Fecitque Dominus juxta verbum Moysi: et mortuæ sunt ranæ de domibus, et de vicis, et de agris.
verses.english: The Lord acted according to Moses' request: the frogs died in the houses, in the villages, and in the fields—everywhere they had been.

verses.latin: Congregaveruntque eas per acervos infinitos: et foetuit terra.
verses.english: The Egyptians gathered them into enormous piles, and the land became foul with the stench of decaying frogs.

verses.latin: Videns autem Pharao quod data esset requies, ingravavit cor suum, et non audivit eos, sicut locutus fuerat Dominus.
verses.english: But when Pharaoh saw that there was relief from the plague, he hardened his heart once again and refused to listen to Moses and Aaron, just as the Lord had foretold.

verses.latin: Dixitque Dominus ad Moysen: Dic Aaroni: Extende baculum tuum, et percute pulverem terræ: et sint sciniphes in universa terra Aegypti.
verses.english: Then the Lord said to Moses, "Command Aaron: 'Stretch out your staff and strike the dust of the ground, and it will become gnats throughout the entire land of Egypt.'"

verses.latin: Feceruntque ita: et extendit Aaron manum, tenens virgam: percussitque pulverem terræ, et facti sunt sciniphes in hominibus et in jumentis: omnis pulvis terræ versus est in sciniphes per totam terram Aegypti.
verses.english: They did as commanded. Aaron stretched out his hand, holding his staff, and struck the dust of the ground. Gnats then appeared on people and animals; all the dust of the ground was transformed into gnats throughout the whole land of Egypt.

verses.latin: Conati suntque similiter arioli in incantationibus suis, ut educerent sciniphes, et non potuerunt: erantque sciniphes tam in hominibus quam in jumentis.
verses.english: The magicians also tried to produce gnats using their secret spells, but they could not. The gnats continued to infest both people and animals.

verses.latin: Et dixerunt arioli ad Pharaonem: Digitus Dei est hic. Ingravatumque est cor Pharaonis, et non audivit eos, sicut locutus fuerat Dominus.
verses.english: The magicians finally confessed to Pharaoh, "This is the very finger of God at work here." Yet Pharaoh's heart remained stubborn, and he refused to listen to them, just as the Lord had foretold.

verses.latin: Dixit quoque Dominus ad Moysen: Consurge diluculo, et sta coram Pharaone: ecce enim egredietur ad aquas: et dices ad eum: Hæc dicit Dominus: Dimitte populum meum ut sacrificet mihi.
verses.english: The Lord then told Moses, "Rise early in the morning and stand before Pharaoh as he goes out to the water—which he often did for religious rituals. Say to him: 'This is what the Lord declares: Let My people go so they can offer sacrifices to Me.'"

verses.latin: Quod si non dimiseris populum meum, ecce ego immittam in te, et in servos tuos, et in populum tuum, et in domos tuas omne genus muscarum: et implebuntur domus Aegyptiorum omne muscarum genere, et universa terra in qua fuerint.
verses.english: "But if you do not let My people go, then I will send swarms of various kinds of flies upon you, your officials, your people, and into your houses. The homes of the Egyptians will be filled with these swarms of flies, and the very ground where they stand will be covered with them."

verses.latin: Et mirabilem faciam in die illa terram Gessen, in qua est populus meus, ut non sint ibi muscæ: et scias quoniam ego Dominus in medio terræ sum.
verses.english: "But on that day, I will set apart the land of Goshen, where My people reside, so that no swarms of flies will be found there. This way you will know that I, the Lord, am present in the midst of this land."

verses.latin: Et ponam divisionem inter populum meum et populum tuum: cras erit signum istud.
verses.english: "I will make a clear distinction between My people and your people. This sign will happen tomorrow."

verses.latin: Fecitque Dominus ita: et venit musca gravissima in domos Pharaonis et servorum ejus, et in omnem terram Aegypti: corruptaque est terra ab hujuscemodi muscis.
verses.english: The Lord did exactly as He said: immense swarms of flies invaded Pharaoh's palace and his officials' homes, and the entire land of Egypt. The land was devastated by these swarms of flies.

verses.latin: Vocavitque Pharao Moysen et Aaron, et dixit eis: Ite, sacrificate Deo vestro in terra hac.
verses.english: Pharaoh then called for Moses and Aaron and said to them, "Go, and offer sacrifices to your God here within this land of Egypt."

verses.latin: Et ait Moyses: Non potest ita fieri: abominatio est enim Aegyptiis ut immolemus Dominum Deum nostrum: si enim immolaverimus quæ colunt Aegyptii, occident nos.
verses.english: Moses replied, "That cannot be done, because the sacrifices we offer to the Lord our God are an abomination to the Egyptians—they consider our sacred animals as idols. If we were to openly sacrifice what the Egyptians worship, they would surely stone us to death."

verses.latin: Tribus dierum itinere proficiscemur in solitudinem, et sacrificabimus Domino Deo nostro, sicut præcepit nobis.
verses.english: "We must travel three days into the wilderness and offer sacrifices to the Lord our God there, as He has commanded us to do."

verses.latin: Dixitque Pharao: Ego dimittam vos ut sacrificetis Domino Deo vestro in solitudine: verumtamen non longe recedatis: orate pro me.
verses.english: Pharaoh then said, "I will indeed let you go to offer sacrifices to the Lord your God in the wilderness, but you must not go too far. And be sure to pray for me."

verses.latin: Et ait Moyses: Ecce ego egredior a te, et orabo Dominum: et auferetur musca a Pharaone, et a servis, et a populo ejus cras: verumtamen ultra ne addas fallere, ut non dimittas populum ad sacrificandum Domino.
verses.english: Moses answered, "Look, I am leaving your presence now, and I will pray to the Lord that the swarms of flies may be removed from Pharaoh, his officials, and his people tomorrow. But let Pharaoh not deceive us again by refusing to let the people go to offer sacrifices to the Lord."

verses.latin: Egressusque Moyses a Pharaone, oravit Dominum.
verses.english: So Moses left Pharaoh's presence and prayed to the Lord.

verses.latin: Fecitque Dominus juxta sermonem ejus, et abstulit muscas a Pharaone, et a servis et a populo ejus: non superfuit ne una quidem.
verses.english: The Lord acted according to Moses' word and removed the swarms of flies from Pharaoh, his officials, and his people. Not a single fly remained.

verses.latin: Et induratum est cor Pharaonis in hac quoque vice, nec dimisit populum.
verses.english: But even on this occasion, Pharaoh hardened his heart and still refused to let the people go.

verses.latin: Ingressus itaque Moyses ad Pharaonem, dixit ad eum: Haec dicit Dominus Deus Hebraeorum: Dimitte populum meum, ut sacrificet mihi.
verses.english: So Moses went in to Pharaoh and spoke to him, saying, "This is what the Lord, the God of the Hebrew people, declares: Let My people go, so they can offer Me proper public worship."

verses.latin: Quod si nolueris dimittere, et adhuc detinueris, ecce manus mea erit super possessionem tuam, campos, equos, et asinos, et camelos, et boves, et oves, pestis valde gravis.
verses.english: But if you refuse to let them go, and you continue to detain them, then behold, My power will be against all your possessions: your fields, your horses, your donkeys, your camels, your cattle, and your sheep. A very severe plague of disease will strike them.

verses.latin: Et faciet Dominus mirabile inter possessiones Israël, et possessiones Ægyptiorum, ut nihil omnino pereat ex his quæ pertinent ad filios Israël.
verses.english: And the Lord will show a powerful distinction between the livestock of Israel and the livestock of the Egyptians. Nothing belonging to the children of Israel will die from this disease.

verses.latin: Constituitque Dominus tempus, dicens: Cras faciet Dominus verbum istud in terra.
verses.english: The Lord set a specific time, saying, "Tomorrow the Lord will bring about this event in the land."

verses.latin: Fecit ergo Dominus verbum hoc altera die, mortuaque sunt omnia animantia Ægyptiorum: de possessione autem filiorum Israël, nihil perüt.
verses.english: So the Lord did this the next day. All the animals belonging to the Egyptians died from the disease, but of the livestock of the children of Israel, not a single one died.

verses.latin: Et misit Pharao ad videndum: nec erat quidquam mortuum de his quæ possidebat Israël. Ingravatumque est cor Pharaonis, et non dimisit populum.
verses.english: Pharaoh sent servants to investigate, and indeed, not one of the animals belonging to Israel had died. But Pharaoh's heart became even more hardened, and he did not let the people go.

verses.latin: Et dixit Dominus ad Moysen et Aaron: Sumite plenas manus cineris de camino, et spargat illum Moyses in cælum coram Pharaone.
verses.english: Then the Lord said to Moses and Aaron, "Take handfuls of ash from a furnace, and let Moses throw it toward the sky in the sight of Pharaoh."

verses.latin: Sitque pulvis super omnem terram Ægypti: erunt enim in hominibus et jumentis ulcera et vesicæ turgentes in universa terra Ægypti.
verses.english: And it will become fine dust over all the land of Egypt. It will turn into festering boils breaking out on people and animals throughout the entire land of Egypt.

verses.latin: Tuleruntque cinerem de camino, et steterunt coram Pharaone: et sparsit illum Moyses in cælum: factaque sunt ulcera vesicarum turgentium in hominibus et jumentis.
verses.english: So they took ash from a furnace and stood before Pharaoh. Moses threw it toward the sky, and festering boils broke out on people and animals.

verses.latin: Nec poterant Magi stare coram Moyse propter ulcera quæ ortæ fuerant: in illis quippe et in omni terra Ægypti.
verses.english: The magicians, who used occult practices, could not even stand before Moses because of the boils that had broken out on them. The boils were on them and on all the people of Egypt.

verses.latin: Ingravavitque Dominus cor Pharaonis, et non audivit eos, sicut locutus est Dominus ad Moysen.
verses.english: And the Lord hardened Pharaoh's heart, so he did not listen to them, just as the Lord had told Moses would happen.

verses.latin: Dixitque Dominus ad Moysen: Mane consurge, et sta coram Pharaone, et dices ad eum: Hæc dicit Dominus Deus Hebræorum: Dimitte populum meum, ut sacrificet mihi.
verses.english: Then the Lord said to Moses, "Rise early in the morning, and stand before Pharaoh, and say to him: 'This is what the Lord, the God of the Hebrew people, says: Let My people go, so they can offer Me proper public worship.'

verses.latin: Quia in hac vice omnes plagas meas mittam super cor tuum, et super servos tuos, et super populum tuum: ut scias, quod non sit similis mei in omni terra.
verses.english: For at this time I will send all My plagues against your heart, and against your servants, and against your people, so that you may know there is no one like Me in all the earth.

verses.latin: Nunc enim extendi manum meam, et percussi te, et populum tuum peste, perissesque de terra.
verses.english: For if I had by now stretched out My hand and struck you and your people with the plague that killed the livestock, you would have been wiped off the earth completely.

verses.latin: Idcirco autem te sustentavi, ut ostendam in te fortitudinem meam, et narretur nomen meum in omni terra.
verses.english: But it is for this reason that I have preserved you and kept you alive—so that I may display My power in you, and that My Name may be proclaimed throughout all the earth.

verses.latin: Adhuc retines populum meum: et non vis dimittere.
verses.english: You are still holding My people captive, and you refuse to let them go.

verses.latin: Ecce ego pluam cras hac hora grandinem multam nimis, qualis non fuit in Ægypto a die qua fundata est, usque in præsens tempus.
verses.english: Listen: tomorrow, about this time, I will cause a very heavy hailstorm to fall, such as has never occurred in Egypt from the day it was founded until now.

verses.latin: Nunc ergo mitte, et congrega jumenta tua, et omnia quæ habes in agro: homines enim, et jumenta quæ inventa fuerint foris, nec intra tecta congregata, irruet super ea grando, et morientur.
verses.english: Therefore, send word now and gather your livestock and everything you have in the open fields. For every person and animal that is found outside and not brought under shelter will be struck by the hail, and they will die.

verses.latin: Qui timuerunt verbum Domini de servis Pharaonis, fecerunt fugere servos suos et jumenta in domos:
verses.english: Those among Pharaoh's servants who feared the word of the Lord quickly brought their own servants and their livestock into their homes for shelter.

verses.latin: qui autem neglexerunt sermonem Domini, dimiserunt servos et jumenta in campis.
verses.english: But those who disregarded the word of the Lord left their servants and their livestock out in the fields.

verses.latin: Dixit autem Dominus ad Moysen: Extende manum tuam in cælum, ut fiat grando in universa terra Ægypti, super homines, et super jumenta, et super omnem herbam agrorum in terra Ægypti.
verses.english: Then the Lord said to Moses, "Stretch out your hand toward the sky, so that hail may fall throughout all the land of Egypt, upon people, upon animals, and upon every plant in the fields across the land of Egypt."

verses.latin: Et extendit Moyses virgam in cælum: et Dominus dedit tonitrua, et grandinem, ac fulgura per terram: misitque Dominus pluviam super terram Ægypti.
verses.english: So Moses stretched out his staff toward the sky, and the Lord sent thunder, and hail, and lightning flashed across the land. The Lord caused rain to fall heavily upon the land of Egypt.

verses.latin: Et grando, et ignis simul mixta inter grandines ferebatur: ac tam magna fuit, qualis nunquam apparuit in tota terra Ægypti, ex quo gens illa condita est.
verses.english: There was hail, and fire was mingled with the hail. This hailstorm was so immense and destructive that nothing like it had ever appeared in all the land of Egypt since that nation was founded.

verses.latin: Et percussit grando in omni terra Ægypti cuncta quæ fuerunt in campis, ab homine usque ad jumentum: cunctamque herbam regionis percussit grando, et omne lignum regionum confregit.
verses.english: The hail struck down everything that was in the open fields throughout the entire land of Egypt, from people to animals. The hail also destroyed every plant in the region and shattered every tree in the fields.

verses.latin: Tantum in terra Gessen, ubi erant filii Israël, grando non cecidit.
verses.english: Only in the land of Goshen, where the children of Israel were living, did the hail not fall.

verses.latin: Misitque Pharao, et vocavit Moysen et Aaron, dicens ad eos: Peccavi in hac vice: Dominus justus est, ego et populus meus impii.
verses.english: Pharaoh sent for Moses and Aaron, saying to them, "I have sinned this time. The Lord is righteous and just, and I and my people are wicked."

verses.latin: Orate Dominum, ut auferat tonitrua Dei, et grandinem: et dimittam vos, ultra non manebitis.
verses.english: Pray to the Lord, that He may stop these powerful thunders and this hail. I will let you go; you will not remain here any longer."

verses.latin: Dixitque Moyses: Cum egressus fuero de urbe, extendam manus meas ad Dominum: et cessabunt tonitrua, et grando non erit ultra: ut scias quia Domini est terra.
verses.english: Moses replied, "As soon as I leave the city, I will stretch out my hands in prayer to the Lord. The thunder will cease, and there will be no more hail, so that you may know that the earth belongs to the Lord."

verses.latin: Novimus autem quod et tu et servi tui necdum timeatis Dominum Deum.
verses.english: However, we know that neither you nor your servants truly fear the Lord God yet.

verses.latin: Grando igitur et fulgura permanserunt, eo quod segetes hordei et lini jam maturescerent: linum quippe jam germinaverat, et hordeum spicas fecerat.
verses.english: Thus, the hail and the lightning continued. This was because the barley and the flax crops were already in their growing season—the flax was in bloom, and the barley had already formed its heads.

verses.latin: Triticum autem et far, serotinum erat: et idcirco non perierat.
verses.english: But the wheat and the spelt were planted later in the season, and therefore they were not destroyed by the hail.

verses.latin: Egressusque Moyses a Pharaone de urbe, extendit manus suas ad Dominum: et cessaverunt tonitrua et grando, et pluvia nec ultra effusa est super terram.
verses.english: When Moses left Pharaoh's presence and went out of the city, he stretched out his hands in prayer to the Lord. The thunder and hail ceased, and the heavy rain no longer poured down upon the earth.

verses.latin: Vidensque Pharao quod cessasset pluvia, et grando, et tonitrua, ingravavit sibi cor: et induravit animum suum, et ipse, et servi ejus.
verses.english: But when Pharaoh saw that the rain, hail, and thunder had stopped, his heart became hardened once more. Both he and his servants became stubborn and unyielding.

verses.latin: Et non dimisit filios Israël, sicut locutus fuerat Dominus per manum Moysi.
verses.english: So Pharaoh did not let the children of Israel go, just as the Lord had declared through Moses.

verses.latin: Dixit autem Dominus ad Moysen: Ingredere ad Pharaonem: ego enim induravi cor ejus, et servorum ejus, ut ostendam signa mea hæc in eo:
verses.english: The Lord then spoke to Moses: 'Go in to Pharaoh, for I have made his heart and the hearts of his servants stubborn, so that I may perform these miraculous signs of Mine among them.'

verses.latin: et narres in auribus filiorum tuorum, et nepotum tuorum, quoties percuterim Aegyptios, et signa mea quæ fecerim in eis: et sciatis quia ego Dominus.
verses.english: and so that you may recount in the hearing of your sons and your grandsons how many times I have struck the Egyptians, and the miraculous signs that I have performed among them; and so that you may know that I am the Lord.'

verses.latin: Itaque ingressi sunt Moyses et Aaron ad Pharaonem, dixeruntque ei: Hæc dicit Dominus Deus Hebræorum: Usquequo non vis subjici mihi? dimitte populum meum ut sacrificet mihi.
verses.english: Therefore, Moses and Aaron went in to Pharaoh and said to him: 'Thus says the Lord, the God of the Hebrews: "How long will you refuse to submit to Me? Let My people go, so that they may offer sacrifice to Me."'

verses.latin: Quod si adhuc resistis, et non vis dimittere eos: ecce ego inducam cras locustam in fines tuos:
verses.english: 'But if you still refuse to submit and will not let them go, behold, tomorrow I will bring the locust into your lands.'

verses.latin: quæ operiat superficiem terræ, nec quicquam ejus appareat, sed comedat quæ residua fuerint grandini: quicquid arboris reliquum est:
verses.english: 'These locusts will cover the surface of your land, so that nothing of it can be seen; and they will devour whatever remained after the hail, and whatever is left of your trees.'

verses.latin: implebuntque domos tuas, et omnium servorum tuorum, et universorum Aegyptiorum: tale quid non viderunt patres vestri, et avi vestri, ex quo nati sunt super terram usque in præsentem diem. Et aversus est, egressusque de Pharaone.
verses.english: 'They will fill your houses, and the houses of all your servants, and of all the Egyptians. Such a plague has never been seen by your fathers or your grandfathers, from the day they were born upon the earth until this very day.' And then Moses turned and left Pharaoh's presence.

verses.latin: Dixerunt autem servi Pharaonis ad eum: Usquequo patiemur hoc scandalum? dimitte homines ut sacrificent Domino Deo suo: an ignoras quod perierit Aegyptus?
verses.english: Pharaoh's servants then said to him: 'How long will we endure this scandal? Let the men go, so that they may offer sacrifice to the Lord their God. Do you not realize that Egypt is utterly ruined?'

verses.latin: Revocaveruntque Moysen et Aaron ad Pharaonem: et ille dixit eis: Ite, sacrificato Domino Deo vestro: qui et qui sunt qui ituri sunt?
verses.english: So Moses and Aaron were called back to Pharaoh, and he said to them: 'Go, offer sacrifice to the Lord your God. But tell me, who exactly are those who will go?'

verses.latin: Cui Moyses: Cum parvulis inquit nostris, et cum senioribus pergemus, cum filiis et filiabus, cum ovibus et armentis cunctis: est enim solemnitas Domini Dei nostri.
