verses.english: To him Moses replied: 'We will go with our young children and our elders, with our sons and our daughters, with all our sheep and our cattle; for it is a solemn feast of the Lord our God.'

verses.latin: Qui respondens ait: Sic sit Dominus vobiscum, quo modo ego dimittam vos, et parvulos vestros? videte periculum in proximo est.
verses.english: Pharaoh replied: 'May the Lord be with you! As for me, in what way would I ever let you go, you and your little ones? Beware, for danger is imminent!'

verses.latin: Non sic, sed tantum viri ite, et sacrificate Domino: sic enim et ipsi petistis. Et ejecerunt eos de conspectu Pharaonis.
verses.english: 'Not so! Only the men among you are to go and offer sacrifice to the Lord, for that is what you yourselves requested.' And Pharaoh's guards then drove them out from his presence.

verses.latin: Dixit autem Dominus ad Moysen: Extende manum tuam super terram Aegypti, et ascendat locusta super eam, et comedat omne fœnum terræ, quicquid residuum fuerit grandini.
verses.english: The Lord then said to Moses: 'Stretch out your hand over the land of Egypt, and let the locusts come up upon it and devour all the vegetation of the land, whatever remained after the hail.'

verses.latin: Extendit ergo Moyses virgam super terram Aegypti: et Dominus induxit ventum urentem de affrica tota die et nocte: et mane facto ventus urens levavit locustam:
verses.english: So Moses stretched out his staff over the land of Egypt; and the Lord brought a scorching wind from the south throughout that entire day and night. And when morning came, the scorching wind carried the locusts.

verses.latin: Quæ operuit universam superficiem Aegypti, et sedit in cunctis finibus Ægyptiorum innumerabilis, qualis ante illud tempus non fuerat, nec futura est.
verses.english: The locusts covered the entire surface of Egypt, settling in all the regions of the Egyptians in such countless numbers that there had never been such a plague before that time, nor will there ever be one like it again.

verses.latin: Comederunt igitur omne fœnum terræ, et quicquid pomorum in arboribus fuit, atque ligni: nec remansit omnino viride in cuncta Aegypto, nec in arboribus, nec in herbis terræ.
verses.english: Therefore, they devoured all the vegetation of the land, and whatever fruit was on the trees, and even the bark of the trees. Nothing green at all remained in all of Egypt, neither on the trees nor in the plants of the land.

verses.latin: Quam ob rem festinato Pharao vocavit Moysen et Aaron, et dixit: Peccavi Domino Deo vestro, et vobis.
verses.english: For this reason, Pharaoh quickly sent for Moses and Aaron, and he said: 'I have sinned against the Lord your God, and against you.'

verses.latin: Nunc ergo auferte, quæso, pariter hoc scelus a me, et rogate Dominum Deum vestrum, ut auferat a me mortem hanc saltem.
verses.english: 'Now therefore, I beg you, forgive this wickedness of mine, and pray to the Lord your God, that He may at least take away this deadly plague from me.'

verses.latin: Egressusque de conspectu Pharaonis, oravit Dominum.
verses.english: So Moses left Pharaoh's presence and prayed to the Lord.

verses.latin: Qui statim misit ventum vehementissimum ab occidente, et rapuit locustas, et projecit in Mare Rubrum: non superfuit ne una quidem in cunctis finibus Aegypti.
verses.english: And immediately the Lord sent a very strong west wind, which caught up the locusts and cast them into the Red Sea. Not even one locust remained in all the regions of Egypt.

verses.latin: Et induravit Dominus cor Pharaonis, nec dimisit filios Israel.
verses.english: But the Lord hardened Pharaoh's heart, and he refused to let the children of Israel go.

verses.latin: Dixit autem Dominus ad Moysen: Extende manum tuam in cælum, ut sint tenebræ super terram Aegypti tam densæ ut palpari queant.
verses.english: The Lord then said to Moses: 'Stretch out your hand toward the sky, so that there may be a darkness over the land of Egypt so dense that it can be felt.'

verses.latin: Extendit Moyses manum in cælum: et factæ sunt tenebræ horribiles in universa terra Aegypti tribus diebus.
verses.english: Moses stretched out his hand toward the sky, and a horrible darkness covered all the land of Egypt for three days.

verses.latin: Non vidit homo fratrem suum, nec movit se de loco in quo erat tribus diebus: ubi vero erant filii Israel, lux lucebat.
verses.english: No one could see his brother, nor did anyone move from the place where he was for three days. However, where the children of Israel were, there was light.

verses.latin: Vocavitque Pharao Moysen, et dixit: Ite, sacrificate Domino: tantum oves vestræ, et armenta maneant, parvuli vestri eant vobiscum.
verses.english: Pharaoh then called Moses and said: 'Go, offer sacrifice to the Lord. Only your sheep and your cattle must remain behind; your young children may go with you.'

verses.latin: Ait Moyses: Sed et tu dabis nobis holocausta, et victimas, quæ offeramus Domino Deo nostro.
verses.english: Moses replied: 'No, you must also provide us with burnt offerings and sacrificial animals, which we may offer to the Lord our God.'

verses.latin: Omnia pecora nostra nobiscum auferemus: non remanebit ex eis ungula: necesse est enim de illis sumere ad cultum Domini Dei nostri, nec scimus quid placiturum sit, donec ad ipsum locum perveniamus.
verses.english: 'We will take all our livestock with us; not a single hoof will remain. For it is necessary for us to take from them for the worship of the Lord our God, and we do not know exactly what will be pleasing to Him until we arrive at the appointed place.'

verses.latin: Dominus autem induravit cor Pharaonis, et noluit dimittere eos.
verses.english: But the Lord hardened Pharaoh's heart, and he refused to let them go.

verses.latin: Dixitque Pharao Moysi: Recede a me, vide ne ultra faciem meam quæras: in quacumque die apparueris mihi, morieris.
verses.english: Pharaoh then said to Moses: 'Get away from me! See to it that you never again seek my presence. On whatever day you appear before me again, you will surely die!'

verses.latin: Cui respondit Moyses: Sicut locutus es, non videbo ultra faciem tuam.
verses.english: To him Moses replied: 'As you have spoken, I will not see your face again.'

verses.latin: Dixit autem Dominus ad Moysen: Adhuc una plaga mittenda est a me super Pharaonem et Aegyptum, et post hæc dimittet vos. Et cum dimiserit, statim expellit.
verses.english: The Lord then spoke to Moses, saying: 'There is one more plague I will send upon Pharaoh and Egypt. After this, Pharaoh will surely let you go. And when he finally lets you go, he will utterly drive you out of Egypt without delay.'

verses.latin: Loquere ergo ad omnem populum, ut postulet vir a socio suo, et mulier a vicina sua, vasa argentea et aurea.
verses.english: Therefore, speak to all the people of Israel, so that every man asks his Egyptian neighbor, and every woman asks her Egyptian female neighbor, for articles of silver and gold.

verses.latin: Dabit enim Dominus gratiam populo suo coram Aegyptiis: et Moyses erat vir grandis valde in terra Aegypti, coram servis Pharaonis et omni populo.
verses.english: For the Lord will grant favor to His people in the sight of the Egyptians, so they will give them what they ask for. And Moses himself was a very great man in the land of Egypt, respected by Pharaoh's servants and by all the people.

verses.latin: Et ait Moyses: Hæc dicit Dominus: Media nocte ingrediar Aegyptum.
verses.english: Then Moses declared: 'This is what the Lord says: About midnight tonight, I will go forth into the midst of Egypt.'

verses.latin: Et morietur omne primogenitum in terra Aegyptiorum, a primogenito Pharaonis, qui sedet in solio ejus, usque ad primogenitum ancillæ quæ est ad molam, et omnia primogenita jumentorum.
verses.english: And every firstborn in the land of Egypt will die: from the firstborn son of Pharaoh, who sits upon his throne, down to the firstborn son of the servant girl who grinds at the mill, and also all the firstborn of the livestock.

verses.latin: Et erit clamor magnus in universa terra Aegypti, qualis nec ante fuit nec postea futurus est.
verses.english: And there will be a great cry throughout the entire land of Egypt, such as has never been before, nor will there ever be again.

verses.latin: Apud omnes autem filios Israel non mugiet canis, a viro usque ad pecus: ut sciatis quanto miraculo dividat Dominus Aegyptios et Israel.
verses.english: But among all the children of Israel, not even a dog will bark, neither against a human nor against an animal. This is so you may know with what great miracle the Lord makes a distinction between the Egyptians and Israel.

verses.latin: Et descendent omnes servi tui isti ad me, et adorabunt me, dicentes: Egredere tu et omnis populus qui sub te est: et post hæc egrediar.
verses.english: And all these servants of yours will come down to me and bow before me, saying: 'Leave, you and all the people who are under your authority!' And only after this will I depart from Egypt.

verses.latin: Et dixit Dominus ad Moysen: Non audiet vos Pharao, ut multa fiant ostenta mea in terra Aegypti.
verses.english: The Lord had also said to Moses: 'Pharaoh will not listen to you, so that many of My wonders may be performed in the land of Egypt.'

verses.latin: Moyses autem et Aaron fecerunt omnia ostenta quæ scripta sunt, coram Pharaone: et induravit Dominus cor Pharaonis, nec dimisit filios Israel de terra sua.
verses.english: Moses and Aaron performed all these wonders that are written about, in the presence of Pharaoh. But the Lord hardened Pharaoh’s heart, and he did not let the children of Israel leave his land.

verses.latin: Dixit autem Dominus ad Moysen et Aaron in terra Aegypti:
verses.english: And the Lord spoke to Moses and Aaron while they were in the land of Egypt:

verses.latin: Mensis iste vobis principium mensium: primus erit in mensibus anni.
verses.english: "This month will be the beginning of your calendar months. It will be the first month of your year.

verses.latin: Loquimini ad universum coetum filiorum Israel, et dicite illis: Decima die mensis hujus tollat unusquisque agnum per familias et domos suas.
verses.english: Tell the whole community of the Children of Israel: 'On the tenth day of this month, each man is to take a lamb for his family and for his household.

verses.latin: Sin autem minor est numerus, et non sufficit ad vescendum agnum, assumet vicinum suum qui junctus est domui suae, juxta numerum animarum, quae sufficere possunt ad esum agni.
verses.english: If the household is too small for a whole lamb, then the family and their nearest neighbor should share one, based on the number of people who can eat the lamb.

verses.latin: Agnus autem erit immaculatus, masculus anniculus: quem de ovibus et capris tolletis.
verses.english: The lamb must be without blemish, a male, and one year old. You may choose it from either the sheep or the goats.

verses.latin: Et servabitis eum usque ad quartam decimam diem mensis hujus: immolabitque illum universa multitudo filiorum Israel ad vesperam.
verses.english: You must keep the lamb until the fourteenth day of this month. Then, the entire assembly of the Children of Israel will sacrifice it at twilight.

verses.latin: Et sument de sanguine ejus, ac ponent super utrumque postem, et in superliminaribus domorum, in quibus comedent illum.
verses.english: And they are to take some of its blood and put it on both doorposts and on the lintel of the houses where they eat the lamb.

verses.latin: Et edent carnes nocte illa assas igni, et azymos panes cum lactucis agrestibus.
verses.english: On that very night, they must eat the meat roasted over fire, along with unleavened bread and bitter herbs.

verses.latin: Non comedetis ex eo crudum quid, nec coctum aqua, sed tantum assatum igni: caput cum pedibus et intestinis ejus.
verses.english: Do not eat any of it raw or boiled in water. It must be roasted over fire, including its head, legs, and internal organs.

verses.latin: Nec remanebit quidquam ex eo usque mane. Si quid residuum fuerit, igne comburetis.
verses.english: You must not leave any of it until morning. If anything remains, you are to burn it with fire.

verses.latin: Sic autem comedetis illum: renes vestros accingetis, calceamenta habebitis in pedibus, tenentes baculos in manibus, et comedetis festinanter: est enim Phase (id est, Transitus) Domini.
verses.english: This is how you are to eat it: with your belts fastened, your sandals on your feet, and your staff in your hand. You must eat it quickly, because it is the Lord's Passover—meaning His passing over.

verses.latin: Transibo enim per terram Aegypti nocte illa, percutiamque omne primogenitum in terra Aegypti ab homine usque ad pecus: et in omnibus diis Aegypti faciam judicia: ego Dominus.
verses.english: For on that very night, I will pass through the land of Egypt and strike down every firstborn son in Egypt, from the firstborn of humans to the firstborn of animals. And I will execute judgments against all the false gods of Egypt, for I am the Lord.

verses.latin: Et erit sanguis vobis in signum in domibus in quibus eritis: et videbo sanguinem, et transibo vos: nec erit in vobis plaga disperdens, quando percussero terram Aegypti.
verses.english: The blood on your houses will be a sign for you. When I see the blood, I will pass over you, and no destructive plague will touch you when I strike the land of Egypt.

verses.latin: Habebitis autem diem hanc in monumentum: et celebrabitis eam solemnem Domino in generationibus vestris ritu sempiterno.
verses.english: This day will be a memorial for you. You are to celebrate it as a festival to the Lord throughout your generations, observing it as a perpetual ordinance.

verses.latin: Septem diebus azyma comedetis: in die primo non erit fermentum in domibus vestris: quicumque comederit fermentatum, a die primo usque ad diem septimum, peribit anima illa de Israel.
verses.english: For seven days, you must eat unleavened bread. On the very first day, you must remove all leaven from your houses. Anyone who eats anything leavened from the first day to the seventh day will be cut off from Israel.

verses.latin: Dies prima sancta erit et solemnis, et dies septima insignis eadem festivitate: nihil operis facietis in eis, excepto his quae ad vescendum pertinent.
verses.english: The first day will be a holy and solemn assembly, and the seventh day will also be a solemn festival. You must not do any work on these days, except for what is necessary to prepare food for everyone.

verses.latin: Et observabitis azyma: in ipsa enim die eduxi exercitum vestrum de terra Aegypti, et custodietis diem istum in generationes vestras ritu sempiterno.
verses.english: You must observe the Festival of Unleavened Bread, because on this very day I brought your armies out of the land of Egypt. So you must keep this day throughout your generations as a perpetual ordinance.

verses.latin: Primo mense, quartadecima die mensis, ad vesperam, comedetis azyma usque ad vigesimam primam diem illius mensis, ad vesperam.
verses.english: In the first month, from the evening of the fourteenth day until the evening of the twenty-first day of that month, you must eat unleavened bread.

verses.latin: Septem diebus fermentum non invenietur in domibus vestris: qui comederit fermentatum, peribit anima illius de coetu Israel, tam advena quam indigena.
verses.english: For seven days, no leaven is to be found in your houses. Anyone who eats anything leavened will be cut off from the community of Israel, whether they are a foreigner or a native-born Israelite.

verses.latin: Omne fermentatum non comedetis: in cunctis habitaculis vestris comedetis azyma.
verses.english: You must not eat anything leavened. In all your dwelling places, you must eat unleavened bread."

verses.latin: Vocavit autem Moyses omnes seniores filiorum Israel, et dixit ad eos: Ite, tollite atque sumite animal per familias vestras, et immolate Phase.
verses.english: Moses then called all the elders of the Children of Israel and said to them, "Go, select and take a lamb for your families, and sacrifice the Passover lamb.

verses.latin: Fasciculum hyssopi tingite in sanguine qui est in limine, et aspergite ex eo superliminare et utrumque postem. Nemo egrediatur de ostio domus suae usque mane.
verses.english: Take a bunch of hyssop, dip it into the blood that is in the basin, and apply some of it to the lintel and both doorposts. And none of you shall go out the door of your house until morning.

verses.latin: Transibit enim Dominus percuciens Aegyptios: cumque viderit sanguinem in superliminari, et in utroque poste, transiet ostium Domini ac non sinet percussorem ingredi domos vestras, et lædere.
verses.english: For the Lord will pass through to strike the Egyptians. And when He sees the blood on the lintel and on both doorposts, the Lord will pass over that door and will not permit the Destroyer—God's instrument of judgment—to enter your houses to harm you.

verses.latin: Custodite verbum istud in ritu et in æternum vos et filii vestri.
verses.english: You must observe this command as an ordinance for you and your children forever.

verses.latin: Cumque ingrederemini terram quam daturus est Dominus vobis, sicut promisit, observabitis cæremonias istas.
verses.english: When you enter the land that the Lord will give you, as He promised, you must keep these ceremonies.

verses.latin: Et cum dixerint vobis filii vestri: Quæ est ista religio?
verses.english: And when your children ask you, "What is the meaning of this religious service?"

verses.latin: Respondebitis eis: Victima transitus Domini est, quando transiit super domos filiorum Israel in Aegypto, percutiens Aegyptios, et domos nostras liberans. Incurvatoque populo adoravit.
verses.english: You will tell them, "It is the sacrifice of the Lord's Passover, because He passed over the houses of the Children of Israel in Egypt when He struck the Egyptians but spared our homes." Then the people bowed down and worshipped.

verses.latin: Et egressi filii Israel fecerunt sicut præceperat Dominus Moysi et Aaron.
verses.english: So the Children of Israel went and did exactly as the Lord had commanded Moses and Aaron.

verses.latin: Factum est autem in media nocte, percussit Dominus omne primogenitum in terra Aegypti, a primogenito Pharaonis qui sedebat in solio ejus, usque ad primogenitum captivi qui erat in carcere, et omne primogenitum jumentorum.
verses.english: And it came to pass at the middle of that night, the Lord struck down every firstborn son in the land of Egypt—from the firstborn of Pharaoh, who sat on his throne, to the firstborn of the captive in the dungeon, and every firstborn of the livestock.

verses.latin: Surrexitque Pharao nocte, et omnes servi ejus, et cuncta Aegyptus: et ortus est clamor magnus in Aegypto: neque enim erat domus, in qua non jaceret mortuus.
verses.english: Pharaoh rose up in the night, along with all his servants and all the Egyptians. And there was a great cry throughout Egypt, for there was not a single house where there was not one dead.

verses.latin: Vocatisque Moysen et Aaron nocte, ait: Surgite, egredimini de medio populi mei, et vos et filii Israel: ite, immolate Domino sicut locuti estis.
verses.english: Then Pharaoh called for Moses and Aaron during the night and said, "Get up! Go out from among my people, both you and the Children of Israel. Go, worship the Lord as you have said.

verses.latin: Oves vestras et armenta assumite, sicut petistis: et proficiscimini: precamini pro me.
verses.english: Take your flocks and your herds, as you requested, and depart. And pray for me, too."

verses.latin: Urgebantque Aegyptii populum de terra exire velociter, dicentes: Omnes moriemur.
verses.english: The Egyptians pressed the people to leave the land quickly, saying, "We will all die if you don't go!"

verses.latin: Tulit itaque populus conspersam farinam, antequam fermentaretur: et alligantes in vestimentis suis involutam humeris.
verses.english: So the people took their dough before it was leavened, and binding their kneading bowls in their cloaks, they carried them on their shoulders.

verses.latin: Fecerunt autem filii Israel sicut præceperat Moyses: et petierunt ab Aegyptiis vasa argentea et aurea, vestemque plurimam.
verses.english: The Children of Israel had also done as Moses commanded: they had asked the Egyptians for articles of silver and gold, and for many garments.

verses.latin: Dedit autem Dominus gratiam populo coram Aegyptiis, et commodantes dederunt: atque ita spoliaverunt Aegyptios.
verses.english: And the Lord gave the people favor in the sight of the Egyptians, so they gave them what they asked for. Thus, the Israelites plundered the Egyptians.

verses.latin: Profectique sunt filii Israel de Ramesse in Succoth, sexcenta fere millia peditum virorum, absque parvulis.
verses.english: The Children of Israel journeyed from Rameses to Succoth, about six hundred thousand men on foot, besides children.

verses.latin: Sed et vulgus promiscuum innumerabile ascendit cum eis, et oves atque armenta, et opes multæ nimis.
verses.english: A mixed multitude of countless others also went up with them, along with a vast amount of flocks and herds and very much wealth.

verses.latin: Coxeruntque farinam quam de Aegypto tulerant, subcinericios panes azymos: nec enim poterant fermentari, cogentibus Aegyptiis egredi, et nulla mora sinitentibus facete quidquam.
verses.english: And they baked unleavened cakes from the dough they had brought out of Egypt, for it could not be leavened. This was because the Egyptians had forced them to leave so suddenly, not allowing them to delay or prepare anything else.

verses.latin: Habitatio autem filiorum Israel, qua manserunt in Aegypto, fuit quadringentorum triginta annorum.
verses.english: Now, the dwelling of the Children of Israel, the time they had lived in Egypt, was four hundred and thirty years.

verses.latin: Locutusque est Dominus ad Moysen, dicens:
verses.english: The Lord then spoke to Moses, saying:

verses.latin: Sanctifica mihi omne primogenitum masculini sexus, quod aperit vulvam in filiis Israel, tam de hominibus quam de jumentis: mea sunt enim omnia.
verses.english: “Consecrate to Me every firstborn male among the sons of Israel, whether human or animal, the first to be born from a mother’s womb; for all of them belong to Me and are Mine.”

verses.latin: Et ait Moyses ad populum: Mementote diei hujus, in qua egressi estis de Aegypto, de domo servitutis: quoniam in manu forti eduxit vos Dominus de loco isto, et non comedetis fermentum.
verses.english: Moses then said to the people: “Remember this day, the day you came out of Egypt, from the house of slavery; because the Lord brought you out of that place with a strong hand, and therefore you shall not eat any leavened bread.”

verses.latin: Hodie egredimini mense novarum frugum.
verses.english: “Today you are leaving, in the month of new harvests,” (which is the month of Aviv, or Nisan, marking the beginning of the religious calendar).

verses.latin: Cumque te introduxerit Dominus in terram Chananæi et Hethæi et Amorrhæi et Hevæi et Jebusæi, quam juravit patribus tuis ut daret tibi, terram fluentem lacte et melle, celebrabis hunc ritum sacrorum mense isto.
verses.english: “And when the Lord has brought you into the land of the Canaanites, the Hittites, the Amorites, the Hivites, and the Jebusites—the land He swore to your fathers to give you, a land flowing with milk and honey—you shall observe this rite of sacred feasts in this very month.”

verses.latin: Septem diebus comedes azymos panes: et in die septimo est solemnitas Domini.
verses.english: “For seven days you shall eat unleavened bread: and on the seventh day there shall be a solemn feast of the Lord.”

verses.latin: Azymi panes comedentur septem diebus: non apparebit apud te fermentum, nec in cunctis finibus tuis.
verses.english: “Only unleavened bread shall be eaten for seven days; no leavened bread shall be seen among you, nor any leaven in all your territory.”

verses.latin: Et narrabis filio tuo in die illo, dicens: Hæc est propter id quod fecit Dominus mihi quando egressus sum de Aegypto.
verses.english: “And you shall explain to your son on that day, saying: ‘This is done because of what the Lord did for me when I came out of Egypt, as a remembrance of His great works.’”

verses.latin: Et erit quasi signum in manu tua, et quasi monumentum ante oculos tuos: ut lex Domini semper sit in ore tuo: quoniam in manu forti eduxit te Dominus de Aegypto.
verses.english: “And this feast shall be like a sign on your hand, and like a reminder before your eyes, so that the law of the Lord may always be on your lips and in your mind; for the Lord brought you out of Egypt with a strong, powerful hand.”

verses.latin: Custodies cultum istum temporibus suis a die in diem.
verses.english: “You shall keep this ordinance at its appointed time, from year to year.”

verses.latin: Cumque introduxerit te Dominus in terram Chananæi, sicut juravit tibi et patribus tuis, et dederit tibi eam:
verses.english: “And when the Lord has brought you into the land of the Canaanites, just as He swore to you and to your fathers, and has given it to you:”

verses.latin: transferes omnes qui aperiunt vulvam Domino, et omne quod primum parit masculini sexus, consecrabis Domino.
verses.english: “You shall set apart to the Lord every firstborn male, every first offspring that opens the womb, dedicating them as consecrated to the Lord.”

verses.latin: Omne primogenitum asini commutabis ove: et si non redemeris, interficies. Omne autem primogenitum hominis de filiis tuis, pretio redimes.
verses.english: “Every firstborn of an ass you shall redeem with a sheep; but if you do not redeem it, you shall break its neck to put it to death. And every firstborn human of your sons you shall redeem by paying a price.”

verses.latin: Cum interrogaverit te filius tuus cras, dicens: Quid est hoc? Respondebis ei: In manu forti eduxit nos Dominus de Aegypto de domo servitutis.
verses.english: “When your son asks you in time to come, saying, ‘What does this mean?’ you shall answer him: ‘With a strong hand the Lord brought us out of Egypt, from the house of slavery.’”

verses.latin: Nam cum induratus esset Pharao, et nollet nos dimittere, occidit Dominus omne primogenitum in terra Aegypti, a primogenito hominis usque ad primogenitum jumentorum: idcirco immolo Domino omne masculini sexus quod aperit vulvam, et omnes primogenitos filiorum meorum redimo.
verses.english: “‘For when Pharaoh stubbornly refused to let us go, the Lord killed every firstborn in the land of Egypt, from the firstborn of man even to the firstborn of animals. Because of this, I sacrifice to the Lord every firstborn male that opens the womb, but I redeem all the firstborn of my sons by paying a price.’”

verses.latin: Et erit quasi signum in manu tua, et quasi inmemoriale ante oculos tuos: propterea quod in manu forti eduxit nos Dominus de Aegypto.
verses.english: “‘And it shall be like a sign on your hand and like a memorial between your eyes, because the Lord brought us out of Egypt with a strong, powerful hand.’”

verses.latin: Igitur cum emisisset Pharao populum, non eos duxit Deus per viam terræ Philisthiim, quæ vicina est: ne forte pœniteret eum, si vidisset bella, et reverteretur in Aegyptum.
verses.english: So when Pharaoh had let the people go, God did not lead them by the way of the land of the Philistines, though that was the shortest and nearest route; for God said, 'Lest perhaps the people change their minds if they see war, and return to Egypt.'

verses.latin: Sed circumduxit per viam deserti, quæ est juxta mare Rubrum. Armati igitur ascenderunt filii Israel de terra Aegypti.
verses.english: Instead, God led them around by way of the desert toward the Red Sea. So the sons of Israel went up out of the land of Egypt prepared for battle, carrying their weapons.

verses.latin: Tulit quoque Moyses ossa Joseph secum: eo quod adjurasset filios Israel, dicens: Visitabit vos Deus, asportate ossa mea hinc vobiscum.
verses.english: Moses also took the bones of Joseph with him; because Joseph had made the sons of Israel swear an oath, saying: 'God will surely visit you and bring you out of this land, so you must carry my bones with you from here.'

verses.latin: Profectique de Succoth, castrametati sunt in Etham, in extremis finibus solitudinis.
verses.english: Then they moved on from Succoth and encamped in Etham, on the edge of the wilderness.

verses.latin: Dominus autem præcedebat eos ad ostendendam viam per diem in columna nubis, et per noctem in columna ignis, ut dux esset itineris utroque tempore.
verses.english: And the Lord went before them, to show them the way by day in a pillar of cloud, and by night in a pillar of fire, so that He might be their guide for the journey at both times.

verses.latin: Numquam defuit columna nubis per diem, nec columna ignis per noctem, coram omni populo.
verses.english: The pillar of cloud by day and the pillar of fire by night never departed from before all the people, always guiding them.

verses.latin: Locutusque est Dominus ad Moysen, dicens:
verses.english: The Lord then spoke to Moses, saying:

verses.latin: Loquere filiis Israel: Revertantur, et castrametentur contra Phihahiroth inter Magdolum et mare contra Beelsephon: in conspectu ejus castra ponetis super mare.
verses.english: “Speak to the children of Israel: Tell them to turn back and make camp before Pi-hahiroth, between Migdol and the Red Sea, opposite Baal-zephon. They must camp by the sea there.”

verses.latin: Dicetque Pharao super filiis Israel: Vagi sunt in terra, conclusit eos desertum.
verses.english: “Pharaoh will then say about the children of Israel: ‘They are lost and wandering aimlessly in the land, and the desert has trapped them in.’”

verses.latin: Et indurabo cor ejus, et persequetur vos: et glorificabor in Pharaone, et in omni exercitu ejus: sciantque Ægyptii, quia ego sum Dominus. Feceruntque ita.
verses.english: “And I will harden Pharaoh's heart, and he will pursue you. I will gain glory through Pharaoh and all his army, so that the Egyptians may know that I am the Lord.” The children of Israel then did exactly as God commanded.

verses.latin: Nuntiatum est autem regi Ægyptiorum, quod fugisset populus: et immutatum est cor Pharaonis et servorum ejus super populum, et dixerunt: Quid hoc fecimus, ut dimitteremus Israel, ne servirent nobis?
verses.english: News was brought to the king of Egypt that the people had fled. Then the hearts of Pharaoh and his servants changed regarding the people, and they said: “What have we done? Why did we let Israel leave our service?”

verses.latin: Junxit ergo currum suum, et omnem populum suum assumpsit secum.
verses.english: So Pharaoh prepared his royal chariot and took his entire army with him.

verses.latin: Tulitque sexcentos currus electos, et quidquid in Ægypto curruum erat: et duces totius exercitus.
verses.english: He took six hundred of the best chariots, along with all the other chariots in Egypt, and all the captains of the entire army.

verses.latin: Et induravit Dominus cor Pharaonis regis Ægypti, et persecutus est filios Israel: at illi egressi fuerant in manu excelsa.
verses.english: And the Lord had hardened the heart of Pharaoh, the king of Egypt, and he pursued the children of Israel, who had departed with great confidence.

verses.latin: Cumque persequerentur Ægyptii vestigia præcedentium, reppererunt eos in castris super mare: omnes equites et currus Pharaonis, et universus exercitus ejus erant in Phihahiroth contra Beelsephon.
verses.english: As the Egyptians followed the Israelites' tracks, they found them encamped by the Red Sea. All of Pharaoh's horsemen, chariots, and his entire army were at Pi-hahiroth, opposite Baal-zephon.

verses.latin: Cumque appropinquasset Pharao, levantes filii Israel oculos suos, viderunt Ægyptios post se: et timuerunt valde: clamaveruntque ad Dominum,
verses.english: As Pharaoh approached, the children of Israel looked up and saw the Egyptians pursuing them. They became terrified and cried out to the Lord for help.

verses.latin: et dixerunt ad Moysen: Forsitan non erant sepulchra in Ægypto, ideo tulisti nos ut moreremur in solitudine? quid hoc fecisti, ut educeres nos ex Ægypto?
verses.english: And they said to Moses: “Were there no graves for us in Egypt that you brought us out here to die in the wilderness? What have you done by leading us out of Egypt?”

verses.latin: Nonne iste est sermo quem loquebamur ad te in Ægypto, dicentes: Recede a nobis, ut serviamus Ægyptiis? multo enim melius est servire eis, quam mori in solitudine.
verses.english: “Is this not the very thing we told you in Egypt, saying: ‘Leave us alone so we may continue serving the Egyptians?’ It is far better for us to serve them than to die out here in the wilderness.”

verses.latin: Et ait Moyses ad populum: Nolite timere: state et videte magnalia Domini, quæ facturus est hodie: Ægyptios enim, quos nunc videtis, nequaquam ultra videbitis usque in sempiternum.
verses.english: And Moses said to the people: “Do not be afraid. Stand firm and witness the Lord's mighty works that He will perform for you today. For the Egyptians you see now, you will never see them again, ever.”

verses.latin: Dominus pugnabit pro vobis, et vos silebitis.
verses.english: “The Lord Himself will fight on your behalf, and you only need to be silent.”

verses.latin: Dixitque Dominus ad Moysen: Quid clamas ad me? loquere filiis Israel, ut proficiscantur.
verses.english: Then the Lord said to Moses: “Why do you cry out to me? Tell the children of Israel to move forward!”

verses.latin: Tu vero eleva virgam tuam, et extende manum tuam super mare, et divide illud: ut gradiantur filii Israel per medium maris sicco pede.
verses.english: “As for you, lift up your staff and stretch out your hand over the Red Sea, and divide its waters, so that the children of Israel may walk through the middle of the sea on dry ground.”

verses.latin: Ego autem indurabo cor Ægyptiorum, ut persequantur vos: et glorificabor in Pharaone, et in omni exercitu ejus, et in curribus, et in equitibus illius.
verses.english: “And I will harden the hearts of the Egyptians, so that they will pursue you. I will gain glory through Pharaoh and all his army, his chariots, and his horsemen.”

verses.latin: Et scient Ægyptii quia ego sum Dominus, cum glorificatus fuero in Pharaone, et in curribus, et in equitibus ejus.
verses.english: “Then the Egyptians will know that I am the Lord, when I have been glorified through Pharaoh, his chariots, and his horsemen.”

verses.latin: Tollensque angelus Dei, qui præcedebat castra Israel, abiit post eos: et cum columna nubis simul, a priore loco recessit, stetitque post tergum,
verses.english: Then the Angel of God, who had been leading the camp of Israel, moved and went behind them. The pillar of cloud also moved from its position in front of them and stood behind them.

verses.latin: inter castra Ægyptiorum et castra Israel. Et erat nubes tenebrosa, et illuminans noctem, et per totam noctem ad invicem accedere non potuerunt.
verses.english: It positioned itself between the camp of the Egyptians and the camp of Israel. To the Egyptians, it was a dark cloud bringing darkness, but to the Israelites, it lit up the night. Thus, for the entire night, the two camps could not approach each other.

verses.latin: Cumque extendisset Moyses manum super mare, reduxit Dominus mare in impetu spiritus vehementis, flagrantis tota nocte, et fecit siccum: et divisæ sunt aquæ.
verses.english: When Moses stretched out his hand over the Red Sea, the Lord drove the sea back with a powerful, strong wind that blew all night. He made the sea into dry land, and the waters were miraculously divided.

verses.latin: Et ingressi sunt filii Israel per medium maris sicco pede: aquæque eis erant quasi pro muro a dextra et læva.
verses.english: The children of Israel walked into the middle of the Red Sea on dry ground, with the waters forming a wall for them on both their right and left sides.

verses.latin: Persequentesque Ægyptii ingressi sunt post eos, et omnis equitatus Pharaonis, currus ejus et equites per medium maris.
verses.english: The Egyptians pursued them and went into the middle of the Red Sea after them—all of Pharaoh's cavalry, his chariots, and his horsemen.

verses.latin: Jamque advenerat vigilia matutina, et ecce respiciens Dominus super castra Ægyptiorum per columnam ignis et nubis, interfecit exercitum eorum.
verses.english: In the early morning watch, the Lord looked down from the pillar of fire and cloud upon the camp of the Egyptians and struck their army, causing great confusion.

verses.latin: Et subvertit rotas curruum, et ferebantur cum difficultate. Dixerunt ergo Ægyptii: Fugiamus Israelem: Dominus enim pugnat pro eis contra nos.
verses.english: He caused their chariot wheels to be removed, so that they drove with great difficulty. Then the Egyptians said: “Let us flee from the Israelites, for the Lord is fighting for them against us!”

verses.latin: Et ait Dominus ad Moysen: Extende manum tuam super mare, ut revertantur aquæ ad Ægyptios, super currus et equites eorum.
verses.english: Then the Lord said to Moses: “Stretch out your hand over the Red Sea, so that the waters may return and cover the Egyptians, their chariots, and their horsemen.”

verses.latin: Cumque extendisset Moyses manum contra mare, reversum est primo diluculo ad priorem locum: et Ægyptii fugientes occurrerunt aquis: et involvit Dominus Ægyptios in mediis fluctibus.
verses.english: So, when Moses stretched out his hand over the Red Sea, it returned to its full depth at the first break of dawn. As the Egyptians fled from it, they ran straight into the returning waters. The Lord then engulfed the Egyptians in the midst of the waves.

verses.latin: Et reversæ sunt aquæ, et operuerunt currus et equites cuncti exercitus Pharaonis, qui sequentes ingressi fuerant mare: ne unus quidem superfuit ex eis.
verses.english: The waters returned and covered all the chariots and horsemen of Pharaoh's entire army that had pursued the Israelites into the sea. Not a single one of them survived.

verses.latin: Filii autem Israel perrexerunt per medium sicci maris, et aquæ eis erant quasi murus a dextris et a sinistris.
verses.english: But the children of Israel had walked safely through the middle of the dry Red Sea, with the waters forming a protective wall for them on their right and on their left.

verses.latin: Liberavitque Dominus in die illo Israel de manu Ægyptiorum: et viderunt Ægyptios mortuos super littus maris.
verses.english: On that day, the Lord delivered Israel from the power of the Egyptians. And the Israelites saw the dead bodies of the Egyptians lying on the seashore.

verses.latin: Et viderunt Israel manum magnam quam exercuerat Dominus contra Ægyptios: et timuit populus Dominum, et crediderunt Domino, et Moysi servo ejus.
verses.english: And Israel saw the Lord's great power that He had exercised against the Egyptians. The people then revered the Lord and put their trust in the Lord and in Moses, His servant.

verses.latin: Tunc cecinit Moyses et filii Israël carmen hoc Domino, et dixerunt:
verses.english: Then Moses and the sons of Israel sang this song to the Lord, saying:

verses.latin: Cantemus Domino, gloriose enim magnificatus est: equum et ascensorem dejecit in mare.
verses.english: Let us sing to the Lord, for He has shown His great glory mightily; He has cast the horse and its rider into the sea.

verses.latin: Fortitudo mea, et laus mea Dominus, et factus est mihi in salutem: iste Deus meus, et glorificabo eum: Deus patris mei, et exaltabo eum.
verses.english: My strength and my praise is the Lord; He has become my salvation. This is my God, and I will glorify Him. He is the God of my father, and I will exalt Him.

verses.latin: Dominus quasi vir pugnator, Omnipotens nomen ejus.
verses.english: The Lord is a mighty warrior; His name is the Almighty.

verses.latin: Currus Pharaonis et exercitum ejus projecit in mare: electi principes ejus submersi sunt in Mari Rubro.
verses.english: He cast Pharaoh’s chariots and his army into the sea; his finest officers were submerged in the Red Sea.

verses.latin: Dextera tua, Domine, magnificata est in fortitudine: dextera tua, Domine, percussit inimicum.
verses.english: Your right hand, O Lord, is glorious in power. Your right hand, O Lord, struck down the enemy.

verses.latin: Et in multitudine gloriae tuae deposuisti adversarios tuos: misisti iram tuam, quae devoravit eos sicut stipulam.
verses.english: And in the greatness of Your glory, You overthrew Your adversaries. You sent forth Your wrath, which devoured them like stubble.

verses.latin: Et in spiritu furoris tui congregatae sunt aquae: stetit unda fluens, congregata est abyssi magnitudo in medio mari.
verses.english: And by the blast of Your fury, the waters were gathered together. The flowing waves stood up like a wall, and the mighty depths were congealed in the midst of the sea.

verses.latin: Dixit inimicus: Persequar et apprehendam, dividam spolia, implebitur anima mea: evaginabo gladium meum, interficiet eos manus mea.
verses.english: The enemy said, 'I will pursue, and I will overtake them. I will divide the spoil; my desire will be satisfied. I will draw my sword; my hand will destroy them.'

verses.latin: Flavit spiritus tuus, et operuit eos mare: submersi sunt quasi plumbum in aquis vehementibus.
verses.english: You blew with Your breath, and the sea covered them. They sank like lead in the mighty waters.

verses.latin: Quis similis tui in fortibus, Domine? quis similis tui, magnificus in sanctitate, terribilis atque laudabilis, faciens mirabilia?
verses.english: Who is like You among the mighty ones, O Lord? Who is like You, magnificent in holiness, awe-inspiring and worthy of praise, doing wonders?

verses.latin: Extendisti manum tuam, et devoravit eos terra.
verses.english: You stretched out Your hand, and the earth swallowed them.

verses.latin: Ducem fuisti in misericordia tua populo quem redemisti: et portasti eum in fortitudine tua ad habitaculum sanctum tuum.
verses.english: You led in Your mercy the people whom You redeemed; and You carried them in Your strength to Your holy dwelling place.

verses.latin: Audierunt populi, et irati sunt: dolores obtinuerunt habitatores Philisthiim.
verses.english: The nations heard, and they trembled. Pains seized the inhabitants of Philistia.

verses.latin: Tunc conturbati sunt principes Edom, robustos Moab stupor obtinuit: obriguerunt omnes habitatores Chanaan.
verses.english: Then the princes of Edom were dismayed. Dread took hold of the mighty men of Moab. All the inhabitants of Canaan grew rigid with fear.

verses.latin: Irruat super eos formido et pavor, in magnitudine brachii tui: fiant immobiles quasi lapis, donec pertranseat populus tuus, Domine: donec pertranseat populus tuus iste quem possedisti.
verses.english: Let terror and dread fall upon them, by the greatness of Your arm. Let them become as still as a stone, until Your people pass over, O Lord—until this people passes over whom You have claimed as Your own.

verses.latin: Introduces eos, et plantabis in monte haereditatis tuae, firmissimo habitaculo tuo quod operatus es, Domine: sanctuarium tuum, Domine, quod firmaverunt manus tuae.
verses.english: You will bring them in and plant them on the mountain of Your inheritance, Your most firm dwelling place, which You, O Lord, have made. It is Your sanctuary, O Lord, which Your hands have established.

verses.latin: Dominus regnabit in æternum et ultra.
verses.english: The Lord will reign forever and beyond.

verses.latin: Ingressus est enim equus Pharao cum curribus et equitibus ejus in mare: et reduxit super eos Dominus aquas maris: filii autem Israël ambulaverunt per siccum in medio eorum.
verses.english: For Pharaoh’s horses, with his chariots and his horsemen, went into the sea; and the Lord brought back the waters of the sea upon them. But the sons of Israel walked on dry land through the midst of the sea.

verses.latin: Sumpsit ergo Maria prophetissa soror Aaron tympanum in manu sua: egressaeque sunt omnes mulieres post eam cum tympanis et choris.
verses.english: Then Miriam the prophetess, the sister of Aaron, took a tambourine in her hand, and all the women went out after her with tambourines and in dances.

verses.latin: Quibus præcinebat, dicens: Cantemus Domino, gloriose enim magnificatus est: equum et ascensorem dejecit in mare.
verses.english: And Miriam led them in song, saying: 'Let us sing to the Lord, for He has shown His great glory mightily; He has cast the horse and its rider into the sea.'

verses.latin: Tulit autem Moyses Israël de Mari Rubro, et egressi sunt in desertum Sur: abieruntque tribus diebus per solitudinem, et non invenerunt aquam.
verses.english: Then Moses led Israel from the Red Sea, and they went out into the desert of Sur. They journeyed for three days through the wilderness and found no water.

verses.latin: Et venerunt in Mara, nec poterant bibere aquas de Mara, eo quod essent amaræ: unde et aptum est nomen loco, appellavitque nomen ejus Mara, id est, amaritudo.
verses.english: And they came to Marah, but they could not drink the waters of Marah because they were bitter. Therefore, a fitting name was given to the place, and he called its name Marah, which means 'bitterness.'

verses.latin: Et murmuravit populus contra Moysen, dicens: Quid bibemus?
verses.english: And the people murmured against Moses, saying, 'What shall we drink?'

verses.latin: At ille clamavit ad Dominum, qui ostendit ei lignum: quod cum misisset in aquas, in dulcedinem versæ sunt. Ibi constituit ei præcepta, atque judicia, et ibi tentavit eum,
verses.english: But Moses cried to the Lord, and the Lord showed him a tree. When Moses cast it into the waters, they became sweet. There the Lord established for them decrees and judgments, and there He tested him—Moses, and through him, the people of Israel.

verses.latin: dicens: Si audieris vocem Domini Dei tui, et quod justum est coram eo feceris, et obedieris mandatis ejus, custodierisque omnia præcepta mea, omnem languorem, quem posui in Ægypto, non inducam super te: ego enim Dominus sanator tuus.
verses.english: Saying: 'If you will diligently listen to the voice of the Lord your God, and will do what is right in His sight, and will obey His commandments, and keep all My statutes, I will bring upon you none of the diseases which I brought upon Egypt. For I am the Lord your healer.'

verses.latin: Venerunt autem in Elim, ubi erant duodecim fontes aquarum, et septuaginta palmæ: et castrametati sunt juxta aquas.
verses.english: Then they came to Elim, where there were twelve springs of water and seventy palm trees; and they encamped there by the waters.

verses.latin: Profectique sunt de Elim, et venit omnis multitudo filiorum Israel in desertum Sin, quod est inter Elim et Sinai, quintadecima die mensis secundi, postquam egressi sunt de terra Ægypti.
verses.english: They set out from Elim. The entire people of the Children of Israel came to the desert of Sin, which is located between Elim and Sinai. This happened on the fifteenth day of the second month—about a month after they had departed from the land of Egypt.

verses.latin: Et murmuravit omnis congregatio filiorum Israel contra Moysen et Aaron in solitudine.
verses.english: The entire community of the Children of Israel began to murmur against Moses and Aaron while they were in the wilderness.

verses.latin: Dixitque ad eos: Utinam mortui essemus per manum Domini in terra Ægypti, quando sedebamus super ollas carnium, et comedebamus panem in saturitate: quare eduxistis nos in desertum hoc, ut occideretis omnem multitudinem fame?
verses.english: And they said to Moses and Aaron, 'If only we had died by the hand of the Lord while we were in the land of Egypt! There, we used to sit by pots of meat and eat our fill of bread. Why have you brought us out into this wilderness, only to kill this entire community with hunger?'

verses.latin: Dixit autem Dominus ad Moysen: Ecce ego pluam vobis panes de cælo: egrediatur populus, et colligat quantum sibi sufficiat per singulos dies: ut tentem eum utrum ambulet in lege mea, an non.
verses.english: Then the Lord said to Moses, 'Listen, I will rain bread down for you from the sky. The people must go out and gather what is sufficient for each day, so that I may test them to see whether they will follow My law or not.'

verses.latin: Die autem sexta parent quod inferant: et sit duplum ejus, quod per singulos dies colligere consueverant.
verses.english: 'But on the sixth day, they must prepare what they bring in, and it will be double what they are accustomed to gather on other days.'

verses.latin: Dixitque Moyses et Aaron ad omnes filios Israel: Vespere scietis quod Dominus eduxerit vos de terra Ægypti:
verses.english: Then Moses and Aaron said to all the Children of Israel, 'This evening you will know that the Lord brought you out from the land of Egypt.'

verses.latin: et mane videbitis gloriam Domini: audivit enim Dominus murmur vestrum contra se: nos enim quid sumus, ut queramini contra nos?
verses.english: 'And in the morning, you will see the glory of the Lord. For the Lord has heard your murmuring against Him. For who are we, that you should complain against us?'

verses.latin: Et ait Moyses: Dabit Dominus vobis vespere carnes ad vescendum, et mane panes in saturitate: eo quod audierit Dominus murmur vestrum, quo murmurati estis contra eum: nos enim quid sumus? nec contra nos est murmur vestrum, sed contra Dominum.
verses.english: And Moses added, 'The Lord will give you meat to eat this evening and bread to eat your fill in the morning. This is because the Lord has heard your murmuring, with which you have murmured against Him. For who are we? Your murmuring is not against us, but against the Lord.'

verses.latin: Dixitque Moyses ad Aaron: Dic omni cœtui filiorum Israel: Accedite coram Domino: audivit enim murmur vestrum.
verses.english: Then Moses said to Aaron, 'Say to the entire assembly of the Children of Israel: Come forward before the Lord, for He has heard your murmuring.'

verses.latin: Cumque loqueretur Aaron ad universam multitudinem filiorum Israel, respexerunt ad solitudinem: et ecce gloria Domini apparuit in nube.
verses.english: And as Aaron spoke to the entire multitude of the Children of Israel, they looked toward the wilderness. And behold, the glory of the Lord appeared in a cloud.

verses.latin: Locutus est autem Dominus ad Moysen, dicens:
verses.english: Then the Lord spoke to Moses, saying:

verses.latin: Audivi murmur filiorum Israel: loquere ad eos, Vespere comedetis carnes, et mane saturabimini panibus: scietisque quod ego sim Dominus Deus vester.
verses.english: 'I have heard the murmuring of the Children of Israel. Speak to them, saying: This evening you will eat meat, and in the morning you will be filled with bread. And you will know that I am the Lord your God.'

verses.latin: Factum est ergo vespere, et ascendens coturnix, operuit castra: mane quoque ros jacuit per circuitum castrorum.
verses.english: So, it came to pass that in the evening, quails came up and covered the entire camp. And in the morning, there was dew lying all around the camp.

verses.latin: Cumque exiccasset, apparuit in superficie solitudinis quasi similitudo minuti granj pulveris super terram.
verses.english: When the dew had evaporated, behold, on the surface of the wilderness, there appeared something like fine flakes of frost upon the ground.

verses.latin: Quod cum vidissent filii Israel, dixerunt ad invicem: Man hu? quod significat: Quid est hoc? nesciebant enim quid esset.
verses.english: When the Children of Israel saw it, they said to one another, 'Man hu?' which means: 'What is this?' For they did not know what it was.

verses.latin: Dixitque Moyses ad eos: Hic est panis, quem dedit Dominus vobis ad vescendum.
verses.english: Then Moses said to them, 'This is the bread which the Lord has given you to eat.'

verses.latin: Hic est sermo, quem præcepit Dominus: Colligat unusquisque ex eo quantum sufficiat ad comedendum, gomor per singula capita, juxta numerum animarum vestrarum quæ habitant in tabernaculo sic tolletis.
verses.english: 'This is what the Lord has commanded: Let each one of you gather from it as much as he needs to eat—a gomor for each person, according to the number of souls in your tents. So shall you gather it.'

verses.latin: Feceruntque ita filii Israel: et collegerunt alius plus, alius minus.
verses.english: And the Children of Israel did so; some gathered more, some less.

verses.latin: Et mensi sunt ad gomor: nec qui plus collexerat, habuit amplius: nec qui minus, reperit minus: sed singuli juxta id, quod comedere poterant, collegerunt.
verses.english: And they measured it by the gomor: he who had gathered more had no excess, and he who had gathered less found no shortage. Each person had gathered just enough according to what they could eat.

verses.latin: Dixitque Moyses ad eos: Nemo relinquat ex eo usque mane.
verses.english: And Moses said to them, 'Let no one leave any of it until morning.'

verses.latin: Et non audierunt: sed quidam ex eis reliquerunt usque mane, et ebullivit vermibus, atque computruit: et iratus est contra eos Moyses.
verses.english: But they did not listen. Some of them left part of it until morning, and it bred worms and became foul. And Moses became angry with them.

verses.latin: Colligebant autem per singulos dies mane, quantum sufficere poterat singulis: cum vero incaluisset sol, liquescebat.
verses.english: They gathered it every morning, each person as much as they needed. But when the sun grew hot, it would melt away.

verses.latin: Die autem sexta collegerunt cibos duplices, duos gomor per singulos: veneruntque omnes principes multitudinis, et narraverunt Moysi.
verses.english: But on the sixth day, they gathered twice as much food, two gomors for each person. And all the leaders of the community came and reported this to Moses.

verses.latin: Qui respondit: Hoc est quod locutus est Dominus: Requies sabbati sanctificata est Domino cras: quodcumque operandum est, facite: et quæcumque coquenda sunt, coquite: quicquid autem reliquum fuerit, reponite usque in mane.
verses.english: He answered, 'This is what the Lord has said: Tomorrow is the rest of the Sabbath, a holy day for the Lord. Whatever you need to bake, bake today; and whatever you need to boil, boil today. But whatever is left over, set aside until morning.'

verses.latin: Et reposuerunt usque mane, sicut præceperat Moyses: nec computruit, nec vermis inventus est in eo.
verses.english: So they set it aside until morning, as Moses had commanded, and it did not become foul, nor were any worms found in it.

verses.latin: Dixitque Moyses: Comedite illud hodie, quia sabbatum Domini est: hodie non invenietis in agro.
verses.english: Then Moses said, 'Eat it today, because today is the Sabbath of the Lord. Today you will not find any of it in the field.'

verses.latin: Et factum est in die septimo, egressi sunt quidam de populo ut colligerent, et non invenerunt.
verses.english: And it happened that on the seventh day, some of the people went out to gather, but they found nothing.

verses.latin: Dixitque Dominus ad Moysen: Usquequo non vultis custodire mandata mea, et legem meam?
verses.english: Then the Lord said to Moses, 'How long will you refuse to keep My commandments and My law?'

verses.latin: Videte quod Dominus dederit vobis sabbatum, et propter hoc die sexta dedit vobis cibos duplices: manete singuli apud vos, non egrediatur homo de loco suo die septimo.
verses.english: 'See, the Lord has given you the Sabbath. That is why on the sixth day He gave you food for two days. Let each of you remain in your place; let no one go out from his place on the seventh day.'

verses.latin: Et sabbatizavit populus die septimo.
verses.english: So the people rested on the seventh day.

verses.latin: Domus autem Israel vocavit nomen ejus Man: erat autem quasi semen coriandri album, et saporis quasi simila cum melle.
verses.english: The house of Israel called its name Manna. It was like white coriander seed, and its taste was like flour mixed with honey.

verses.latin: Dixitque Moyses: Hic est sermo, quem præcepit Dominus: Imple gomor ex eo, et custodiatur in generationes vestras, ut sciant posteri vestri, ubi vos aluerim in solitudine, quando eduxi vos de terra Ægypti.
verses.english: And Moses said, 'This is what the Lord has commanded: Fill a gomor of it and keep it for your future generations, so that your descendants may know how I fed you in the wilderness, when I brought you out from the land of Egypt.'

verses.latin: Dixitque Moyses ad Aaron: Sume vas unum, et mitte ibi Man quantum potest capere gomor, et pone juxta testimonium, ut custodiatur in generationes vestras.
verses.english: Then Moses said to Aaron, 'Take an urn and put in it as much Manna as a gomor can hold, and place it beside the Testimony, so that it may be kept for your future generations.'

verses.latin: Sicut præcepit Dominus Moysi, posuitque Aaron juxta testimonium in custodiam.
verses.english: As the Lord had commanded Moses, so Aaron placed it beside the Testimony for safekeeping.

verses.latin: Filii autem Israel comederunt Man quadraginta annis, donec venirent in terram habitabilem: hujus cibi usi sunt, donec ad fines pervenerunt terræ Chanaan.
verses.english: Now the Children of Israel ate Manna for forty years, until they came to an inhabited land. They used this food until they reached the borders of the land of Canaan.

verses.latin: Gomor autem decima pars est ephi.
verses.english: Now, a gomor is the tenth part of an ephah.

verses.latin: Et erunt vestimenta tua juxta numerum temporum anni; et facient ad te sacrificia votiva, quia Dominus benedicet te in omni opere manuum tuarum.
verses.english: This verse is a textual error in some editions of the Clementine Vulgate, appearing here instead of Deuteronomy 14:22. It does not relate to the narrative of Exodus 16.

verses.latin: Ut quæcumque volueris, et in omnibus quibus indigueris, et quæ pro te, et pro domo tua volueris, et quæ in omnibus locis in quibus habueris, offeras Domino Deo tuo; ut benedicat tibi in omni opere manuum tuarum.
verses.english: This verse is also a textual error in some editions of the Clementine Vulgate, appearing here instead of Deuteronomy 14:26. It does not relate to the narrative of Exodus 16.

verses.latin: Et ne sis mendicus: quia Dominus Deus tuus dabit tibi benedictionem in omni opere manuum tuarum, in quo benedixerit tibi.
verses.english: This verse is also a textual error in some editions of the Clementine Vulgate, appearing here instead of Deuteronomy 15:10. It does not relate to the narrative of Exodus 16.

verses.latin: Et aperiet Dominus thesauros suos, qui sunt in cælo, ut pluam terram tuam, et benedicat omnia opera manuum tuarum.
verses.english: This verse is also a textual error in some editions of the Clementine Vulgate, appearing here instead of Deuteronomy 28:12. It does not relate to the narrative of Exodus 16.

verses.latin: Profectusque omnis conventus filiorum Israel de deserto Sin per mansiones suas juxta sermonem Domini, castrametati sunt in Raphidim: nec erat aqua populo ad bibendum.
verses.english: The entire community of the sons of Israel then moved on. They departed from the Desert of Sin, traveling through their regular stopping places. This was all according to the command of the Lord. They made their camp in a place called Rephidim, but there was no water there for the community to drink.

verses.latin: Jurgatusque est populus cum Moyse, et dixerunt: Da nobis aquam ut bibamus. Quibus respondit Moyses: Quid jurgamini mecum? quid tentatis Dominum?
verses.english: The community argued with Moses. They demanded: “Give us water so we can drink!” Moses replied to them: “Why are you quarreling with me? Why are you putting the Lord God to the test?”

verses.latin: Sitivit ergo ibi populus pro aquæ penuria, et murmuravit contra Moysen, dicens: Cur de Ægypto nos eduxisti, ut occideres nos et liberos nostros ac jumenta siti?
verses.english: The community there became extremely thirsty due to the lack of water. And they grumbled against Moses, saying: “Why did you bring us out of Egypt? Was it so you could kill us, our children, and our livestock with thirst?”

verses.latin: Clamavitque Moyses ad Dominum, dicens: Quid faciam populo huic? Adhuc parvum, et lapidabunt me.
verses.english: Moses then cried out to the Lord God, saying: “What should I do for this community? It will be only a little while, and they will stone me to death.”

verses.latin: Et dixit Dominus ad Moysen: Antecede populum, et assume tecum de senioribus Israel: et virgam tuam, qua percussisti fluvium, tolle in manu tua, et vade.
verses.english: Then the Lord God said to Moses: “Go ahead of the community, and take some of the elders of Israel with you. Also, take in your hand your staff—the very one with which you struck the Nile River—and go.”

verses.latin: Ecce ego stabo coram te ibi super petram Horeb: percutiesque petram, et exibit ex ea aqua ut bibat populus. Fecit Moyses ita coram senioribus Israel.
verses.english: “Look, I will stand before you there, on the rock at Horeb. You will strike that rock, and water will flow out of it so the community can drink.” Moses did exactly as he was told, in the presence of the elders of Israel.

verses.latin: Et vocavit nomen loci illius Tentatio, propter jurgium filiorum Israel, et quia tentaverunt Dominum, dicentes: Estne Dominus in nobis, an non?
verses.english: And he called the name of that place Massa, which means “Testing”. He did this because the sons of Israel quarreled, and because they put the Lord God to the test, saying: “Is the Lord God truly among us, or not?”

verses.latin: Venit autem Amalec, et pugnabat contra Israel in Raphidim.
verses.english: Amalek then came and fought against Israel in Rephidim.

verses.latin: Dixitque Moyses ad Josue: Elige tibi viros robustos, et egressus pugna contra Amalec: cras ego stabo in vertice collis, habens in manu mea virgam Dei.
verses.english: Moses said to Joshua: “Choose strong, capable men for yourself. Go out with them and fight against Amalek. Tomorrow, I will stand at the top of the hill, holding the staff of God in my hand.”

verses.latin: Fecit Josue ut locutus erat Moyses, et pugnavit contra Amalec: Moyses autem et Aaron et Hur ascenderunt super verticem collis.
verses.english: Joshua did exactly as Moses had told him, and he fought against Amalek. Meanwhile, Moses, Aaron, and Hur climbed to the very top of the hill.

verses.latin: Cumque elevasset Moyses manus, vincebat Israel: sin autem paululum remisisset, superabat Amalec.
verses.english: Whenever Moses raised his hands, Israel gained the advantage. But when he lowered them even slightly, Amalek began to prevail.

verses.latin: Manus autem Moysi erant graves: sumentesque lapidem posuerunt subter eum, in quo sedit: et Aaron et Hur sustentabant manus ejus ex utraque parte. Et factum est ut manus illius permanerent erectæ usque ad occasum solis.
verses.english: However, Moses' arms were very heavy. So they took a stone and placed it under him, and he sat on it. Then Aaron and Hur supported his hands on both sides. And so it was that his hands remained raised until the setting of the sun.

verses.latin: Fugavitque Josue Amalec et populum ejus in ore gladii.
verses.english: Joshua then routed Amalek and his community with the edge of the sword.

verses.latin: Dixit autem Dominus ad Moysen: Scribe hoc ob monumentum in libro, et trade auribus Josue: Quia delebo nomen Amalec sub cælo.
verses.english: Then the Lord God said to Moses: “Write this down as a memorial in a book, and recite it for Joshua to hear, because I will utterly blot out the name of Amalek from under the sky.”

verses.latin: Edificavitque Moyses altare: et vocavit nomen ejus, Dominus exaltationis meæ, sive, Dominus vexillum meum.
verses.english: And Moses built an altar. He called its name “The Lord is My Exaltation”, or “The Lord is My Banner”.

verses.latin: Dixit enim: Quia manus solii Domini, et bellum Domini erit contra Amalec de generatione in generationem.
verses.english: For he said: “Because a hand was lifted against the Lord God's throne, the Lord God's war will be against Amalek from generation to generation.”

verses.latin: Audiit autem Jethro sacerdos Madian, cognatus Moysi, omnia quæ fecerat Deus Moysi et Israëli populo suo, eo quod eduxisset Dominus Israël de Ægypto.
verses.english: Jethro, Moses' father-in-law and the priest of Midian, heard about all the great and mighty things God had done for Moses and for His people Israel, because the Lord had led Israel out of Egypt.

verses.latin: Et accepit Jethro cognatus Moysi Sephoram uxorem ejus, quam remiserat,
verses.english: Jethro, Moses' father-in-law, had taken Zipporah, Moses' wife, after Moses had sent her away for a time.

verses.latin: et duos filios ejus: quorum unus vocabatur Gersam, dicens: Advena fui in terra aliena.
verses.english: And Jethro also took Moses' two sons. The name of the first son was Gershom, which means 'I have been a stranger in a foreign land'.

verses.latin: Alter vero Eliezer, dicens: Deus enim patris mei adjutor meus, et eruit me de manu Pharaonis.
verses.english: The name of the other son was Eliezer, which means 'For the God of my father is my helper, and He has rescued me from the hand of Pharaoh'.

verses.latin: Venitque Jethro cognatus Moysi et filii ejus, et uxor ad Moysen in desertum, ubi erat castrametatus juxta montem Dei.
verses.english: So Jethro, Moses' father-in-law, came with Moses' sons and his wife to Moses in the desert, where Moses had set up camp near the mountain of God.

verses.latin: Et mandavit Moysi dicens: Ego Jethro cognatus tuus venio ad te, et uxor tua, et duo filii tui cum ea.
verses.english: Jethro sent a messenger to Moses, saying, 'I, Jethro, your father-in-law, am coming to you, along with your wife and your two sons with her.'

verses.latin: Et egressus est Moyses in occursum cognati sui: et adoravit, et osculatus est eum: inquiruntque mutuo salutem, et venerunt in tabernaculum illius.
verses.english: Moses went out to meet his father-in-law. He bowed down to him and kissed him. They asked about each other's well-being, and then they entered Moses' tent.

verses.latin: Et narravit Moyses cognato suo cuncta quæ fecerat Dominus Pharaoni et Ægyptiis propter Israël: et omnem laborem, qui acciderat eis in via, et quomodo liberaverat eos Dominus.
verses.english: Moses then recounted to his father-in-law everything the Lord had done to Pharaoh and the Egyptians for the sake of Israel, and all the hardship and troubles that had befallen them on their journey, and how the Lord had graciously delivered them from every danger.

verses.latin: Lætatusque est Jethro super omnibus bonis, quæ fecerat Dominus Israëli, eo quod eruisset eum de manu Ægyptiorum.
verses.english: Jethro rejoiced greatly over all the good things the Lord had done for Israel, especially because He had delivered them from the oppressive hand of the Egyptians.

verses.latin: Et ait: Benedictus Dominus, qui liberavit vos de manu Ægyptiorum, et de manu Pharaonis, qui eruit populum suum de manu Ægypti.
verses.english: And Jethro said, 'Blessed be the Lord, who has delivered you from the cruel hand of the Egyptians and from the powerful hand of Pharaoh, and who has rescued His people from the servitude of Egypt.'

verses.latin: Nunc cognovi, quia major sit Dominus cunctis diis: eo quod superbe egerint contra illos.
verses.english: Now I know and fully understand that the Lord is greater than all other gods, because He has demonstrated His power against those who dealt so proudly and arrogantly with Israel.

verses.latin: Attulit ergo Jethro cognatus Moysi holocastum et hostias Deo: veneruntque Aaron et omnes senes Israël, ut comederent panem cum eo coram Deo.
verses.english: Then Jethro, Moses' father-in-law, brought a burnt offering and other sacrifices to God. Aaron and all the elders of Israel came and ate a sacred meal with Moses' father-in-law in the presence of God.

verses.latin: Factum est autem in crastinum, sedit Moyses ut judicaret populum: qui stabat coram Moyse de mane usque ad vesperam.
verses.english: Now on the next day, Moses sat as judge over the people. And the people stood before Moses from early morning until late in the evening.

verses.latin: Cum vidisset cognatus Moysi omnia quæ agebat, dixit: Quid est hoc quod facis in populo? quare solus sedes, et omnis populus coram te stat de mane usque ad vesperam?
verses.english: When Moses' father-in-law saw all the work Moses was doing for the people, he asked, 'What is this thing you are doing for the people? Why do you alone sit as judge, while all the people stand around you from morning until evening?'

verses.latin: Cui respondit Moyses: Quia venit ad me populus quærens sententiam Dei:
verses.english: Moses answered him, 'It is because the people come to me to inquire about God's will and to seek a judgment from Him.'

verses.latin: siquando acciderit eis quæstio, veniunt ad me, ut judicem inter eos, et ostendam præcepta Dei et leges ejus.
verses.english: Whenever they have a dispute, they come to me, so that I may judge between them and make known to them the statutes of God and His laws.

verses.latin: Cui cognatus Moysi: Non bona est, inquit, res quam facis.
verses.english: Moses' father-in-law said to him, 'The way you are handling this situation is not good; it is not efficient or sustainable.'

verses.latin: Frustra consumeris, et tu, et hic populus qui tecum est: ultra vires tuas est negotium, solus illud ferre non poteris.
verses.english: 'You will surely wear yourself out, and so will these people who are with you. The burden of this task is too heavy for you; you alone cannot possibly bear it.'

verses.latin: Sed audi verba mea, et consilium dabo tibi, et erit Deus tecum. Esto tu populo in his quæ ad Deum pertinent, ut referas quæ dicuntur ad eum:
verses.english: 'Now listen to my words, and I will give you counsel, and may God be with you as you implement it. You should continue to represent the people before God, bringing their cases and concerns to Him.'

verses.latin: deque præceptis, et cæremoniis instrue illos: et ostende eis viam per quam ingredi debeant, et opus quod agere.
verses.english: 'You should also instruct them in God's statutes and sacred ceremonies, and show them the specific path they should walk and the work they are obligated to do.'

verses.latin: Provide autem de omni plebe viros strenuos, timentes Deum, in quibus sit veritas, et qui oderint avaritiam, et constitue super eos tribunos, et centuriones, et quinquagenarios, et decanos,
verses.english: 'But from among all the people, you must select capable men—men who truly fear God, who are trustworthy, and who utterly hate dishonest gain and corruption. Appoint them over the people as leaders of thousands, of hundreds, of fifties, and of tens.'

verses.latin: qui judicent populum omni tempore: quicquid autem majus fuerit, referant ad te, et ipsi minora tantum judicent: leviusque tibi sit, partito in alios onere.
verses.english: 'Let these men judge the people at all times. Whatever matters are too major or complex, they should refer to you, but they themselves should judge all the minor and simpler matters. This way, your burden will be lighter, as the responsibility will be shared by others.'

verses.latin: Si hoc feceris, implebis imperium Dei, et poteris sustinere: et omnis hic populus ad loca sua cum pace revertetur.
verses.english: 'If you do this, and God so commands you to do it, then you will be able to endure this work, and all these people will be able to return to their homes in peace and with justice served.'

verses.latin: Quibus auditis, Moyses fecit omnia quæ ille suggesserat.
verses.english: Moses listened carefully to his father-in-law's voice and did everything that he had suggested.

verses.latin: Et elegit viros strenuos de universo Israël: constituitque eos principes populi, tribunos, et centuriones, et quinquagenarios, et decanos.
verses.english: So Moses chose capable and virtuous men from all of Israel and appointed them as leaders over the people: leaders of thousands, leaders of hundreds, leaders of fifties, and leaders of tens.

verses.latin: Qui judicabant plebem omni tempore: quicquid autem majus erat, referebant ad eum: minora tantum judicabant.
verses.english: These appointed men judged the people at all times. Whatever matters were more significant, they referred to Moses himself; only the minor cases did they judge on their own.

verses.latin: Dimisitque cognatum suum: qui reversus abiit in terram suam.
verses.english: Then Moses sent his father-in-law away, and Jethro returned and went back to his own land.

verses.latin: Mense tertio egressionis Israël de terra Ægypti, in die hac venerunt in solitudinem Sinai.
verses.english: In the third month after Israel had departed from the land of Egypt, on that very day, they arrived in the Sinai wilderness.

verses.latin: Nam profecti de Raphidim, et pervenientes usque in desertum Sinai, castrametati sunt in eodem loco: ibique Israël fixit tentoria contra montem.
verses.english: After they had set out from Rephidim and arrived at the Sinai desert, they made their camp in that very place. There, the people of Israel pitched their tents facing Mount Sinai.

verses.latin: Ascendit autem Moyses ad Deum: vocavitque eum Dominus de monte, dicens: Hæc dices domui Jacob, et annuntiabis filiis Israël:
verses.english: Moses then climbed the mountain to encounter God. From the mountain, the Lord called to him, saying, "You are to speak these words to the family of Jacob, and you are to announce them to the descendants of Israel:"

verses.latin: Vos ipsi vidistis quæ fecerim Ægyptiis, quomodo portaverim vos super alas aquilarum, et assumpserim mihi.
verses.english: "You yourselves saw what I did to the Egyptians. You saw how I carried you safely, as if on the wings of eagles, and brought you directly to Myself."

verses.latin: Nunc igitur si audieritis vocem meam, et custodieritis pactum meum, eritis mihi in peculium de cunctis populis: mea est enim omnis terra:
verses.english: "Now then, if you truly listen to My voice and faithfully keep My covenant, you will become My own cherished possession from among all the nations. For the entire earth is Mine."

verses.latin: et vos eritis mihi in regnum sacerdotale, et gens sancta. Hæc sunt verba quæ loqueris filiis Israël.
verses.english: "And you will be for Me a kingdom of priests—a nation set apart by God to serve Him—and a holy people. These are the words you must speak to the people of Israel."

verses.latin: Venit Moyses: et convocatis majoribus natu populi, exposuit omnes sermones, quos mandaverat Dominus.
verses.english: So Moses returned and called together the elders of the people. He then explained to them all the words and instructions that the Lord had commanded him to share.

verses.latin: Responditque omnis populus simul: Omnia quæ locutus est Dominus, faciemus. Cumque retulisset Moyses verba populi ad Dominum,
verses.english: And all the people responded together, saying, "Everything that the Lord has spoken, we will do." Then Moses reported the people's words back to the Lord.

verses.latin: ait Dominus ad Moysen: Ecce ego veniam ad te in caligine nubis, ut audiat populus loquentem me tecum, et tibi credant in perpetuum. Dixit autem Moyses verba populi ad Dominum.
verses.english: The Lord said to Moses, "Listen! I am coming to you in a thick, dark cloud. This is so the people will hear Me speaking with you directly, and from that moment on, they will always believe in you." Moses had already delivered the people's words to the Lord.

verses.latin: Et dixit ei Dominus: Vade ad populum, et sanctifica illos hodie et cras: laventque vestimenta sua,
verses.english: Then the Lord told him, "Go to the people and prepare them to be set apart for Me today and tomorrow. They must wash their garments."

verses.latin: et sint parati in diem tertium: nam in die tertio descendet Dominus coram omni populo in montem Sinai.
verses.english: "And they must be ready by the third day, because on that third day, the Lord Himself will descend visibly upon Mount Sinai in the sight of all the people."

verses.latin: Et constitues terminos populo per circuitum, dicens: Cavete ne ascendatis in montem, nec tangatis fines illius: omnis qui tetigerit montem, morte morietur.
verses.english: "You must also set boundaries around the mountain for the people, and tell them: 'Be extremely careful not to go up on the mountain or even touch its edge. Anyone who touches the mountain will certainly be put to death.'"

verses.latin: Manus non tanget eum, sed lapidibus opprimetur, aut confodietur jaculis: sive jumentum fuerit, sive homo, non vivet. Cum cœperit tuba canere, tunc ascendent.
verses.english: "No human hand should touch such a one, but they must be stoned or shot through with arrows. Whether it is an animal or a person, it shall not live if it touches the mountain. Only when the ram's horn sounds a long blast, then they may ascend the mountain."

verses.latin: Descenditque Moyses de monte ad populum, et sanctificavit eos. Cumque lavissent vestimenta sua,
verses.english: So Moses descended from the mountain to the people and oversaw their purification rites. When they had washed their garments,

verses.latin: ait ad eos: Estote parati in diem tertium, et ne appropinquetis uxoribus vestris.
verses.english: he told them, "Be ready by the third day, and during this time, do not engage in marital relations."

verses.latin: Jamque tertio die, redeunte mane, et ecce cœperunt audiri tonitrua, ac micare fulgura, et nubes densissima operire montem, et clangor buccinae vehementior insonuit: timuitque populus, qui erat in castris.
verses.english: On the third day, as morning dawned, suddenly there were thunderings and flashes of lightning, and a very thick cloud covered Mount Sinai. A powerful blast from a ram's horn sounded, growing louder and louder. The people who were in the camp were filled with terror.

verses.latin: Et eduxit Moyses populum in occursum Dei de castris, et steterunt ad radices montis.
verses.english: Moses then led the people out of the camp to meet God, and they took their stand at the very foot of the mountain.

verses.latin: Totus autem mons Sinai fumabat: eo quod descendisset Dominus super eum in igne, et ascenderet fumus ex eo quasi de fornace, et totus mons vehementer terreretur.
verses.english: The entire Mount Sinai was smoking because the Lord had descended upon it in fire. Smoke billowed up from it like from a furnace, and the whole mountain was violently shaken.

verses.latin: Et sonitus buccinae paulatim crescebat in majus, et tendebatur in longum: Moyses loquebatur, et Deus respondebat ei.
verses.english: The sound of the ram's horn continued to grow louder and more prolonged. Moses spoke, and God answered him with a voice that could be heard.

verses.latin: Descenditque Dominus super montem Sinai, in ipso montis vertice, et vocavit Moysen in verticem ejus. Cumque ascendisset Moyses,
verses.english: The Lord descended upon the summit of Mount Sinai. From there, He called Moses to the very top of the mountain. When Moses had climbed up,

verses.latin: dixit ad eum: Descende, et contestare populum: ne forte velit transcendere terminos ad videndum Dominum, et pereat ex eis plurima multitudo.
