verses.english: God said to him, "Go down at once and strictly warn the people not to break through the boundaries to gaze upon the Lord, for if they do, many of them will surely perish."

verses.latin: Sacerdotes quoque qui appropinquant ad Dominum, sanctificentur: ne forte percatiat eos Dominus.
verses.english: "Even the priests who regularly approach the Lord must consecrate themselves, otherwise, the Lord might strike them down."

verses.latin: Dixitque Moyses ad Dominum: Non poterit populus ascendere in montem Sinai: tu enim testificatus es, et jussisti, dicens: Pone terminos circa montem, et sanctifica illum.
verses.english: Moses said to the Lord, "The people cannot possibly ascend Mount Sinai, because You Yourself warned us and strictly commanded: 'Set boundaries around the mountain and make it holy.'"

verses.latin: Et ait illi Dominus: Vade, descende: et ascendes tu, et Aaron tecum. Sacerdotes autem, et populus, ne transeant terminos, nec ascendant ad Dominum, ne forte occidat illos.
verses.english: The Lord said to him, "Go down! Then you may come up again, you and Aaron with you. But the priests and the people must not break through the boundaries and ascend to the Lord, lest He strike them dead."

verses.latin: Descenditque Moyses ad populum, et omnia narravit illis.
verses.english: So Moses went down to the people and told them all these things.

verses.latin: Locutusque est Dominus cunctos sermones hos: atque ait:
verses.english: And the Lord spoke all these commands, saying:

verses.latin: Ego sum Dominus Deus tuus, qui eduxi te de terra Aegypti, de domo servitutis.
verses.english: “I am the Lord, your God, who led you out of the land of Egypt, out of the place of your slavery.

verses.latin: Non habebis deos alienos coram me.
verses.english: You shall not have other gods besides Me.

verses.latin: Non facies tibi sculptile, neque omnem similitudinem quæ est in cælo desuper, et quæ in terra deorsum, et quæ in aquis sub terra.
verses.english: You shall not make for yourself any carved image, nor any likeness of anything that is in the sky above, or that is on the earth below, or that is in the waters beneath the earth.

verses.latin: Non adorabis ea, neque coles: Ego sum Dominus Deus tuus fortis, zelotes, reddens iniquitatem patrum in filios, in tertiam et quartam generationem eorum qui oderunt me:
verses.english: You shall not adore these false images, nor worship them; for I am the Lord, your God, a powerful and jealous God, who punishes the wickedness of the fathers on their children, even to the third and fourth generation of those who hate Me.

verses.latin: et faciens misericordiam in millia his qui diligunt me, et custodiunt præcepta mea.
verses.english: But I show mercy to thousands of those who love Me and keep My commandments.

verses.latin: Non assumes nomen Domini Dei tui in vanum: nec enim habebit insontem Dominus eum qui assumpserit nomen Domini Dei sui frustra.
verses.english: You shall not take the Name of the Lord, your God, in vain; for the Lord will not hold guiltless anyone who takes the Name of the Lord, his God, in vain.

verses.latin: Memento ut diem sabbati sanctifices.
verses.english: Remember to keep the Sabbath day holy.

verses.latin: Sex diebus operaberis, et facies omnia opera tua.
verses.english: For six days you shall labor and do all your work.

verses.latin: Septimo autem die Sabbatum Domini Dei tui est: non facies omne opus in eo, tu et filius tuus et filia tua, servus tuus et ancilla tua, et jumentum tuum, et advena qui est intra portas tuas.
verses.english: But the seventh day is the Sabbath of the Lord, your God; you shall not do any work on it, neither you, nor your son, nor your daughter, nor your male servant, nor your female servant, nor your animal, nor the stranger who is within your gates.

verses.latin: Sex enim diebus fecit Dominus cælum et terram, et mare, et omnia quæ in eis sunt, et requievit in die septimo: idcirco benedixit Dominus diei sabbati, et sanctificavit eum.
verses.english: For in six days the Lord made the universe, the earth, the sea, and all that is in them, and He rested on the seventh day; therefore, the Lord blessed the Sabbath day and made it holy.

verses.latin: Honora patrem tuum et matrem tuam, ut sis longævus super terram, quam Dominus Deus tuus dabit tibi.
verses.english: Honor your father and your mother, so that you may live long in the land that the Lord, your God, will give you.

verses.latin: Non occides.
verses.english: You shall not murder.

verses.latin: Non moechaberis.
verses.english: You shall not commit adultery.

verses.latin: Non furtum facies.
verses.english: You shall not steal.

verses.latin: Non loqueris contra proximum tuum falsum testimonium.
verses.english: You shall not bear false witness against your neighbor.

verses.latin: Non concupisces domum proximi tui: non desiderabis uxorem ejus, non servum, non ancillam, non bovem, non asinum, nec omnia quæ illius sunt.
verses.english: You shall not covet your neighbor’s house; you shall not desire his wife, nor his male servant, nor his female servant, nor his ox, nor his donkey, nor anything that belongs to him.”

verses.latin: Cunctus autem populus videbat voces, et lampades, et sonitum buccinæ, et montem fumantem: et perterriti ac timore concussi, steterunt procul,
verses.english: Now all the people saw the thundering voices, and the lightning flashes, and the sound of the trumpet, and the smoking mountain. And being terrified and shaken with fear, they stood afar off.

verses.latin: dicentes Moysi: Loquere tu nobis, et audiemus: non loquatur nobis Dominus, ne forte moriamur.
verses.english: They said to Moses, “You speak to us, and we will listen; but let not the Lord speak to us, lest we die.”

verses.latin: Et ait Moyses ad populum: Nolite timere: ut enim probaret vos Deus venit, et ut terror illius esset in vobis, et non peccaretis.
verses.english: And Moses said to the people, “Do not fear, for God has come to test you, and that His awe-inspiring presence might be in you, so that you do not sin.”

verses.latin: Stetitque populus procul, Moyses autem accessit ad caliginem in qua erat Deus.
verses.english: So the people stood afar off, but Moses approached the thick darkness where God was.

verses.latin: Dixitque Dominus ad Moysen: Hæc dices filiis Israël: Vos vidistis quod de cælo locutus sum vobis.
verses.english: Then the Lord said to Moses, “This is what you shall say to the children of Israel: ‘You yourselves have seen that I spoke to you from the sky.’

verses.latin: Non facietis mecum deos argenteos, et deos aureos non facietis vobis.
verses.english: You shall not make gods of silver alongside Me, nor shall you make gods of gold for yourselves.

verses.latin: Altare de terra facietis mihi, et offeretis super eo holocausta et pacifica vestra, oves vestras et boves in omni loco in quo memoria fuerit nominis mei: veniam ad te, et benedicam tibi.
verses.english: You shall make an altar of earth for Me, and on it you shall offer your burnt offerings and your peace offerings, your sheep and your oxen. In every place where I cause My Name to be remembered, I will come to you and bless you.

verses.latin: Si quid autem altare de lapidibus feceris mihi, non ædificabis illud de sectis et politis lapidibus: si enim tullum mallei erexeris, polluisses illud.
verses.english: But if you make an altar of stones for Me, you shall not build it of cut and polished stones; for if you lift up a tool upon it, you will have defiled it.

verses.latin: Nec ascendet per gradus ad altare meum, ne reveletur turpitudo tua.
verses.english: Nor shall you go up by steps to My altar, so that your nakedness may not be exposed upon it.”

verses.latin: Haec sunt judicia quae propones eis.
verses.english: These are the legal decrees that you must present to the people of Israel.

verses.latin: Si emeris servum Hebraeum, sex annis serviet tibi: in septimo egredietur liber gratis.
verses.english: If you purchase a Hebrew servant, he shall serve you for six years. In the seventh year, he shall leave as a free man without having to pay anything.

verses.latin: Cum quali intraverit, cum tali exiet: si habens uxorem intraverit, cum uxore sua exibit.
verses.english: He shall leave with the same status he had when he entered service. If he entered with a wife, then his wife shall leave with him.

verses.latin: Si vero dominus dederit illi uxorem, et pepererit filios et filias: mulier et liberi ejus erunt domini sui: ipse vero exibit solus.
verses.english: But if his master gives him a wife, and she bears him sons or daughters, then the wife and her children shall remain the master's property, and the man himself shall leave alone.

verses.latin: Si spondea dicens servus, Non egrediar liber, quia diligo dominum meum et uxorem ac liberos:
verses.english: But if the servant should plainly declare, saying: 'I do not wish to leave as a free man, because I love my master, my wife, and my children; I want to remain with them.'

verses.latin: adducet eum dominus suus ad Deos, et statuet ad postem et ostium: et terebrabit aurem ejus subula, et erit ei servus in sempiternum.
verses.english: Then his master shall bring him before the judges, and he shall bring him to a door or doorpost. The master shall then pierce his ear with an awl, and he shall remain his servant for the rest of his life.

verses.latin: Si quis vendiderit filiam suam in ancillam, non egredietur sicut ancillae solent.
verses.english: If a man sells his daughter to be a female servant, she shall not leave her service as other female servants do.

verses.latin: Si displicuerit domino suo, cui tradita fuerat, dabit ei facultatem ut redimi possit: et ad alienam gentem vendendi eam non habebit potestatem, si spreverit eam.
verses.english: If she does not please her master, to whom she was given, he must allow her to be redeemed by her family. He does not have the power to sell her to a foreign people if he has rejected her.

verses.latin: Sin autem filio suo desponderit eam, de more filiarum faciet illi.
verses.english: However, if he betroths her to his own son, then he must treat her with the same rights and dignity as a natural daughter.

verses.latin: Et si aliam duxerit uxorem, alimenta, et vestes, et pretium pudicitiae non negabit.
verses.english: And if he takes another wife, he shall not diminish her food, her clothing, nor her conjugal rights.

verses.latin: Si haec tria non fecerit, egredietur gratis absque pecunia.
verses.english: If he does not provide her with these three things, then she shall leave as a free woman, without having to pay any money.

verses.latin: Qui percusserit hominem et mortuus fuerit, morte moriatur.
verses.english: Whoever strikes a man and causes his death, he shall surely be put to death.

verses.latin: Qui autem non est insidiatus, sed Deus illi tradidit in manus: constituam tibi locum ad quem fugiat.
verses.english: But if a man did not intentionally plot to kill, and God allowed the person to die by his hand accidentally, then I will designate a place for you where he may flee for safety.

verses.latin: Si quis per industriam occiderit proximum suum, et per insidias: ab altari meo evelles eum, ut moriatur.
verses.english: But if someone intentionally and treacherously murders his neighbor, you shall take him away from My altar, and he shall be put to death.

verses.latin: Qui percusserit patrem suum aut matrem, morte moriatur.
verses.english: Whoever strikes his father or his mother shall surely be put to death.

verses.latin: Qui furatus fuerit hominem et vendiderit, convictusque fuerit, morte moriatur.
verses.english: Whoever kidnaps a person and sells him, and is proven guilty, shall surely be put to death.

verses.latin: Qui maledixerit patri suo vel matri, morte moriatur.
verses.english: Whoever curses his father or his mother shall surely be put to death.

verses.latin: Si rixati fuerint viri, et percusserit alter proximum suum lapide vel pugno, et ille mortuus non fuerit, sed jacuerit in lecto:
verses.english: If men quarrel and one strikes his neighbor with a stone or with his fist, and the man does not die but is confined to his bed,

verses.latin: si surrexerit et ambulaverit foras super baculum suum, innocens erit qui percusserit, hoc tamen solvet damna, et curationes impenderit.
verses.english: if the injured man then rises and walks about outside, even if with a staff, the man who struck him shall not be guilty of murder. However, the assailant must pay for the injured man’s lost wages and cover all medical expenses for his full recovery.

verses.latin: Si quis percusserit servum suum vel ancillam virga, et mortui fuerint sub manibus ejus, criminis reus erit.
verses.english: If a man strikes his male or female servant with a rod, and the servant dies while still under his hand, the master shall be guilty of a crime.

verses.latin: Sin autem uno vel duobus diebus supervixerit, non subjacebit poenae, quia pecunia illius est.
verses.english: However, if the servant survives for a day or two, the master shall not be punished for murder, as the servant is considered his property, and the loss of his property is a sufficient consequence for him.

verses.latin: Si rixati fuerint viri, et percusserit quis mulierem praegnantem, et abortivum quidem fecerit, sed ipsa vixerit: subjacebit damno quantum maritus mulieris expetierit, et arbitri judicaverint.
verses.english: If men quarrel and one strikes a pregnant woman, causing her to miscarry, but the woman herself lives, then the offender shall surely be fined. The amount of the fine shall be determined by what the woman's husband demands, and what the judges determine is just.

verses.latin: Sin autem et mortem ejus fuerit consecutum, reddet animam pro anima:
verses.english: But if her death also results from the injury, then it shall be 'a life for a life'—the offender shall be put to death.

verses.latin: oculum pro oculo, dentem pro dente, manum pro manu, pedem pro pede,
verses.english: An eye for an eye, a tooth for a tooth, a hand for a hand, a foot for a foot,

verses.latin: adustionem pro adustione, vulnus pro vulnere, livorem pro livore.
verses.english: a burn for a burn, a wound for a wound, a bruise for a bruise.

verses.latin: Si quis percusserit oculum servi sui aut ancillae, et luscos fecerit, dimittet eos liberos pro oculo quem eruit.
verses.english: If a man strikes the eye of his male or female servant and permanently damages it, he must set the servant free in compensation for the eye he destroyed.

verses.latin: Dentem quoque si excusserit servo vel ancillae suae, similiter eos liberos dimittet.
verses.english: And if he knocks out a tooth of his male or female servant, he shall likewise set them free.

verses.latin: Si bos cornibus interfecerit virum aut mulierem, lapidibus obruetur: et non comedentur carnes ejus: dominus vero bovis innocens erit.
verses.english: If an ox gores a man or a woman to death, the ox shall be stoned to death, and its meat must not be eaten. However, the owner of the ox shall be considered innocent of the death, provided he was unaware of the ox's aggressive nature.

verses.latin: Quod si bos cornupeta fuerit jam heri et nudius tertius, et contestatus fuerit dominus ejus, nec recluserit eum, et occiderit virum aut mulierem: et ipse lapidibus occidetur, et dominum ejus interficient.
verses.english: But if the ox was known to be aggressive and prone to goring in the past, and its owner was warned about it yet failed to keep it securely confined, and it then kills a man or a woman, then both the ox shall be stoned to death and its owner shall also be put to death.

verses.latin: Quod si pretium fuerit ei impositum, dabit pro anima sua quicquid fuerit postulaverit.
verses.english: However, if a ransom is imposed upon him instead of the death penalty, he shall pay whatever amount is demanded as compensation for his life.

verses.latin: Sive filium sive filiam occiderit, similiter judicabitur.
verses.english: Whether the ox kills a son or a daughter, the owner shall be judged according to these same laws.

verses.latin: Si servum vel ancillam interfecerit, triginta siclis argenti dabit domino servi, et ipse bos lapidibus occidetur.
verses.english: If the ox kills a male or female servant, the owner must pay thirty shekels of silver to the servant's master, and the ox itself shall be stoned to death.

verses.latin: Si quis aperuerit cisternam, et foderit foveam, et non operuerit eam, cecideritque bos vel asinus in eam:
verses.english: If a man opens a pit, or digs a pit and does not cover it, and an ox or a donkey falls into it,

verses.latin: dominus foveae reddet pecuniam jumentorum: quod autem mortuum est, ipsius erit.
verses.english: the owner of the pit shall fully compensate the animal's owner with money. The dead animal itself shall then belong to the owner of the pit.

verses.latin: Si bos alienus bovem alterius laeserit, et ille mortuus fuerit: vendent bovem viventem, et divident pretium, et cadaver mortui divident.
verses.english: If one man's ox gores another man's ox so that it dies, then they shall sell the living ox and divide the money from the sale equally. They shall also divide the carcass of the dead ox.

verses.latin: Sin autem scierit bos cornupeta esse ab heri et nudius tertius, et dominus illius non custodierit eum: reddet bovem pro bove, et quod mortuum est, ipsum habebit.
verses.english: But if it was known that the ox was accustomed to goring in the past, and its owner did not keep it confined, then he must give an ox in full payment for the other ox. The dead ox shall then belong to the negligent owner.

verses.latin: Si quis furatus fuerit bovem aut ovem, et occiderit vel vendiderit: quinque boves pro uno bove, et quatuor oves pro una ove restituet.
verses.english: If someone steals an ox or a sheep, and then either slaughters it or sells it, he shall repay five oxen for the one ox, and four sheep for the one sheep. This law ensures a high restitution for depriving the owner of their property permanently.

verses.latin: Si effringens fur domum, sive perfodiens fuerit inventus, et accepto vulnere mortuus fuerit: qui eum occidit non erit reus sanguinis.
verses.english: If a thief is caught breaking into a house—by tunneling through a wall or breaking in—and is struck and dies, the one who killed him will not be held guilty for his death. This law permits self-defense against burglars at night.

verses.latin: Quod si orto jam sole hoc fecerit, reus erit sanguinis: et ipse restituet. Si vero nihil habuerit, vendetur pro furtivo.
verses.english: But if this happens after sunrise, the homeowner will be guilty for the death. If the thief survives, he must make restitution. If he has nothing, he shall be sold into servitude to cover the cost of his theft. This distinction between night and day reflects the assumption that at night, one cannot discern the thief's intent.

verses.latin: Si inventum fuerit apud eum furtum vivens, sive bos, sive asinus, sive ovis: duplum restituet.
verses.english: If the stolen animal—whether an ox, a donkey, or a sheep—is found alive in the thief's possession, he must restore double its value to the owner. This lesser penalty applies when the stolen item can be returned.

verses.latin: Si quis depastus fuerit agrum vel vineam, et dimiserit jumentum suum ut depascatur aliena: quidquid optimum habuerit in agro suo, et in vinea, restituet.
verses.english: If someone lets his livestock graze in a field or vineyard belonging to another, causing damage, he must make restitution with the best produce from his own field and vineyard. This ensures that the compensation is full and fair.

verses.latin: Si egressus ignis invenerit spinas, et comprehenderit segetes plenas, aut in acervos congregatas, sive agrum: restituet damnum qui ignem succenderit.
verses.english: If a fire starts and spreads to thorny bushes, then catches a field of grain—whether it is standing or gathered in piles—or an entire field, the person who started the fire must repay the damage. This law holds one responsible for negligence with fire.

verses.latin: Si quis commendaverit amico pecuniam aut vas, et illud furto ablatum fuerit ab eo qui acceperat: si deprehensus fuerit fur, duplum restituet.
verses.english: If someone gives money or an item to a friend for safekeeping, and it is stolen from the one who received it: if the thief is caught, he must restore double its value. This protects entrusted property.

verses.latin: Si latet fur, dominus domus exhibebitur ad Deos, et jurabit quod non fecerit furtum.
verses.english: If the thief is not found, the owner of the house where the item was stolen from safekeeping must approach the judges—who represent God's justice—and swear an oath that he did not take the item himself. This places the matter under divine judgment.

verses.latin: Pro omni fraude tam in bove, quam in asino, ove, vestimento, et quocumque damno: si quis non habuerit quid furatus sit, duplum restituet proximo suo.
verses.english: For every case of fraud—whether it concerns an ox, a donkey, a sheep, clothing, or any other loss—if a person is suspected but cannot prove he did not steal, he shall repay double to his neighbor. This covers various types of misappropriation.

verses.latin: Si quis commendaverit proximo suo asinum, bovem, ovem, et omne jumentum ad custodiam, et mortuum fuerit, aut debilitatum, vel captum, nullusque hoc viderit:
verses.english: If someone entrusts to his neighbor a donkey, an ox, a sheep, or any other animal for safekeeping, and it dies, is injured, or is carried off, and no one witnesses what happened:

verses.latin: jusjurandum erit in medio utriusque, quod non extenderit manum ad rem proximi sui: suscipietque dominus quod juratum fuerit, et ille reddere non cogetur.
verses.english: An oath before God shall settle the matter between them both, that the keeper did not lay a hand on his neighbor's property. The owner must accept this sworn statement, and the keeper will not be compelled to pay restitution. This relies on the keeper's integrity before God.

verses.latin: Quod si furto ablatum fuerit, restituet damnum domino.
verses.english: But if the animal was stolen from the keeper, he must pay restitution for the loss to the owner. This indicates a higher level of responsibility for preventing theft.

verses.latin: Si comestum fuerit a bestia, afferet quod occisum est in testimonium, et damnum non restituet.
verses.english: If the animal was torn apart by a wild beast, the keeper must bring the remains as proof, and he will not have to pay restitution for the loss. This acknowledges uncontrollable circumstances.

verses.latin: Si quis mutuatum acceperit ab amico, et debilitatum fuerit, aut mortuum, domino non praesente, restituere cogetur.
verses.english: If someone borrows an animal from a friend, and it is injured or dies while the owner is not present, the borrower must certainly repay its value. This is because the borrower is solely responsible for its care.

verses.latin: Sin autem praesente domino fuerit, non restituet. Maxime si conductum venerat, merces erit pro damno.
verses.english: But if the owner was present when the injury or death occurred, the borrower is not compelled to repay. This applies especially if the animal was hired out; the rental fee itself covers the risk of loss in the presence of the owner.

verses.latin: Si seduxerit quis virginem nondum desponsatam, et dormierit cum ea: dotabit eam, et habebit uxorem.
verses.english: If someone seduces a virgin who is not yet promised to another man, and has relations with her, he must pay the marriage price for her and take her as his wife. This law protects the virgin's honor and ensures her future.

verses.latin: Si pater virginis dare noluerit, pecuniam dabit juxta morem dotis et puellarum.
verses.english: If the virgin's father utterly refuses to give her to him, the seducer must still pay money equal to the customary marriage price for virgins. This serves as a penalty for his actions, even without marriage.

verses.latin: Maleficos non patieris vivere.
verses.english: You shall not allow sorcerers and witches to live. This command reflects God's strong condemnation of magic and demonic practices.

verses.latin: Omnis qui coierit cum jumento, morte moriatur.
verses.english: Anyone who has sexual relations with an animal must surely be put to death. This is an abomination against natural law and purity.

verses.latin: Qui immolat diis, nisi Domino soli, interficietur.
verses.english: Whoever sacrifices to any god except the Lord God alone shall be utterly destroyed—put to death. This is a primary commandment against idolatry.

verses.latin: Advenam non contristabis, neque affliges eum: quia et ipsi advenae fuistis in terra Ægypti.
verses.english: You shall not distress a foreigner, nor oppress him, because you yourselves were once foreigners in the land of Egypt. This command calls for empathy and justice, remembering their own past experience.

verses.latin: Viduae et pupillo non nocebitis.
verses.english: You shall not harm widows or orphans. These vulnerable groups are under God's special protection.

verses.latin: Si laeseritis eos, et clamaverint ad me, audiam clamorem eorum:
verses.english: If you harm them, and they cry out to me, I will surely hear their cry. This warns of God's immediate response to injustice against the vulnerable.

verses.latin: et irascetur furor meus, percutiamque vos gladio, et erunt uxores vestrae viduae, et filii vestri pupilli.
verses.english: And my wrath will be kindled, and I will strike you down with the sword, so your own wives will become widows and your children orphans. This is a severe warning of reciprocal divine judgment.

verses.latin: Si pecuniam mutuam dederis populo meo pauperi, qui tecum moratur, non urgues eum quasi exactor, nec usuris opprimes.
verses.english: If you lend money to my people, to the poor among you, you shall not act like a moneylender towards them. You shall not burden them with interest. This command prohibits usury among Israelites, especially to the poor.

verses.latin: Si pignus tuleris vestimentum proximi tui, ante solis occasum restitues illi.
verses.english: If you take your neighbor's outer garment as a pledge for a loan, you must return it to him before the sun sets. This is because the poor may need it for warmth during the night.

verses.latin: Ipsum est enim indumentum solum quo operitur, et vestimentum carnis ejus, nec habet aliud quo dormiat: si clamaverit ad me, ego exaudiam, quia misericors sum.
verses.english: For it is his only covering, the very clothing for his body; he has nothing else to sleep in. If he cries out to me, I will hear him, because I am merciful. God hears the cries of the poor and oppressed.

verses.latin: Diis non detrahes, et principi populi tui non maledices.
verses.english: You shall not revile the judges—those who represent God's authority—nor curse the ruler of your people. This command teaches respect for all authority, both divine and civil.

verses.latin: Decimas tuas et primitias tuas non tardabis reddere: primogenitum filiorum tuorum dabis mihi.
verses.english: You shall not delay in offering your tithes and your first fruits. The firstborn of your sons you shall give to Me. This refers to the dedication of the firstborn male to God, later redeemed.

verses.latin: De bobus quoque et ovibus similiter facies: septem diebus erit cum matre sua, octavo die reddes mihi.
verses.english: You shall do the same with your oxen and your sheep: for seven days, an offspring shall be with its mother, but on the eighth day, you shall give it to Me. This is about dedicating the firstborn animals.

verses.latin: Viri sancti eritis mihi: carnem quae a bestiis fuerit jacta, non comedetis, sed projicietis canibus.
verses.english: You shall be holy people to Me. You must not eat any meat that has been torn by wild beasts in the field, but you shall throw it to the dogs. This preserves ritual purity and distinction.

verses.latin: Non suscipies vocem mendacii: nec junges manum tuam ut proferas testimonium falsum.
verses.english: You shall not accept a false report. Nor shall you join hands with a wicked person to give dishonest testimony.

verses.latin: Non sequeris turbam ad malum: nec in judicio plurimorum acquiesces sententiae, ut a vero devies.
verses.english: You shall not follow the crowd to do evil. Nor shall you in a lawsuit agree with the opinion of the many, if their judgment would cause you to deviate from the truth.

verses.latin: Pauperem non misereberis in judicio.
verses.english: You shall not show partiality to a poor person in a lawsuit.

verses.latin: Si obviaveris bovi inimici tui aut asino erranti, reduc illud ad eum.
verses.english: If you encounter the ox or donkey of your enemy straying, you must bring it back to him.

verses.latin: Si videris asinum odientis te jacere sub onere, non pertransibis, sed sublevabis cum eo.
verses.english: If you see the donkey of someone who hates you lying under its burden, you shall not just pass by it, but you must help the person to lift it up.

verses.latin: Non declinabis judicium pauperis in lite sua.
verses.english: You shall not pervert justice against a poor person in their lawsuit.

verses.latin: Mendacium fugies. Innocentem et justum non occides: quia aversor impium.
verses.english: You shall flee from falsehood. You shall not kill an innocent and righteous person, for I abhor the wicked.

verses.latin: Nec accipies munera, quae excaecant etiam prudentes, et subvertunt verba justorum.
verses.english: Nor shall you accept bribes, which blind even the wise and distort the words of the righteous.

verses.latin: Advenam non affliges: scitis enim animas advenarum, quia et ipsi advenae fuistis in terra Aegypti.
verses.english: You shall not oppress a foreigner, for you know the hearts of foreigners, because you yourselves were foreigners in the land of Egypt.

verses.latin: Sex annis seras terram tuam, et congregabis segetes ejus.
verses.english: For six years you shall sow your land and gather its harvest.

verses.latin: Septimo autem anno dimittes eam, et requiescere facies: ut comedant pauperes populi tui, et quidquid reliquum fuerit, depascant bestiae regionis tuae: ita facies in vinea et oliveto tuo.
verses.english: But in the seventh year, you shall let the land rest and lie fallow. This is so the poor among your people may eat from it, and whatever they leave, the wild animals of your region may devour. You shall do the same with your vineyard and your olive grove.

verses.latin: Sex diebus operaberis: septimo die cessabis, ut requiescat bos et asinus tuus, et refrigeretur filius ancillae tuae cum advena.
verses.english: For six days you shall do your work, but on the seventh day you shall rest. This is so your ox and your donkey may rest, and the son of your female servant, along with the foreigner, may be refreshed.

verses.latin: Omnia quae dixi vobis, custodite. Et per nomen deorum alienorum non jurabitis, neque audietur ex ore vestro.
verses.english: All that I have told you, you shall observe carefully. You shall not swear by the names of other gods, nor shall their names be heard from your mouth.

verses.latin: Tribus vicibus in anno solemnitatem mihi facietis.
verses.english: Three times a year you shall keep a feast for Me.

verses.latin: Solemnitatem azymorum custodies. Septem diebus non comedes fermentum, sicut praecepi tibi in tempore mensis novarum, quando egressus es de Aegypto: non apparebis in conspectu meo vacuus.
verses.english: You shall observe the Feast of Unleavened Bread. For seven days you shall eat no leavened bread, just as I commanded you at the appointed time in the month of Abib (which means 'new sprouts'), when you came out of Egypt. You shall not appear before Me empty-handed.

verses.latin: Et solemnitatem segetis primitiarum operis tui, quaecumque serueris in agro: et solemnitatem in exitu anni, quando congregaveris omnes fruges tuas de agro.
verses.english: And you shall observe the Feast of Harvest, the firstfruits of your labor, of what you have sown in the field. And you shall observe the Feast of Ingathering at the end of the year, when you have gathered all your produce from the field.

verses.latin: Tribus vicibus in anno apparebit omne masculinum tuum coram Domino Deo tuo.
verses.english: Three times a year, all your males shall appear before the Lord, your God.

verses.latin: Non immolabis super fermento sanguinem hostiae meae, nec remanebit de victima solemnitatis meae in crastinum.
verses.english: You shall not offer the blood of My sacrifice with leavened bread, nor shall any part of the sacrifice of My feast remain until the morning.

verses.latin: Primitias frugum terrae tuae deferes in domum Domini Dei tui. Non coques haedum in lacte matris suae.
verses.english: You shall bring the best of the firstfruits of your land into the house of the Lord, your God. You shall not boil a young goat in its mother's milk.

verses.latin: Ecce ego mittam angelum meum, qui praecedat te, et custodiat in via, et introducat in locum quem paravi.
verses.english: Behold, I am sending My angel before you to guard you on the way and to bring you into the place which I have prepared.

verses.latin: Observa eum, et audi vocem ejus, nec contemnas: quia non dimittet cum peccaveris, et est nomen meum in illo.
verses.english: Be attentive to him and listen to his voice; do not rebel against him. For he will not forgive your transgressions, because My Name is in him.

verses.latin: Quod si audieris vocem ejus, et feceris omnia quae loquor tibi: inimicus ero inimicis tuis, et affligam affligentes te.
verses.english: But if you diligently listen to his voice and do all that I speak to you through him, then I will be an enemy to your enemies and afflict those who afflict you.

verses.latin: Praecedetque te angelus meus, et introducet te ad Amorrhæum, et Hethæum, et Pherezæum, Chananaeumque, et Hevæum, et Jebusæum, quos ego contero.
verses.english: My angel will go before you and bring you to the Amorites, and the Hittites, and the Perizzites, and the Canaanites, and the Hivites, and the Jebusites, whom I will utterly destroy.

verses.latin: Non adorabis deos eorum, nec coles eos: non facies opera eorum, sed suffringes statuas eorum, et confringes aras illorum.
verses.english: You shall not worship their gods, nor serve them. You shall not imitate their practices, but you shall utterly break down their sacred pillars and smash their altars.

verses.latin: Et servietis Domino Deo vestro, ut benedicam panibus tuis et aquis, et auferam languorem a medio tui.
verses.english: And you shall serve the Lord, your God, so that I may bless your bread and your water, and remove sickness from your midst.

verses.latin: Non erit abortiva, nec sterilis in terra tua: numerum dierum tuorum implebo.
verses.english: There shall be no woman who miscarries or is barren in your land. I will fulfill the number of your days.

verses.latin: Terrorem meum mittam in praecursum tuum, et conturbabo omnem populum ad quem ingredieris: cunctosque inimicos tuos a te fugere faciam.
verses.english: I will send My terror before you and throw into confusion every people to whom you come. I will make all your enemies flee from you.

verses.latin: Mittens hostias prius, quae fugabunt Hevæum, et Chananaeum, et Hethæum, antequam ingrediaris.
verses.english: I will send My forces before you, which will drive out the Hivites, the Canaanites, and the Hittites, before you enter the land.

verses.latin: Non ejiciam eos in anno uno, ne terra in solitudinem redigatur, et crescant contra te bestiae.
verses.english: I will not drive them out from before you in a single year, lest the land become desolate and the wild animals multiply against you.

verses.latin: Paulatim expellam illos de conspectu tuo, donec augearis, et possideas terram.
verses.english: Little by little I will drive them out from before you, until you become numerous and take possession of the land.

verses.latin: Ponamque terminos tuos a mari Rubro usque ad mare Palæstinorum, et a deserto usque ad flumen: tradam enim in manibus vestris habitatores terræ, et ejiciam illos de conspectu vestro.
verses.english: And I will set your boundaries from the Red Sea to the Sea of the Philistines, and from the desert to the River (meaning the Euphrates). For I will deliver the inhabitants of the land into your hands, and I will drive them out from before you.

verses.latin: Non inibis fœdus cum eis, nec cum diis eorum.
verses.english: You shall make no covenant with them, nor with their gods.

verses.latin: Non habitabunt in terra tua, ne forte peccare te faciant in me, si servieris diis eorum: quod tibi erit in scandalum.
verses.english: They shall not dwell in your land, lest they make you sin against Me by serving their gods, which would become a snare to you.

verses.latin: Dixit quoque ad Moysen: Ascende ad Dominum, tu, et Aaron, Nadab, et Abiu, et septuaginta senes ex Israel: et adorabitis procul.
verses.english: God also said to Moses: "Come up to the Lord, you, and Aaron, Nadab, and Abihu, and seventy elders from Israel, and you all shall worship from a distance (as a sign of reverence for My holy presence)."

verses.latin: Solusque Moyses ascendet ad Dominum: et illi non appropinquabunt, nec populus ascendet cum eo.
verses.english: Moses alone will ascend closer to the Lord. The others (Aaron, Nadab, Abihu, and the seventy elders) will not come near Him, and the people will not ascend with Moses at all (maintaining a clear distinction in access to God's presence).

verses.latin: Venit ergo Moyses et narravit plebi omnia verba Domini, atque judicia: responditque omnis populus una voce: Omnia verba Domini, quæ locutus est, faciemus.
verses.english: So Moses came down and told the people all the words (commands and laws) of the Lord, as well as His judgments. And all the people responded with one voice, proclaiming: "All the words which the Lord has spoken, we will do (confirming their acceptance of the covenant)."

verses.latin: Scripsit autem Moyses universos sermones Domini: et surgens mane, ædificavit altare sub monte, et duodecim titulos per duodecim tribus Israel.
verses.english: Then Moses wrote down all the words of the Lord (the terms of the covenant). And rising early in the morning, he built an altar at the foot of the mountain, and he set up twelve stone pillars, each one representing one of the twelve tribes of Israel (symbolizing their unified presence before God).

verses.latin: Misitque juvenes ex filiis Israel, et obtulerunt holocausta, immolaveruntque victimas pacificas Domino, vitulos.
verses.english: He then sent young men from among the children of Israel, and they offered burnt offerings (sacrifices entirely consumed by fire, symbolizing complete dedication to God). They also sacrificed calves as peace offerings (sacrifices for fellowship and communion with God and each other) to the Lord.

verses.latin: Tulit itaque Moyses dimidiam partem sanguinis, et misit in crateras: partem autem dimidiam fudit super altare.
verses.english: So Moses took half of the blood from these sacrifices and put it into basins. But the other half he poured over the altar (signifying atonement and consecration to God).

verses.latin: Et assumens volumen fœderis, legit audiente populo: qui dixerunt: Omnia quæ locutus est Dominus, faciemus, et erimus obedientes.
verses.english: Then, taking the book of the covenant (the written laws and stipulations), he read it aloud for the people to hear. And they responded, saying: "Everything that the Lord has spoken, we will do, and we will be obedient (reaffirming their solemn commitment)."

verses.latin: Ille vero sumpto sanguine aspersit super populum, et ait: Hic est sanguis fœderis, quod pepigit Dominus vobiscum super cunctis sermonibus his.
verses.english: Then Moses took the remaining blood and sprinkled it on the people. And he declared: "This is the blood of the covenant (the solemn agreement sealed by life itself) which the Lord has made with you concerning all these words (His laws and promises)."

verses.latin: Ascenderunt ergo Moyses et Aaron, Nadab et Abiu, et septuaginta de senioribus Israel:
verses.english: So Moses and Aaron, Nadab and Abihu, and seventy of the elders of Israel (the same group mentioned in verse 1, now granted a closer approach) went up the mountain.

verses.latin: Et viderunt Deum Israel: et sub pedibus ejus quasi opus lapidis sapphirini, et quasi cælum cum serenum est.
verses.english: And they saw a manifestation of the God of Israel. Under His feet was something like a pavement made of sapphire stone, appearing as clear and blue as the sky when it is serene (a vision of divine glory, not God's essence).

verses.latin: Nec super his, qui procul viderant Deum, misit manum suam: videruntque Deum, et comederunt ac biberunt.
verses.english: And God did not lay His hand in judgment upon these leaders who had seen this manifestation of Him, even though it was a partial viewing of the Almighty. So they saw God (in His revealed glory), and they ate and drank (participating in a covenant meal in His presence, an act of great favor).

verses.latin: Dixitque Dominus ad Moysen: Ascende ad me in montem, et esto ibi: et dabo tibi tabulas lapideas, et legem, ac mandata quæ scripsi, ut doceas eos.
verses.english: Then the Lord said to Moses: "Come up to Me on the mountain and stay there (for an extended period). And I will give you tablets of stone (the Decalogue, written by My own hand), containing the Law and the commandments which I have written, so that you may teach them to the people of Israel."

verses.latin: Surrexerunt Moyses et Josue minister ejus: et ascendens Moyses in montem Dei,
verses.english: So Moses rose, along with Joshua his assistant (who would accompany him part-way up the mountain). And Moses began ascending the mountain of God (Mount Sinai, where God's presence was revealed).

verses.latin: Senioribus ait: Expectate hic donec revertamur ad vos. Habebitis Aaron et Hur vobiscum: si quid natus fuerit quæstionis, referetis ad eos.
verses.english: He said to the elders (who remained at the foot of the mountain): "Wait here for us until we return to you. You will have Aaron and Hur with you; if any question or dispute arises among you, you shall refer it to them (as your temporary leaders)."

verses.latin: Cumque ascendisset Moyses, operuit nubes montem:
verses.english: As Moses ascended higher, a thick cloud covered the mountain (a visible sign of God's dwelling there and His hidden glory).

verses.latin: Et habitavit gloria Domini super Sinai, tegens illum nubes sex diebus: septimo die vocavit Moysen de medio caliginis.
verses.english: And the glory of the Lord (His magnificent presence) dwelt (rested) upon Mount Sinai, with the cloud covering it for six days. On the seventh day, He called Moses from the midst of the thick darkness (the innermost part of the cloud where God communed directly with him).

verses.latin: Erat autem species gloriæ Domini quasi ignis ardens super verticem montis in conspectu filiorum Israel.
verses.english: Now the appearance of the glory of the Lord, as visible to the children of Israel below, was like a blazing fire on the very top of the mountain (a fearsome and awe-inspiring sight).

verses.latin: Et ingressus Moyses medium nebulæ, ascendit in montem: fuitque ibi quadraginta diebus, et quadraginta noctibus.
verses.english: So Moses entered the midst of the cloud and ascended further into the mountain. And he remained there for forty days and forty nights (a profound period of fasting, communion, and divine instruction).

verses.latin: Locutusque est Dominus ad Moysen, dicens:
verses.english: The Lord spoke to Moses again (while he was on the mountain), saying:

verses.latin: Dic filiis Israel ut afferant mihi primitias: ab omni homine qui offert ultroneus, accipietis eas.
verses.english: "Tell the children of Israel to bring Me offerings. From every person whose heart moves him to offer willingly (without compulsion), you shall accept these offerings for My sanctuary."

verses.latin: Hæc sunt autem quæ accipere debetis: aurum, et argentum, et æs,
verses.english: "Now these are the materials you are to receive (as voluntary offerings): gold, and silver, and bronze (or copper, as a strong and useful metal)."

verses.latin: hyacinthum, et purpuram, et coccum bis tinctum, et byssum, et pilos caprarum,
verses.english: "And blue fabric, and purple fabric, and scarlet fabric (dyed twice for a rich, vibrant color). Also, fine linen, and goats' hair (for durable textiles)."

verses.latin: et pelles arietum rubricatas, et pelles janthinas, et ligna setim,
verses.english: "And rams' skins dyed red, and fine leather (likely badger skins or another durable, colorful leather suitable for covering). And acacia wood (a strong, rot-resistant wood found in the desert regions)."

verses.latin: oleum ad luminaria concinnanda, aromata in unguenta, et thymiama boni odoris,
verses.english: "Oil for the lamps (to keep the sanctuary illuminated). Spices for the anointing oil (used to consecrate persons and objects) and fragrant incense (for worship, creating a sweet aroma before God)."

verses.latin: lapides onychinos, et gemmas ad ornanda superhumerale, et rationale.
verses.english: "Onyx stones, and other precious stones for the ephod (a sacred vestment worn on the shoulders by the High Priest) and the breastplate (a ceremonial pouch worn over the chest, containing the Urim and Thummim for divine guidance)."

verses.latin: Facientque mihi sanctuarium, et habitabo in medio eorum:
verses.english: "And they shall make Me a sanctuary (a holy, set-apart dwelling place). The purpose of this is so that I may dwell (make My presence known) among them (as their God and guide)."

verses.latin: Juxta omnem similitudinem tabernaculi, quod ostendam tibi, et omnium vasorum in cultum ejus: sic facietis.
verses.english: "You are to make it according to every exact pattern of the tabernacle (this portable dwelling of God) which I will show you, and according to the pattern of all its vessels (the sacred furnishings) for its service. This is precisely how you shall make it (emphasizing divine origin and specific design)."

verses.latin: Facient et arcam de lignis setim: longitudinis habentem duos cubitos et dimidium, et latitudinis cubitum unum et dimidium, et altitudinis cubitum unum et dimidium.
verses.english: "They shall also make an ark (a sacred chest, the most important object in the Tabernacle) of acacia wood. Its length shall be two and a half cubits (approximately 45 inches). Its width shall be one and a half cubits (approximately 27 inches). And its height shall also be one and a half cubits (approximately 27 inches)."

verses.latin: Et deaurabis eam auro mundissimo intus et foris: faciesque in superna ejus, coronam auream per circuitum:
verses.english: "You shall overlay it (the ark) with pure gold, both inside and out. And you shall make a gold molding (a decorative rim, often called a 'crown') around its upper edge (adding to its beauty and distinction)."

verses.latin: et quatuor circulos aureos, quos pones per singula latera arcæ. Præbebitur autem duo circuli in latere uno, et duo in altero.
verses.english: "And you shall cast four gold rings, which you will place on its four feet (or corners), one on each side of the ark. Two rings shall be on one side, and two rings on the other side (providing attachment points for carrying)."

verses.latin: Facies et vectes de lignis setim, et deaurabis eos auro.
verses.english: "You shall also make poles (carrying staves) of acacia wood, and you shall overlay them with gold (matching the ark's precious material)."

verses.latin: Introduscesque per circulos qui sunt in lateribus arcæ, ut portetur in eis.
verses.english: "You shall put these poles through the rings that are on the sides of the ark, so that it may be carried by them (without anyone directly touching the holy ark)."

verses.latin: Qui semper in circulis erunt, nec unquam extrahentur ab illis.
verses.english: "These poles shall remain in the rings permanently. They shall never be removed from them (as a strict command, emphasizing the ark's sanctity and readiness for movement)."

verses.latin: Ponesque in arca testificationem quam dabo tibi.
verses.english: "And you shall put into the ark the Testimony (the two tablets of the Ten Commandments, which bear witness to God's covenant) which I will give to you (as the foundation of My covenant with Israel)."

verses.latin: Facies et propitiatorium de auro mundissimo: duos cubitos et dimidium in longitudine, et cubitum et dimidium in latitudine.
verses.english: "You shall also make a mercy seat (or 'atonement cover') of pure gold. Its length shall be two and a half cubits, and its width one and a half cubits (exactly matching the dimensions of the ark it will cover)."

verses.latin: Duos quoque cherubim aureos, et productiles facies ex utraque parte oraculi.
verses.english: "You shall also make two cherubim (angelic figures, symbolizing heavenly guardians of God's presence) of hammered gold. You shall make them skillfully crafted from the two ends of the mercy seat (where God will speak, hence 'oracle')."

verses.latin: Cherub unus sit in latere uno, et alter cherub in altero latere: ex utraque parte propitiatorii facies eos.
verses.english: "One cherub shall be on one side (of the mercy seat), and the other cherub on the other side. You shall make them to emerge seamlessly from each end of the mercy seat itself." This ensures they are an integral part of the mercy seat.

verses.latin: Extendentesque alas, et operientes propitiatorium, erunt alarum tegminibus, et se mutuo respicient vultibus, versis in propitiatorium.
verses.english: "The cherubim shall have their wings spread upwards, covering the mercy seat with their wings (as if guarding it). And their faces shall be turned towards each other, looking reverently down towards the mercy seat (the place of divine communion and atonement)."

verses.latin: Ponesque propitiatorium desuper arcæ, in qua repones testimonium quod dabo tibi.
verses.english: "And you shall put the mercy seat on top of the ark. In that ark, you shall place the Testimony (the tablets of the Law) which I will give to you (thus the mercy seat covers the Law, signifying God's mercy over judgment)."

verses.latin: Inde præcipiam tibi, et loquar ad te desuper propitiatorio, ac de medio duorum cherubim, qui erunt super arcam testimonii, cuncta quæ mandabo per te filiis Israel.
verses.english: "From there (from above the mercy seat), I will give commands to you. And I will speak with you from above the mercy seat, from between the two cherubim that are upon the ark of the Testimony (the Ark of the Covenant). There, I will give you all the commandments that I will impart through you to the children of Israel (establishing this as the central place of divine revelation and intercession)."

verses.latin: Locutusque est Dominus ad Moysen, dicens:
verses.english: The Lord then spoke to Moses, saying:

verses.latin: Loquere filiis Israël, ut afferant mihi primitias: ab omni homine qui offert ultroneus et sponte cordis, tolletis eas.
verses.english: Speak to the children of Israel and tell them to bring me contributions—offerings for the Tabernacle. You are to receive these gifts from everyone whose heart is willing to give.

verses.latin: Hæc sunt autem quæ accipere debetis: aurum, et argentum, et æs,
verses.english: These are the contributions you shall receive from them: gold, silver, and bronze;

verses.latin: hyacinthum, et purpuram, et coccum bis tinctum, et byssum, et pilos caprarum,
verses.english: blue-violet yarn, purple yarn, scarlet yarn that has been dyed twice, fine linen, and goat hair;

verses.latin: et pelles arietum rubricatas, et pelles hyacintinas, et ligna setim,
verses.english: rams’ skins dyed red, badger skins, and acacia wood;

verses.latin: oleum ad luminaria concinnanda, aromata in unguenta et thymiama, gemmasque onychinas, et lapides ad ornanda superhumerale et rationale.
verses.english: oil for the lamps, aromatic spices for anointing oil and for the fragrant incense, onyx stones, and other precious stones for the ephod and the breastpiece.

verses.latin: oleum ad luminaria concinnanda, aromata in unguenta et thymiama, gemmasque onychinas, et lapides ad ornanda superhumerale et rationale.
verses.english: oil for the lamps, aromatic spices for anointing oil and for the fragrant incense, onyx stones, and other precious stones for the ephod and the breastpiece.

verses.latin: Facientque mihi sanctuarium, et habitabo in medio eorum:
verses.english: And they shall build a sanctuary for Me, so that I may dwell among them and be present with My people.

verses.latin: juxta omnem similitudinem tabernaculi quod ostendam tibi, et omnium vasorum in cultum ejus: sic facietis.
verses.english: You shall make it exactly according to all the design of the Tabernacle that I will show you, and of all its furnishings for its service. You shall make it in this way.

verses.latin: Arcam de lignis setim facies: longitudinem habentem duorum cubitorum et dimidii, et latitudinem cubiti unius et dimidii, altitudinem similiter cubiti unius et dimidii.
verses.english: You shall make an Ark from acacia wood. Its length shall be two and a half cubits, its width one and a half cubits, and its height likewise one and a half cubits.

verses.latin: Et deaurabis eam auro mundissimo: intrinsecus et extrinsecus operies, faciesque in ea coronam auream per circuitum.
verses.english: You shall cover it with the purest gold, inside and outside you shall cover it. You shall also make a golden crown, a molding around its upper edge, all around it.

verses.latin: Et quatuor circulos aureos fundes, et pones per quatuor angulos arcæ: duo circuli sint in latere uno, et duo in altero.
verses.english: And you shall cast four gold rings for it, and place them on its four corners: two rings on one side, and two rings on the other side.

verses.latin: Facies et vectes de lignis setim, et operies eos auro.
verses.english: You shall also make poles from acacia wood, and cover them with gold.

verses.latin: Mittesque in circulos qui sunt in lateribus arcæ, ut portetur in eis.
verses.english: You shall put the poles into the rings that are on the sides of the Ark, so that it may be carried by them.

verses.latin: Jugo semper erunt in circulis, nec extrahentur ex eis.
verses.english: The poles shall remain in the rings permanently; they are not to be removed from them.

verses.latin: Ponesque in arca testificationem quam dabo tibi.
verses.english: And into the Ark you shall put the testimony—the tablets of the Ten Commandments—which I will give to you.

verses.latin: Facies et propitiatorium de auro mundissimo: duos cubitos et dimidium in longitudine, et cubitum ac dimidium in latitudine.
verses.english: You shall also make a propitiatory—a mercy seat—of the purest gold. Its length shall be two and a half cubits, and its width one and a half cubits.

verses.latin: Duos quoque cherubim aureos et protensos facies ex utraque parte oraculi.
verses.english: You shall make two cherubim—angelic figures—of gold. You shall make them of hammered work at the two ends of the propitiatory.

verses.latin: Cherub unus sit in latere uno, et alter cherub in altero latere: ex utraque parte propitiatorii facies eos.
verses.english: Let one cherub be on one end and the other cherub on the other end. From the two ends of the propitiatory, you shall make the cherubim.

verses.latin: Extentisque alis operient propitiatorium, et se mutuo respicient, versis vultibus in propitiatorium quo operienda est arca.
verses.english: The cherubim shall have their wings spread upward, covering the propitiatory with their wings, and they shall face each other, with their faces turned toward the propitiatory, which is to cover the Ark.

verses.latin: Ponesque propitiatorium desuper arcæ, in qua pones testificationem quam dabo tibi.
verses.english: You shall place the propitiatory on top of the Ark, and in the Ark you shall put the testimony—the tablets—which I will give to you.

verses.latin: Et inde præcipiam tibi, et loquar ad te desuper propitiatorio, ac de medio duorum cherubim, qui erunt super arcam testimonii, cuncta quæ mandabo per te filiis Israël.
verses.english: From there I will give you instructions, and I will speak to you from above the propitiatory—the mercy seat—and from between the two cherubim that are upon the Ark of the Testimony, concerning all that I will command you for the children of Israel.

verses.latin: Facies et mensam de lignis setim, habentem longitudinem duorum cubitorum, et latitudinem cubiti unius, et in altitudinem cubitum ac dimidium.
verses.english: You shall also make a table from acacia wood. Its length shall be two cubits, its width one cubit, and its height one and a half cubits.

verses.latin: Et deaurabis eam auro mundissimo, et facies illi coronam auream per circuitum.
verses.english: You shall cover it with the purest gold, and make a golden crown—a molding—all around its edge.

verses.latin: Et quatuor digitis simul et laminam auream, spatio coronæ, in circuitu ejus: et duos annulos aureos per singulos angulos qui in quatuor pedibus sunt.
verses.english: You shall make a rim all around it, a handbreadth wide, and make a golden molding for the rim around it. Also, you shall make two gold rings for it, and place them on the four corners that are on its four legs.

verses.latin: Sub lamina erit annulus, ut mittantur vectes per eos, et possit mensa portari.
verses.english: The ring shall be under the rim, so that poles may be put into them, and the table may be carried.

verses.latin: Ipsosque vectes facies de lignis setim, et operies eos auro, ut in eis mensa portetur.
verses.english: You shall make these poles from acacia wood and cover them with gold, so that the table may be carried by them.

verses.latin: Ponesque super mensam panes propositionis in conspectu meo semper.
verses.english: And on the table you shall always place the Bread of the Presence—the showbread—before Me.

verses.latin: Facies et scyphos ac mortariola, et cyathos ac turibula aurea, in quibus offerenda sunt libamenta.
verses.english: You shall also make its dishes, its censers, its bowls, and its jars of pure gold, in which libations—drink offerings—are to be poured.

verses.latin: Ponesque super mensam panes propositionis in conspectu meo semper.
verses.english: And on the table you shall always place the Bread of the Presence—the showbread—before Me.

verses.latin: Facies et candelabrum lucidissimum de auro puro, et cælatum: hastile ejus, et calamos, scyphos, et sphærulas, ac lilia ex ipso procedentia.
verses.english: You shall also make a lampstand of pure, hammered gold. Its base and its shaft, its cups, its ornamental knobs, and its lilies shall proceed from it as one piece.

verses.latin: Sex calami egredientur de lateribus, tres ex uno latere, et tres ex altero.
verses.english: Six branches shall extend from its sides: three branches of the lampstand from one side, and three branches from the other side.

verses.latin: Tres scyphi quasi nucis avellanæ, in calamo uno, et sphærula simul et lilium: et tres similiter scyphi in calamo altero, quasi nucis avellanæ, sphærula simul et lilium. Opus sex calamorum qui de hastile exeunt.
verses.english: Three cups shaped like almond blossoms, each with its ornamental knob and a lily, shall be on one branch. And similarly, three cups shaped like almond blossoms, each with its ornamental knob and a lily, shall be on the next branch. This pattern applies to all six branches that extend from the lampstand's central shaft.

verses.latin: Et in hastile candelabri, quatuor scyphi quasi nucis avellanæ, et sphærulæ simul et lilia singula.
verses.english: And on the central shaft of the lampstand, there shall be four cups shaped like almond blossoms, each with its ornamental knob and a lily.

verses.latin: Et sphærulæ per singulos calamos, binæ de sex qui procedunt de hastile.
verses.english: There shall also be an ornamental knob under each pair of the six branches that extend from the central shaft of the lampstand.

verses.latin: Et sphærulæ et calami ex ipso erunt, universa puro auro perfecta.
verses.english: Their ornamental knobs and their branches shall be of one piece with the lampstand; all of it shall be one piece of pure, hammered gold.

verses.latin: Facies et lucernas septem, et pones eas super candelabrum, ut luceant ex adverso.
verses.english: You shall also make its seven lamps, and set them on the lampstand so that they give light in front of it.

verses.latin: Emunctoria quoque et exceptoria ubi lucernæ emunguntur, ex auro purissimo.
verses.english: Its snuffers and its trays—for the wicks and soot from the lamps—shall also be of purest gold.

verses.latin: Omnia vasa quæ supra diximus, de talento auri purissimi fiant.
verses.english: All these vessels which we have mentioned shall be made from a talent of purest gold.

verses.latin: Intuere et fac juxta exemplar quod tibi in monte monstratum est.
verses.english: Look carefully and make them according to the pattern that was shown to you on the mountain.

verses.latin: Facies et tabernaculum de decem cortinis de bysso retorta, et hyacintho, et purpura, coccoque bis tincto, variis operibus intertextas.
verses.english: You shall then make the Tabernacle itself—the sacred dwelling place—from ten curtains. These curtains are to be woven from fine twisted linen, along with blue, purple, and double-dyed scarlet threads, skillfully crafted with artistic designs.

verses.latin: Longitudo cortinae unius habebit viginti octo cubitos: latitudo quatuor cubitorum erit aequalis mensura omnium cortinarum.
verses.english: Each one of these curtains is to be twenty-eight cubits long, which is about forty-two feet, and four cubits wide, which is about six feet. All the curtains will have the exact same measurements.

verses.latin: Quinque cortinae jungentur sibi mutuo, et quinque aliae alteri cohaerebunt.
verses.english: Five of these curtains are to be joined together to form one large sheet, and the other five curtains will likewise be joined together to form a second large sheet.

verses.latin: Facies et ansulas hyacinthinas in extremitatibus et ex utraque parte cortinae unius, et alterius ejusdem modi.
verses.english: You shall also make loops of blue thread along the edge of the first set of five curtains, and similar loops along the edge of the second set of five curtains, on the sides where they will be joined.

verses.latin: Quinquaginta ansulas in cortina una, et quinquaginta ansulas in summitate alterius cortinae facies, ita ut contra se invicem respiciant ansulae, et altera alteri possit adjungi.
verses.english: You are to make fifty loops on the edge of one large curtain sheet, and fifty loops on the edge of the other large curtain sheet. These loops should be directly opposite each other, so that one sheet can be joined to the other.

verses.latin: Facies et quinquaginta annulos aureos, quibus cortinarum junges ansulas, et fiet unum tabernaculum.
verses.english: Then you will make fifty golden clasps. With these clasps, you will join the loops of the curtains, and in this way, the two large sheets will become one complete Tabernacle covering.

verses.latin: Facies et operimentum tabernaculi de undecim ciliciis caprarum.
verses.english: You will also make an outer covering for the Tabernacle from eleven curtains woven from goat hair.

verses.latin: Longitudo cilicii unius habebit triginta cubitos: et latitudo quatuor cubitorum erit aequalis mensura omnium cilicii.
verses.english: Each one of these goat hair curtains is to be thirty cubits long, which is about forty-five feet, and four cubits wide, which is about six feet. All the goat hair curtains will have the exact same measurements.

verses.latin: Quinque cortinas seorsum junges, et sex alias seorsum: ita ut sexta cortina duplicetur in fronte tabernaculi.
verses.english: You will join five of these goat hair curtains together into one section, and the other six curtains into a second section, so that the sixth curtain in this second section will be folded over at the very front of the Tabernacle, providing extra coverage.

verses.latin: Facies et quinquaginta ansulas in ora cortinae unius, et quinquaginta ansulas in ora cortinae alterius, ut invicem cohaereant.
verses.english: You shall make fifty loops along the edge of one section of goat hair curtains, and fifty loops along the edge of the other section of goat hair curtains, so that they can be joined together.

verses.latin: Et quinquaginta annulos aeneos, quibus junges ansulas, et fiet unum tectum.
verses.english: And you will make fifty bronze clasps, which you will use to join the loops. In this way, the two sections of goat hair curtains will form one unified roof covering.

verses.latin: Quod autem superfluum est in ciliciis operimenti, id est, unum cubitum ex utraque parte, pendebit super latera tabernaculi.
verses.english: The surplus fabric from the goat hair covering, specifically one cubit from each side, will hang down over the sides of the Tabernacle.

verses.latin: Et cubitus unus ex utraque parte quae redundat in longitudine tecti tabernaculi, utrumque latus tabernaculi tegiet.
verses.english: And the extra cubit of length from each end of the roof covering for the Tabernacle will cover both sides of the Tabernacle structure, extending fully over it.

verses.latin: Facies et operimentum tabernaculi de pellibus arietum rubricatis, et aliud desuper de pellibus hyacinthinis.
verses.english: You shall also make an additional covering for the Tabernacle from rams' skins dyed red, and above that, another covering made from fine leather.

verses.latin: Facies et tabulas tabernaculi de lignis setim stantes.
verses.english: You are to make the upright frames for the Tabernacle from acacia wood.

verses.latin: Decem cubitos altitudinis habebit tabula una: et in una tabula duo cubiti erit latitudo.
verses.english: Each frame board will be ten cubits high, which is about fifteen feet, and two cubits wide, which is about three feet.

verses.latin: Binas incastratas per singulas tabulas, ut altera alteri jungatur. Sic facies in cunctis tabulis tabernaculi.
verses.english: Each board will have two tenons at its bottom, like pegs, designed to fit into sockets, so that one board can be securely joined to another. You are to make all the boards for the Tabernacle this way.

verses.latin: E quibus viginti tabulae erunt in plagam meridianam, contra austrum.
verses.english: Of these boards, twenty will be placed on the south side, facing the south wind.

verses.latin: Quarantam bases argenteas facies, quae supponantur viginti tabulis. Binae bases sub singulis tabulis per singulas incastratas.
verses.english: You shall make forty silver bases to support these twenty boards. There will be two bases under each board, one for each of its tenons.

verses.latin: In latere quoque secundo tabernaculi, quod vergit ad aquilonem, viginti tabulae erunt.
verses.english: On the second side of the Tabernacle, which faces the north, there will also be twenty boards.

verses.latin: Et bases argenteas quadraginta. Binae bases sub singulis tabulis.
verses.english: And for these, you will make forty silver bases, with two bases under each board.

verses.latin: Ad occidentalem vero plagam tabernaculi facies sex tabulas.
verses.english: For the west side of the Tabernacle, you are to make six boards.

verses.latin: Et duas alias tabulas facies per singulos angulos tabernaculi contra dorsa sua, et erunt junctae deorsum usque sursum, et pariter in unum convenient capite, et cardine. Ita fiet in utraque parte, et duobus angulis.
verses.english: And you will make two additional boards for the corners of the Tabernacle at the rear. These corner boards will be joined from the bottom all the way to the top and meet perfectly at the corner with a pivot-like joint. This is how it will be done for both corners.

verses.latin: Et erunt junctae deorsum usque sursum, et pariter in unum convenient capite, et cardine. Ita fiet in utraque parte, et duobus angulis.
verses.english: These boards will be joined securely from the bottom up to the very top, meeting together in a single unit at the top and by means of a precise hinge. This design will be applied to both parts and both corners, ensuring stability.

verses.latin: Et octo tabulae, et bases argenteae sedecim. Binae bases erunt sub singulis tabulis.
verses.english: So, for the west side and its corners, there will be a total of eight boards, and sixteen silver bases, with two bases under each board.

verses.latin: Facies et vectes de lignis setim, quinque ad continendas tabulas lateris unius tabernaculi,
verses.english: You shall also make crossbars from acacia wood: five bars to hold together the boards on one side of the Tabernacle.

verses.latin: et quinque alterius lateris, et quinque ad occidentalem plagam in dorsalibus tabernaculi.
verses.english: And five bars for the boards on the other side of the Tabernacle, and five bars for the west side, which is the rear of the Tabernacle.

verses.latin: Ipseque vectis medius transibit per medias tabulas a summo usque ad summum.
verses.english: The middle crossbar will run all the way through the centers of the boards, from one end to the other, providing continuous strength.

verses.latin: Ipsasque tabulas operies auro, et anulos fundes aureos, per quos vectes introferantur: ipsosque vectes operies auro.
verses.english: You are to overlay the boards themselves with pure gold, and you will cast golden rings to serve as holders, through which the crossbars will be passed. And you shall also overlay the crossbars themselves with pure gold.

verses.latin: Et eriges tabernaculum juxta exemplum quod tibi in monte monstratum est.
verses.english: You are to set up the Tabernacle exactly according to the pattern that was shown to you on the mountain.

verses.latin: Facies et velum de hyacintho, et purpura, coccoque bis tincto, et bysso retorta, opere polymitarius intertextum, et varium,
verses.english: You shall also make an inner veil from blue, purple, and double-dyed scarlet threads, along with fine twisted linen. It must be skillfully woven with intricate embroidery, showing various artistic designs.

verses.latin: quod appendes aureis annulis super quatuor columnas de lignis setim, quae et ipsae auro vestientur, et bases habebunt argenteas.
verses.english: You will hang this veil by golden rings upon four pillars made of acacia wood. These pillars are themselves to be overlaid with gold and set into silver bases.

verses.latin: Intra velum pones arcam testimonii, et quod sanctuarium et sanctorum erit, velo dividetur.
verses.english: Inside this veil, you are to place the Ark of the Testimony. The veil will then serve as the division between the Holy Place and the Most Holy Place, separating these two sacred areas.

verses.latin: Pones et propitiatorium super arcam testimonii in sancta sanctorum.
verses.english: You shall also place the Mercy Seat upon the Ark of the Testimony within the Most Holy Place itself.

verses.latin: Et pones mensam extra velum, et candelabrum ex adverso mensae in latere tabernaculi, quod vergit ad meridiem: mensam vero in latere aquilonis.
verses.english: You are to place the table outside the veil, and the lampstand opposite the table on the south side of the Tabernacle, with the table itself on the north side.

verses.latin: Facies et tentorium in introitu tabernaculi de hyacintho, et purpura, coccoque bis tincto, et bysso retorta, opere plumarii.
verses.english: You shall also make a screen for the entrance of the Tabernacle, using blue, purple, and double-dyed scarlet threads, along with fine twisted linen, all expertly embroidered.

verses.latin: Et quinque columnas de lignis setim, quae auro vestientur, et capita earum aurea erunt, basesque aeneas fundes.
verses.english: And for this screen, you will make five pillars of acacia wood, which are to be overlaid with gold. Their capitals—the decorative tops—will also be golden, and you shall cast bronze bases for them.

verses.latin: Facies quoque altare de lignis setim, quinque cubitorum longitudinis, et totidem latitudinis, id est, quadratum, et trium cubitorum altitudinis.
verses.english: You shall also make an altar out of acacia wood. It must be five cubits long and five cubits wide, so it will be square, and it must be three cubits high.

verses.latin: Cornuaque per quatuor angulos ex ipso procedant: et operies illud aere.
verses.english: Make four horn-like projections extending from its four corners, all of it made from the same wood. Then cover the entire altar and its horns with bronze.

verses.latin: Parabisque in usus ejus lebetes ad cineres auferendos, et forcipes atque fuscinulas, et uncos et ignitum, omnia vasa ejus ex aere.
verses.english: You shall also make all the necessary tools for the altar: pans for removing the ashes, shovels, meat forks, and fire pans. All these tools must be made of bronze.

verses.latin: Craticulamque illi aeneam in modum retis: per cujus quatuor angulos quatuor annulos aeneos facies.
verses.english: You shall also make a bronze grate for it, designed like a net, and attach four bronze rings to its four corners.

verses.latin: Et pones eam subter marginem altaris inferiorem: eritque craticula usque ad medium altaris.
verses.english: You must place this bronze grate below the lower rim of the altar, extending halfway up the altar itself.

verses.latin: Facies et vectes altaris de lignis setim, quos operies ære.
verses.english: You shall also make carrying poles for the altar out of acacia wood, and cover these poles with bronze.

verses.latin: Et perducas per annulos, eruntque vectes ex utroque latere altaris, ut portetur.
verses.english: These poles are to be inserted through the rings on the altar, so they extend from both sides, allowing the altar to be carried.

verses.latin: Non solidum, sed inane et cavum intrinsecus facies illud, sicut tibi in monte monstratum est.
verses.english: You must make this altar hollow and empty on the inside, not solid, exactly as it was shown to you on the mountain.

verses.latin: Facies et atrium tabernaculi, in cujus australi plaga erunt cortinae de bysso retorta, centum cubitos longitudinis, una ex parte.
verses.english: You shall also make a courtyard for the Tent of Meeting. On its south side, there will be hangings made of finely twisted linen, a hundred cubits long on that one side.

verses.latin: Columnas viginti cum basibus totidem aeneis, et capita columnarum, annulosque earum argenteos.
verses.english: For this, there will be twenty posts with twenty bronze bases, and the tops of these posts, along with their connecting rods, shall be made of silver.

verses.latin: Similiter ad plagam septentrionalem per longum, centum cubitos erunt cortinae, columnas viginti, et bases aeneas ejusdem numeri, et capita columnarum, annulosque argenteos.
verses.english: Similarly, for the north side, there will be hangings a hundred cubits long, along with twenty posts, the same number of bronze bases, and silver tops for the posts and their connecting rods.

verses.latin: In latitudine vero atrii, quæ respicit ad occidentem, per quinquaginta cubitos erunt cortinæ, et columnas decem, et bases totidem.
verses.english: For the width of the courtyard, facing west, there will be hangings fifty cubits long, with ten posts and ten bases.

verses.latin: In ea quoque latitudine atrii, quæ respicit ad orientem, quinquaginta cubitos.
verses.english: For the width of the courtyard that faces east, it will also be fifty cubits.

verses.latin: Decem cubitorum cortinae unius lateris, et columnas tres, et bases totidem.
verses.english: On one side of the entrance, there will be hangings ten cubits long, with three posts and three bases.

verses.latin: Et in alterius lateris decem cubitorum erunt cortinae, et columnas tres, et bases totidem.
verses.english: And on the other side of the entrance, there will also be hangings ten cubits long, with three posts and three bases.

verses.latin: In introitu autem atrii fient vela, viginti cubitorum altitudinis, ex hyacintho et purpura, coccoque bis tincto, et bysso retorta, opere plumarii: columnas quatuor, et bases totidem.
verses.english: At the entrance of the courtyard, you shall make a screen of twenty cubits in height, crafted from blue, purple, and scarlet material, and finely twisted linen, embroidered with designs. For this screen, there will be four posts and four bases.

verses.latin: Omnes columnæ atrii per circuitum, argenteis circulis junctæ erunt, et capitibus argenteis, basibus aeneis.
verses.english: All the posts around the perimeter of the courtyard shall be joined with silver connecting rods and have silver caps, and all their bases will be bronze.

verses.latin: In longitudine occupabit atrium centum cubitos, in latitudine quinquaginta, altitudine quinque cubitos, de bysso retorta: et bases columnarum aeneæ.
verses.english: The courtyard will be a hundred cubits long and fifty cubits wide. Its hangings will be five cubits high, made of finely twisted linen, and all the bases of its posts shall be bronze.

verses.latin: Cuncta vasa tabernaculi in omni usu atque cæremoniis, et universi pali ejus, et atrii, ex ære fient.
verses.english: All the tools for the Tent of Meeting, used for every service and ceremony, and all its pegs, as well as the pegs for the courtyard, must be made of bronze.

verses.latin: Præcipe filiis Israel ut afferant tibi oleum de olivis purissimum atque limpidissimum, ad concinnandas lucernas jugiter.
verses.english: Command the sons of Israel to bring you the purest and clearest olive oil, so that the lamps may be kept burning continually.

verses.latin: In tabernaculo testimonii extra velum, quod est ante testimonium, ordinabunt illud Aaron et filii ejus, ut ardeat a vespere usque mane coram Domino, justum est sempiternum in generationibus eorum a filiis Israel.
verses.english: In the Tent of Meeting, outside the veil that screens the Testimony, Aaron and his sons shall tend these lamps so they burn from evening until morning before the Lord. This is a perpetual decree for the generations of the sons of Israel.

verses.latin: Accipe autem tecum Aaron fratrem tuum cum filiis suis de medio filiorum Israel, ut sacerdotio fungantur mihi: Aaron, Nadab, Abiu, Eleazar et Ithamar.
verses.english: You are to bring to yourself, Moses, your brother Aaron along with his sons from among the children of Israel. They are to perform the sacred office of priest for me: Aaron, Nadab, Abiu, Eleazar, and Ithamar.

verses.latin: Faciesque vestes sanctas Aaron fratri tuo in gloriam et decorem.
verses.english: You shall then make sacred garments for Aaron your brother, which are for his glory and for his beauty.

verses.latin: Et loqueris ad omnes sapientes corde, quos replevi spiritu sapientiae, ut faciant vestes Aaron, in quibus sanctificatus ministret mihi.
verses.english: And you shall speak to all those with wise hearts, whom I have filled with the spirit of wisdom. They are to make Aaron’s garments, in which he will be consecrated and minister to me.

verses.latin: Haec autem sunt vestimenta quae facienda sunt: rationale, et ephod, et tunica, et linea stricta, cidarim, et balteum. Vestimenta sancta facient Aaron fratri tuo et filiis ejus, ut sacerdotio fungantur mihi.
